captions: That gentle evening light flooding into the kitchen, a bunch of overblown pink tulips and a plate of leftover meringues inviting me to help myself. Small things, all making me feel happy today. I love that the days are getting so long - feels like summer is well on its way. Hope youre week is off to a good start too

Last week I made a tarte tatin - with a box of nespole (loquats) that we had lying about in the kitchen and that were almost past their best. I had almost forgotten quite how much I love tarte tatin: that buttery pastry laced with just that hint of burnt caramel and ever-so-slightly tart fruit. I thought I would share the recipe here in case you too find yourself in the mood for a spoiling pudding: if you dont have loquats, you can make it with apricots instead. Other heavenly variations on the theme of tarte tatin are apple and peach. Youll need: 600g loquats (roughly); a squeeze of lemon juice; 20g butter + extra for greasing the pan; 80g caster sugar; 1 x packet of ready rolled puff pastry; 1 egg (lightly whisked); and a handful of coarsely chopped pistachios. Heat the oven to 180C. Halve and peel the loquats, scoop out their stones and discard. Arrange the fruit snugly in a frying pan (ideally one with a heatproof handle so you can use it in the oven), squeeze over the lemon juice and add a splash of water, cover and set over a medium heat for 5-10 mins until the fruit has softened a little. Take the fruit out, set to one side and grease the pan with butter. Pour the sugar into a small saucepan with 3 tbsp water and set over a medium-low heat - dont stir but very gently shake the pan from time to time; when the sugar syrup begins to caramelise, take it off the heat and add the butter. Stir in to melt, and add a generous pinch of salt. Pour the caramel into the buttered pan, then arrange the fruit snugly over the thin layer of caramel (cut side up). Cover the fruit with the puff pastry, tucking the edges in snugly around the loquats (or apricots or what-have-you). Lightly glaze the pastry with the egg. Bake for 35-40 mins until the pastry is crisp and golden. Allow to cool in the pan for 5 mins, then turn out onto a plate and sprinkle over the pistachios. Eat warm with ice cream or thick, runny double cream

Weve been in lockdown for eight weeks now (I think? Ive lost track of time...) and Ive found that as a family weve come to develop our own happy pseudo-traditions in this time: on Friday nights we have pizza and watch a movie together. And once a week (usually on a Saturday) we roast a rib of beef which we eat warm with roast potatoes and all the trimmings. Then the next day we have what is leftover of the beef cold for lunch, and make sandwiches with buttered sourdough tomato, peppery rocket and heaps of horseradish (probably the highlight of my week). During this period of lockdown, Ive found myself cooking more than ever and a silver lining has been the joy of rediscovering old recipes and cookbooks that I love but hadnt looked at properly in years. This Wednesday (20th) at 6pm (GMT) Ill be in conversation with @emily.k.tobin and @the_calico_club talking all things cooking-in-quarantine and favourite cookbooks. Would love you to join: tickets are available through the link in @the_calico_club the_calico_club profile.

Ive been cooking a lot with freezer ingredients the last few weeks - and this recipe for Pea, Basil and Watercress Soup, served chilled with a dollop of crme fraiche, is one that I make often and really love. I thought that I would share the recipe here in case you feel like making it too: heat a dash of olive oil (roughly 2 tbsp) in a saucepan over a medium heat, then add 1 chopped onion (I use the frozen kind, because Im super lazy about chopping onion) and a pinch of salt. Cook for 5 minutes or so, until soft and translucent then add a bag of frozen peas and cover with 1l vegetable stock. Simmer gently for 10 minutes, then take off the heat and throw in a small bunch of basil and a couple of handfuls of fresh watercress (if you have them - otherwise fresh mint or just the peas soup as is are both delicious). Blitz in a blender until smooth, season with salt and pepper, then chill in the fridge. Serve with bread and lashings of crme fraiche

Please join me this Thursday (14th May) for a live cook-along with @anthropologieeu: well be baking a summer berry pavlova and Ill be answering any cooking quandaries (quarantine or otherwise) you might have. Im so looking forward to it and would love to see you there: 1pm (GMT), tickets are free (though donations to NHS Charities Together are welcome) and can be booked through the link in my profile or in the events section of the @anthropologieeu homepage.

All sorts of store cupboard recipes for my @sundaytimesfood column this weekend: the kind of simple food that you can easily magic together out of tins, jars and other bits you likely have hanging around in your kitchen. Pasta with anchovies, pistachio and lemon (tastes like a summer holiday); chickpea, tomato and saffron stew (a much treasured recipe and, incidentally, what we ate for lunch today); onion soup (with grilled bread and melted cheese on top); and toasted sourdough with dark chocolate, olive oil and salt (words cant fully describe how good this is). You can find all the recipes in the @thestmagazine or online - should they take your fancy.

Last October I was lucky enough to spend a few sun-kissed, blissfully peaceful days at the @arnianopaintingschool. Still now I dream about it and long to go back: the most heavenly food and company, idyllic countryside and days spent learning to paint (sort of). I wrote a piece about it in this months issue of @tatlermagazine: it feels like a lifetime ago now but the very happiest of memories that I will treasure always. @delilahkhomo @amberguinness @matthewbellglobal @willropercurzon

I had such a fun time this morning baking these sweet almond pastries on the @bloomsburycooks Tuesday cook-along... and as an added bonus, we now have lots leftover to eat. Thank you to everyone who joined me - it was such a joy cooking with you and the highlight of my week! If you missed it, you can find the full recipe for the pastries in my book A Table in Venice and you can also watch the video demo for how to make them (I cant tell you how easy they are to do!) on the @bloomsburycooks stories for a little while longer.

Todays lunch was mostly cobbled out of leftovers from the weekend: a dish of baba ganoush revived with a generous glug of olive oil; cous cous salad with capers, parsley and some bbq-ed sweet peppers thrown in; and warm flatbreads lightly brushed in melted, ever-so-slightly salted butter. We had lots of veggie odds and ends hanging about in the fridge, which @anthonysantospirito deep fried in a light batter: zucchine blossoms, a few asparagus, some bushy fennel tops, sage leaves, and best of all... chunks of mozzarella which, when fried, melted to the point of near perfection. Chocolate brownies for pudding. Highlight of my day

During lockdown, more than ever meals have come to punctuate our days: theyre something to look forward to, to plan for, to cook for, and then to enjoy together. We spring from breakfast to lunch to dinner - and then start again the next day. I like weekends to feel a little special so instead of our usual porridge or toast, we treat ourselves to an extra spoiling breakfast: yesterday (Saturday) was hot chocolate and pastries (pain au chocolat and apricot danish) and today ambrosial, deeply indulgent maritozzi (sweet, soft buns filled with whipped cream) and a pot of hot tea

Next Tuesday (5th May) at 1pm GMT Im excited to be taking over the @bloomsburycooks account and hosting a live cook-a-long. Ill be baking almond paste croissants (so good!) and would love you to join me. If you feel like baking along with me (and treating yourself to a warm croissant after), youll need 2 packets of ready rolled puff pastry, 1 egg, 30g flaked almonds and 90g ground almonds, a spoonful of apricot jam and a dash of icing sugar. Hope to see you there!

Ive been working to a tight deadline so lunch today was thrown together in a hurry: smoked burrata cheese with tomatoes and a generous glug of olive oil; Sicilian cous cous salad with tuna, almonds, parsley and slivers of crisp fennel (a recipe from the throw together section of my new book); and a big plate of mortadella peppered with pistachios (so good). Super simple to pull together, but my favourite kind of food to eat

When your husband is Australian, Sunday lunch bbq is a serious matter: sausages and lamb skewers; corn on the cob with butter and paprika salt; baby baked potatoes; roasted aubergine and peppers; pumpkin roasted in the embers with butter and honey; and a watermelon carpaccio (so good and a recipe from my new cookbook). Triple chocolate brownies for pudding. @anthonysantospirito
Two tiers of carrot cake layered with lemon-y marzipan buttercream baked with love for one very special birthday girl. @cgconsultancy @sophiegoodwin

Delighted and honoured to be the first guest on @hamishbowless fabulous new cookery series for @voguemagazine: I had the best time cooking a feast for one (chilled almond soup, salmon & baby asparagus en papillotte, tomato salad, and strawberries in sweet balsamic syrup) with Hamish, and admiring his dreamy collection of pink plates and Gucci tumblers. You can find the video we made (via Zoom!) along with the recipes for dinner online at @voguemagazine (or through the link in my stories). Ps Baby Achille says hi!

Spending the day being cosy and at home (for obvious reasons): we had fluffy buttermilk pancakes for breakfast (my favourite); and barbecued sausages with corn on the cob, followed by toasted marshmallow smores for lunch. Highlight of the day. Other things bringing me great joy: freshly baked chocolate and almond butter cookies (@melissa.hemsleys brilliant recipe which Im completely obsessed with), a loaf of soda and walnut bread still warm from the oven, and the magnificent, rainbow-hued tulips sitting on our kitchen counter, which @milliproust sent us as a present a few days ago. Hope youre well and taking care of yourself - and that your weekend has been happy too

Finally starting on this tapestry that Ive had tucked away in a drawer for forever. May take me a while (!)... but the plan is to make a cushion for the big bucket armchair in our yellow kitchen, the one where Aeneas likes to sit while I cook

I made bread and butter pudding with some (slightly stale) hot cross buns that we had in our bread bin, then layered them with sticky marzipan and sweet apricot jam: such a treat. Pretty much the most comforting pudding ever. So I thought I would share the recipe here... You can play around with the recipe as you like, depending on what you have to hand, but to make a pudding for 8-10 (or for a family of 4 with plenty of leftovers to reheat the next day) youll need: 8 hot cross buns; 5-6 tbsp apricot jam; 120g marzipan; 500ml milk; 75ml double cream; 3 eggs; 40g caster sugar. Heat the oven to 180C. Cut the buns in half, and arrange the bottom halves snugly in a heatproof dish. Spoon the apricot jam over them, then cut the marzipan into small pieces and sprinkle over the jam. Sandwich the hot cross tops on top of the bottoms. Gently warm the milk and cream together in a saucepan, taking care not to let it boil (you want to take it off the heat just as the tiniest little bubbles begin to form at the edge of the pan). Crack the eggs into a mixing bowl, add the sugar and beat with a fork until smooth. Pour in the warmed milk and whisk until smooth and combined. Pour the custard over the marzipan filled buns and set in the oven for 30-40 mins, until the custard is set and the pudding is golden brown on top. Hope you like it

The most spoiling surprise when I opened the front door this afternoon to find this beautiful bucket of flowers. I was so touched: its a present from my sweetest friend @milliproust who lovingly grew each and every one of these sweet scented blooms herself, in her own garden. How lucky I am to have such wonderful friends in my life - and how I long to spend lots and lots of time together once this lockdown is over.

Over the past few weeks of lockdown, Ive been looking to our freezer for inspiration when cooking, getting creative with bags of frozen peas, berries and the like. Some of my most trusty recipes made with frozen goods are online with @sundaytimesfood now: haddock and pecorino fishcakes; prawn and lemon risotto; pasta with peas and cream; and a heavenly amaretto and berry crumble cake (which Aeneas has declared his favourite cake ever

Happy Easter! Hoping youre well and safe. Easter this year has been different: were especially missing @romilly_mca who we always celebrate special occasions with... But we had pancakes for breakfast, a wild chocolate egg hunt in the kitchen, and a very spoiling lunch. Rack of lamb in a pistachio crust (delicious recipe from the @tablemannerspodcast cookbook), peas, cheesy baked leeks and panzanella salad. For pudding: soft, sweet colomba (Italian Easter cake, kind of like panettone with a sugar almond topping) with salted honey and chocolate chip ice cream (a favourite recipe from my new cookbook, which is released later this year). All round its been a happy day - hope yours has been too and sending lots love from locked-down London

Delighted to contribute a recipe for this Lemon and Lavender Cream Cake to @cook.corriere this weekend. You can find the recipe online (on the Corriere della Sera website or follow the link in my stories) along with lots of other Easter delights from some of my favourites @valdirose @mimithor @angelafrenda. Happy Easter! Xx

Have been spending the past week plotting and planning what we should eat over this Easter weekend, thinking of menus that feel like a special treat. Am thinking rack of lamb for lunch on Sunday and hot cross buns in many incarnations over the course of the weekend... but lunch today was melon and prosciutto; deep fried zucchine blossoms (filled with smoked cheese), sage leaves and fennel (so good!); chilled almond soup with cheesy bread and sweet grapes. No pudding, but lemon and lavender cream cake for afternoon tea

I made this summer berry pavlova for a special treat last Sunday and am thinking about making it again over the weekend for Easter. I thought I would share the rough recipe here in case you fancy making it too and hope that you enjoy it as much as I do! So: you will need 4 egg whites (I used the ones that come in a carton but obviously separating eggs works just as well then you can use the yolks for making mayonnaise or zabaione); 200g caster sugar (plus a couple of tbsp extra to sprinkle on top of the fruit); 500ml thick double cream; a punnet each of strawberries and blackberries. Heat the oven to 140 C, and line a baking tray with greaseproof paper. Whisk the egg whites until frothy, then add the sugar, one spoonful at a time, whisking all the while until you have a stiff glossy white mass. Spoon the meringue onto the baking tray and spread it out into the a thick circle. Bake in the oven for 1 hour, then switch off the oven but do not open the door and leave the meringue in there for another hour. Whisk the cream until thickened. Put the meringue on a nice serving plate, spoon the whipped cream over it, arrange the berries on top and sprinkle over a couple of spoonfuls of sugar. You could also top with mini eggs, if you wanted something extra Easter-y! Keep in the fridge for up to a few hours before serving
In other news: this little one is now officially on the move and crawling

I have no notion of time at the moment, as each day merges into the next: it feels like time is passing so very slowly and yet somehow here we are and another week has flown by. Its Sunday and the sun is shining, so: bbq on our tiny back patio for lunch (sausages, steak and heaps of delicious grilled veggies), and pavlova with thick whipped Jersey cream, strawberries and sharp blackberries for pudding (because somehow pavlova and bbq go hand in hand). Cant think of a happier way to spend the day

Todays lunch was roast chicken, crispy potatoes, fennel and citrus salad, peas, jammy roasted plums, and hot cross bun & chestnut stuffing (so good!). We spent most of the morning cooking together, and the afternoon lazily eating lunch and chatting round the table. Then: a game of Scrabble and movie night
Feeling luckier than ever to have these two little treasures in my life - today most especially. Happy Mothers Day to all the Mammas out there - I hope youve been spoiled rotten as you deserve to be!

I baked a cake today. Pistachio butter cake with rose scented marzipan icing. Because tomorrow is my birthday and while it might feel like the world is falling apart around us, its still not a birthday without cake. I havent been online much of late: it seems so frivolous to talk about sweets, and dinner menus, and the like when the world feels so very full of fear and sadness. Yet somehow these smaller things in life - a lovingly cooked meal or a cheery bunch of flowers - feel more precious to me now than ever; they bring joy when Im feeling down, and my hope is that by sharing those moments here it might bring you a tiny bit of joy too. Heres hoping for brighter days to come, and in the meantime sending love from our little kitchen in London xx
The promise of Spring in our kitchen... even though its storming, dark and horribly grey outside the window.

Weekend baking: a beetroot & gorgonzola tart with a few crumbled walnuts thrown in, in the making. Recipe lightly adapted from one I did for the @sundaytimesfood a while back (should be online in their archives). Hope youre having a happy Sunday too

Happy remnants of last nights heavenly supper with friends: we had spinach and cheese frittata, lentil and wild rice salad, a big plate of bresaola with Parmesan... and for pudding red wine poached pears and a chocolate, chestnut & rosemary cake. What was leftover of the cake, I treated myself to for breakfast this morning. Such a fun evening in the very best of company

Out and about running errands in London today and theres definitely more than a whisper of Spring in the air: daffodils in Hyde Park; tulips for sale by the armful on the flower stands; crisp blue skies; lighter, brighter evenings; and the promise of warm, sunny weather to come

All sorts of scrumptious, comforting polenta concoctions in my column for the @sundaytimesfood today: grilled polenta bites with mushrooms and buttery tomato sauce; polenta quiche with baby tomatoes and pancetta; and buttercup yellow polenta cake with jammy raspberries. Quick, easy and so so good. Recipes in todays ST Magazine and online.
When its a howling gale outside so you spend the afternoon curled up on the sofa with cake and a mug of hot tea

So happy to be back in Venice after being away for a couple of months. Especially lucky with the weather: blue blue skies and a crisp chill in the air; and Carneval is in full flow with flamboyant costumes here there and everywhere

I have some VERY exciting news that Ive been longing to share with you: this past year Ive been working on a new cookbook! Its called A Table for Friends: The Art of Cooking for Two or Twenty and will be published by @bloomsburycooks this Summer... just a few months to go! There are honestly few things in life that give me greater pleasure than to sit down to a good lunch (or dinner) in the company of friends that I love: this is a book about how to cook for friends and how to enjoy doing it (and not end up slaving away in the kitchen while everyone else is having a wonderful time). After years of hosting more people than its ever seemed sensible to squeeze round our dining table, this book is everything that Ive learned: tips, tricks and just over 100 simple recipes, ones that I cook time and time again and truly love (like burrata with preserved lemon, honey roast poussin, leeks bakes in creamy mustard sauce, pistachio butter cake with marzipan buttercream icing, chocolate and sugared chestnut pavlova cake, and so many more...). The recipes fall into 3 chapters: stars, sides and sweets - plus should you need a little something extra (like homemade mayonnaise or freshly baked bread) then there is a chapter of extras too at the very back of the book. And because the biggest challenge for me as a homecook is always juggling oven space, all the recipes are divided by how you cook them - throw together (no actual cooking per se involved), on the hob and in the oven - to help you create a stress-free menu that works well for your kitchen and for your life (there are plenty of menu suggestions too, should you be looking for inspiration). This is a book that Ive been writing in my head for years and that I have long wished that I owned on my shelf: its been a labour of love to create and Im so excited to see it come to life. I cant wait to hear what you think!! You can find more details on Amazon (just follow the link in my profile), where you can also pre-order it and make me the happiest person in the world

Sunday lunch was spinach and cheese frittata, roasted bay leaf potatoes, and a big bowl of winter tomato salad. Finished off with pavlova cake (special request from @anthonysantospirito): three tiers of rose scented meringue with whipped cream, lychees, raspberries and pistachios

My favourite and most trusted recipes for making use of leftover roast chicken in todays @sundaytimesfood column: a chicken, chestnut and pancetta pie; wonderfully soothing chicken and lemon soup; and a chicken salad with crusty bread, dates, almonds and ridiculously more-ish spiced honeyed dressing
Running a few errands in Notting Hill today, lapping up the bright blue skies and the pretty street views. Followed by lunch and a long stroll in the park

Playing around in the kitchen with Achille. Thank you sweet @phoeberosesocial for snapping this photo, which I will treasure in years to come when those baby cuddles (and deliciously chubby cheeks) become a memory
Its a good day when you have cake for breakfast. Roasted sugary pink rhubarb and jasmine tea to go with it are an added bonus

Winter sunshine - quasi magical and soul soothing - as it pours in through the living room window. I love those bright, crisp winter days in London - I can feel my mood lifting with every little drop of sunlight.

Cosy and wonderfully relaxed Sunday lunch: we had roast chicken (my favourite) with potatoes, roasted carrots and a big salad. For pudding this pistachio butter cake with marzipan icing and a dish of roasted, ever-so-slightly-sugared rhubarb. Best of all the company. @gianlucalongogg @martinamondadori

A few things that I love: these old copper moulds (bought on Ebay) which double as decoration and cooking utensils; cookbooks that Im loving reading (and cooking from) right now; the first daffodils of the season; an old blue jug from @charliebordewichantiques and a beautiful hand painted glass one from my brilliant friend @petra_palumbo

Pretty-in-pink rhubarb recipes in todays @sundaytimesfood: buttery rhubarb, goats cheese and walnut salad; smoked mackerel with roasted rhubarb; and a baked ricotta and rhubarb cheesecake. Find the recipes in todays paper or online
A lazy Saturday with no great plans other than pottering in the kitchen - baking, cooking and spending time with my boys. Hope youre having a wonderful weekend too!

I dont usually bother much cooking for myself. If its just me Ill have some tomatoes on toast or something like that. But today I made myself a proper lunch (though nonetheless pretty quick to throw together): smoked mackerel fillets with a heavenly rocket, parsley, date and almond salad (inspired by one similar that we had for lunch at @lhotelmarrakech on our recent trip to Morocco). And I thought I really should do this more often
Back in the kitchen after the holidays, and making lemon meringue pie with a thick, creamy lemon curd filling.
Happy new year from Marrakech! Heres to the new year bringing much love, happiness, good health and buckets of sweet scented roses

A pretty perfect spot for lunch: in the warm dappled shade, at the edge of a field of sweet scented roses. And if you look out into the distance you can see the Atlas Mountains looming magnificently not so very far away. This morning we explored the Jardin Majorelle; and this afternoon we had chocolate ice cream and I read my book (The Light Years by E J Howard) sitting in the garden. I never want to leave. @beldicountryclub

A three hour flight, a short drive, a hop and a skip and I feel like weve stepped into another world - one where the air feels warm, and smells of roses mingled with orange blossom, and where the skies are the softest shade of pink

Achille is six months old today. Where does time go?! We spent most of the day lounging in our pyjamas, eating leftovers, basking generally in a happy post-Christmas glow, and packing for our trip to Morocco tomorrow. Cant think of a lovelier Boxing Day - hope yours was every bit as happy and lazy.
Happy Christmas! Wishing you and your loved ones all the joy in the world.
Possibly the prettiest panettone Ive ever seen: a very spoiling gift from my mother and the centrepiece for our Christmas feast tomorrow
Hot ginger tea, a stash of sweet treats to snack on, carols playing on repeat, yards of velvet ribbon and a mountain of presents to wrap. Only two sleeps left to go

The loveliest, most relaxed Sunday lunch: we had spinach and cheese frittata (baked in the oven so wonderfully soft and gooey in the middle); a crisp salad; leeks roasted in the oven until almost caramelised; and @maria.kastanis dakos (made with barley rusks, tomatoes, cheese and oodles of olive oil). Pudding was creamy pannacotta with sharp, sugary pink rhubarb and a slice or two of leftover panettone cake (from yesterdays celebrations

If youre looking for last minute Christmas present ideas, my column for @sundaytimesfood today is all about edible gifts! Recipes for Sicilian almond and glac cherry cookies; rose and cinnamon biscuits; white chocolate, pistachio and cranberry salami (looks like a salami, tastes like chocolate fridge cake - so good!); and hazelnut and chocolate biscotti - all online now or in todays paper.
My brilliant friend @milliproust has decked our home in ivy, holly, fir and swathes of festive greenery. It looks utterly magical, kind of like stepping into a Narnia. And smells of Christmas.

Aeneas standing by the window waiting for everyone to arrive, just bursting with excitement. Today we celebrated Christmas with friends who are like family. We had roast duck with potatoes, chestnut and bacon stuffing, creamy leeks and winter salad. Panettone cake layered with brandy cream and enrobed in soft Italian meringue for pudding. There were crackers, presents, hugs... I loved every moment of it and feel so lucky to have such wonderful friends in my life.
Twenty Christmas cakes baked, decorated and wrapped. A few more still to go

Today was a mad rush of Christmas shopping: cheese from @paxtonscheese, the most delicious scented candles from @alexeaglestudio and pretty nic nacs (the kind I always long for but never actually buy for myself) from @libertylondon. Every year I swear that Ill be more organised; and every year I do pretty much everything the week before Christmas

Cooking at the weekends, when there is no rush and I can happily potter in the kitchen all morning, is just about my favourite thing to do. We had friends for lunch yesterday: I cooked ossobuco, roast potatoes, roasted radicchio and buttery spinach. Then lightly boiled these baby artichokes in salted water for a few minutes with a big bunch of parsley, and served them drenched in olive oil. By the time we finished lunch and got up from the table, it was dark outside. Cant think of a lovelier way to spend the day. @anthonysantospirito @lukeedwardhall @jduncancampbell @martinbrudnizki @jonathan_brook
Cake, pastries and a big bowl of persimmons for breakfast this morning. A deliciously lazy start to the day with @jduncancampbell @lukeedwardhall and @anthonysantospirito

When we landed back in Venice yesterday it was howling a blustery gale and pouring rain. Then when I woke up this morning, it looked like this: utterly serene and like nothing bad could ever happen in the world. I love these cold clear winter days

I'm a firm believer that food is more than just fuel: it's memories, nostalgia, an excuse to indulge in the company of friends. It's comfort, celebration, tradition and so much more in between - at Christmastime most especially so. I worked with @zarahome to make a short film on how to host for the holidays: what to cook, how to decorate the table, how to mix a good Christmas cocktail... I absolutely loved working on this project and am excited to share a sneak peek of the video we created together with you here! You can watch it in full on the @zarahome website (or just follow the link in my stories). And if youre looking for inspiration as to what to cook, Ive also created some festive recipes for your Christmas table: crostini with ricotta, honey and persimmon; a scrumptious Christmas salad; honey roast chicken with rosemary and plums; and (my particular favourite!) a mascarpone, dark chocolate and pistachio cake

Such a fun dinner with friends last night: it felt like the first of the holiday celebrations. We had honey roasted poussin, roasted leeks, plums and potatoes; chestnut stuffing; a huge bitter leaf salad; and I made soda bread, which we ate warm and slathered in butter. For pudding: this Prosecco jelly hidden under a blanket of shimmering red pomegranate seeds. The recipe is from @nigellalawsons wonderful book, Christmas, which is one I love and turn to year round, but is most especially useful at this time of year (for obvious reasons

Feeling festive... thank you @milliproust for the most beautiful and elegant wreath, which I still cant believe you made and which is hanging very proudly on our front door. You truly are the most talented and generous friend

Every year I make Christmas cakes to give as presents to friends: its one of my most treasured Christmas traditions. I started today by soaking the fruits in brandy and will leave them to steep for a few days: 6 kg of raisins, currants and sultanas; 2kg of glac cherries and mixed peel; and more brandy than could ever seem sensible

Skye in Skye. On a majestically blustery day. Ive always wanted to visit this corner of Scotland, if only because its my namesake. And its more breathtakingly beautiful than I ever imagined; but above all magical to be here celebrating the wedding of two of my most favourite people in the world. @hugomacd

The table laid for supper last night. Such a fun evening with wonderful friends. We had roasted duck legs with potatoes and plums; leeks baked in cream and mustard; a big salad and a freshly baked loaf of soda bread slathered in butter. Pannacotta for pudding

Pannacotta is fast becoming my go-to pudding for supper parties: so quick and easy to make, but also wonderfully indulgent to eat. I made this yesterday evening, left it to chill in the fridge overnight and well be eating it for dinner today.

LOVE the Christmas issue of @sundaytimesfood which is out today and bursting with culinary inspiration. Im thrilled to be sharing some of my recipes for a very spoiling festive breakfast in there: pistachio butter pastries (cant tell you how good these are!); panettone French toast; uova in purgatorio (eggs in a buttery tomato sauce); and a heavenly cheese and ham croissant bake. All the beautiful photographs by @aarongraubart

Apples filled with amaretto and raisin crumble ready to bake in the oven. So good with ice cream (salted honey and chocolate chip is my current favourite). The rest of lunch was super simple: a tart, cheeses, cold cuts with Piccalilli and a big bitter leaf salad. Relaxed and deliciously low-maintenance to throw together. Very lovely company too! PS for anyone who fancies making the apples... you can find my recipe for them online in the @sundaytimesfood archives

I love London in the build-up before Christmas, the streets and shops all decked out in their festive finery. And most especially so on days like today when the air is crisp, and the skies bright and blue. Plus: soft boiled eggs with buttered toast for breakfast at the @chilternfirehouse and a peek in at the fabulous @cabanamagazine pop-up shop on Holbein Place

Delighted to be sharing some festive recipes from A Table in Venice in this months issue of @townandcountryuk. Thank you @lucy.halfhead for the beautiful feature. And also a joy to see @james_richs scrumptious apple recipes in the magazine too!
Everywhere else in the house is total chaos, but this little corner by the sink at least looks cheery...
Its beginning to feel a lot like Christmas... and Im delighted to be sharing my party essentials on @wardrobeicons alongside @fionaleahydesign @cookinboots @matildagoad and @rowan_blossom

The least fun part about cooking is the washing up that comes after... With that in mind, all the recipes for my @sundaytimesfood column today are ones that you cook and serve in a single pot. Four cheese risotto; a very simple recipe for melanzane alla parmigiana baked in layers of mozzarella and buttery tomato sauce; and baked apples filled with amaretto and sweet raisin crumble

Im the kind of person who goes straight to the desert list when presented with a menu in a restaurant. By the same principle, pudding is always my favourite part of any meal - and more often than not, I will plan the whole meal around it. Last night we had chocolate and mascarpone tart, topped with sharp redcurrants and jammy, sugar-sweet roasted plums
Supper in the making: shepherds pie; an earthy beetroot, walnut and gorgonzola tart; buttery spinach; and baby leeks roasting in the oven. The kitchen smells like heaven.

Doing what I love most tonight: cooking for friends. Its been a chaotic day so supper is mostly dishes that I could make ahead: duck confit pie (an old favourite), slow roasted leeks, buttery spinach and a regally-hued chicory salad with mustard dressing. For pudding (the best bit, as far as Im concerned): panna cotta with black cherries in syrup. Looking forward to a relaxed and cosy evening in the very loveliest of company

Acqua alta, the tides flooding in and out of the city, are a part of life in Venice. As a child, I loved splashing through the water in wellington boots, and better still when school was cancelled due to high water... But this week the floods have been quasi apocalyptic, wreaking devastation on homes, businesses and Venices ancient architecture. This is a picture taken from the terrace at my mothers house, the home where I grew up: its one of the highest points in the city and in the thirty years weve lived there has flooded only a handful of times. Its a marker of how bad this acqua alta is that the kitchen, dining room and Aeneas bedroom have all been knee deep underwater this week, with more violent floods predicted for the weekend... Heartbreaking to watch: if like me you love Venice and have enjoyed the citys inimitable charms, then please support the work of @weareherevenice, a charity that works tirelessly, with unparalleled passion, to protect Venice so that she can continue to bring joy for generations more to come.

Aeneas and I made this nutty cake together at the weekend: its a soft chocolate sponge of sorts, layered with sweet hazelnut butter then smothered in thick buttercream and toasted nuts. Were both completely obsessed. Am currently banishing Monday blues with two very chocolate-y slices and a cup of tea.

A few years ago, I traded in a life in academia for one doing what I love most: cooking, creating recipes and writing about it. I feel unbelievably privileged to be able to call what I do work and I was delighted when @veuveclicquot_ww asked me to collaborate with them, and share my story as part of their exciting new makers program. We spent a day together shopping for porcini mushrooms at the Rialto market, leafing through old cookbooks (pretty much my favourite pastime), cooking, chatting...and eating. I loved showing them my world and am so excited to share this short film we created together with you
Its a very good start to the weekend when you have pastries (still warm from the oven and outrageously buttery) for breakfast. A nice antidote to the grey and drizzly weather outside

Autumnal baking, playing around with recipes old and new: pistachio butter cake (a favourite recipe from the @sundaytimesfood archives) but with thick buttercream instead of the lemon drizzle icing I usually make it with; and a jammy persimmon crostata. Still playing with the recipe for that one... but basically you blend the sweet, jelly-like flesh of three persimmons with one cooked apple and a few tablespoons of sugar, a dash of ground cinnamon (to taste) and a squeeze of lemon (to stop the fruit browning too much). I use ready rolled shortcrust pastry to make the tart and bake it all in the oven for 30 mins or so until the pastry turns golden and the filling feels firm to touch

The table laid for supper on a chilly evening. Heaps of candles because everything looks warmer, cosier and all round better by candlelight. We had ossobuco with lemon zest, fennel and sage; baby artichoke and pecorino salad; roast potatoes with burnt bits (the best bit, as far as Im concerned); saffron poached fennel and pumpkin flan topped with heaps of grated salted ricotta

After last weeks glorious weather today felt like the first day of autumn: it rained and I spent the day pottering in the kitchen. Trying new recipes for sweet persimmon tart and pumpkin & mascarpone flan since its the season for both... and also made my favourite pistachio butter cake with whipped marzipan icing

My beautiful baby boy turns seven today. Goodness, time flies. We had chocolate cake to celebrate: the same fudgy cake that my mother used to make for me, smothered with chocolate icing and jelly beans. To go with it: ham and cheese sandwiches, nutty gelato, biscuits and baby tomatoes (Aeneas request @anthonysantospirito @romilly_mca

The skies were so blue and clear today that it almost felt like summer. Ive been soaking up every last moment of this beautiful weather before winter sets in proper. And I just checked the forecast for the weekend: its looking good (fingers crossed)... I hope yours is off to a great start too

Spent today pottering in the kitchen - which is pretty much my favourite way to spend the day. Playing around with a few new recipes... but its an old favourite for supper tonight: cheesy melanzane alla parmigiana, followed by a couple of sugary sweet, ambrosial persimmons for pudding

My last day at the @arnianopaintingschool couldnt have been more heavenly: spent the morning painting in the sunshine under @willropercurzons expert guidance. Then lunch under the shady lime tree, beautifully prepared by brilliant @amberguinness. All of my favourite things: creamy burrata with baby tomatoes; radicchio salad with almonds and buttery beans; and a gargantuan bowl of fusilli with pesto and peppery rocket. Chocolates (lots of them) and coffee for pudding. More painting and nap in the afternoon.

Three deliciously simple recipes in my @sundaytimesfood column today. All made with ready rolled puff pastry: beetroot, gorgonzola and walnut tart; butternut squash soup with a pastry hat; and a higgledy piggledy blackberry and mascarpone millefeuille

Exploring the Tuscan countryside with @arnianopaintingschool. Rolling hills and majestic views at every turn. We ended up at the cosiest trattoria for lunch: plates upon plates of salami, cheese, crostoni doused in olive oil and garlic, juicy tomato bruschetta and the most blissfully nourishing bowl of ribollita soup
Waking up in the heaven that is @arnianopaintingschool. Ive longed to come for ages and am so excited to finally be here. @amberguinness @delilahkhomo @tatlermagazine

Dinner in our kitchen last night: we had beetroot, gorgonzola and walnut tart; wild rice and pistachio salad; slow roasted leeks (cooked to the point where they turn sweet and caramelised); buttery saffron fennel; and my favourite red chicory salad in a peppery mustard dressing. Heavenly company and such a fun evening. A special thank you to @carolynasome for bringing together such a fabulous gang of ladies, friends new and old, all of whom it was a pleasure and a true privilege to cook for

The skies were grey and menacing when I woke up this morning... and its rained cats and dogs pretty much all day. Somehow I didnt get much further than the front door and have ended up spending most of the day pottering in the kitchen in my pyjamas. All in all, a very nice Sunday

The most magical bunch of flowers from @mccormickcharlies garden. Like something out of a fairy tale. So gargantuan in size that we couldnt find a vase big enough to store them and have ended up repurposing our umbrella stand. Thank you, Charlie xx
Ten years today. Love you always @anthonysantospirito

Landed in Venice for a fleeting few days. A heavenly lunch of scampi and baby artichokes with @romilly_mca; errands and meetings this afternoon; and supper with friends tonight. So lovely to be back: just wish my boys were with me
That magical morning light flooding through our bathroom window. What a lovely start to the week! @benpentreath

My favourite kind of Saturday lunch: long and lazy and with the very loveliest of company. Roast chicken with @anthonysantospiritos scrumptious roast Ratte potatoes, fennel gratin, and a red chicory salad drenched in mustard dressing. For pudding: tiramis (and lots of it) layered with fudgy, sugary sweet chestnut pure.

Accidentally vegan recipes in todays @sundaytimesfood: poached peaches in lemon syrup; pasta with basil and almond pesto; sweet peppers with breadcrumbs; and wild rice salad with pomegranate and pistachios.

Supper at home with friends. We were out all day (watching the annual Venice Regata) so dinner was super simple, a mix of cold bits and the kind of food you can make in advance: creamy vitello tonnato, sauted green beans with baby tomatoes (served at room temperature), black rice and pistachio salad and blistered aubergines drenched in olive oil. For pudding: two big bowls of tiramis

The last, sun kissed and deliciously happy days of the summer holidays. Today we drove our little boat out to the sleepy island of Mazzorbo. Lunch was under a shady pergola: fried seafood followed by sweet biscuits, fig tart and iced coffee. Thank you @bridierhall for this sweet photo of me with Aeneas who gets bigger and more grown up by the day: we cant stop time from flying by, but so happy to have these memories to look back on
Exactly two months old. Time flies
Weekend mood and exciting things happening in the kitchen
A happy afternoon spent running errands
One of my favourite recipes from A Table In Venice, most especially in the warm summer months: poached langoustines with sunny saffron mayonnaise
When you treat yourself to syrupy poached peaches and thick Greek yogurt for breakfast

Simple, summery salads (and a savoury tart) to enjoy along with your bbq in my column for the @sundaytimesfood today. Fennel and lemon salad; baby mozzarella with fresh, sweet mint; slow cooked red peppers with black olives; and THE simplest ever tomato and courgette tart
Breakfast of dreams. Most especially the custard filled doughnut on top of the pile
This mornings view from our front door. On our way to get pastries from the bakery for breakfast.
Flowers from the garden sitting on our hall table, amongst the sea of keys, sun glasses and general life clutter. Make me smile every time I walk through the door.
Matching in summery blue stripes. Achille fast asleep on my chest, hiding from the hot sun under his (too) big sun hat

Simple, but blissfully indulgent Summer recipes (all of which you can make ahead) in my @sundaytimesfood column today: cold roasted salmon with saffron mayonnaise; zucchine carpaccio with a dash of salty pecorino cheese; and a heavenly champagne, amaretto and strawberry custard
Early morning stroll before the heat of the day sets in. @romilly_mca
Shades of glorious pink and the prettiest peonies Ive ever seen. @paulafitzherbert
One of my all time favourite recipes: orecchiette pasta with a devilishly creamy broccoli and cauliflower sauce. I cant tell you how comforting this is to eat. Recipe in the @sundaytimesfood archives
House move and baby in the same week: its been a busy and overwhelmingly exciting few days. Heaven to spend this weekend at home just pottering, unpacking boxes and not doing very much at all
One week and two days old today. A bundle of bonny joy and the newest and member of our family: Achille Lorenzo Santospirito
Happy Fathers Day to the best Papi we could wish for @anthonysantospirito.

Preparations (in the form of chocolate, mascarpone & strawberry tart and brown sugar meringues) for last nights supper with @deborahbrett @petrostofberg @laura.fantacci @matildagoad @edit.58 @romeoandjulesbespoke @natasha.montrose and @carolynasome. The very best start to the week

A pop of bright, summery green in the @sundaytimesfood today! Im sharing recipes for asparagus and egg tart, pappardelle with courgette and burrata, and basil sorbet in todays column. Grab a copy if they tickle your fancy. Happy Sunday!
Usually Im an early riser, but this morning I stayed in bed napping and reading and it was pretty close to heaven

The morning after the night before. Our dining table happily awash with Turkish delight scented roses from @mccormickcharlies garden, pink peonies (a present from @mariashollenbarger), half drunk bottles of wine and leftover sweets. I love the aftermath of a good supper party - its a chance to relive the fun of the night before
Lemon meringue pie tonight. Buttery lemon chicken roasting in the oven, to eat with roasted baby potatoes and blanched asparagus swimming in olive oil
Meringue cake with whipped cream and summer berries for supper tonight. Also, cold roast beef; new potatoes with lemon and samphire; and green beans with baby tomatoes
Dispatch from Venice. Aeneas and @anthonysantospirito are on a boys trip to Venice without me, but they sent me this photo of a peony which they picked from the garden
Desk day (or afternoon) made all the cheerier by a pot of hot tea and too-pretty-to-eat (almost) biscuits from the @the_berkeley

Thank you darling @paulafitzherbert and @maria.kastani for hosting the most magical baby shower for me. Our kitchen is now filled with the sweet scent of pink flowers, cakes, biscuits and the happiest of memories

When life gives you lemons... Make lemon and ricotta galette; pasta with lemon and buttery melted burrata sauce; and a creamy lemon and honey panna cotta. Recipes in the @sundaytimesfood today should they take your fancy... Happy Sunday
Some very exciting and happy news to share: just over a month to go (photo by the loveliest @stephie_howard)

I wrote about my life in Venice and why I love it so much in todays edition of COOK in @corriere. Am also sharing some classic and much loved Venetian recipes... grab a copy for roasted sea bass with lemon and capers, scampi in agrodolce, baby artichoke and pecorino salad, risotto with bruscandoli (wild hops), lemon and saffron meringue pie and a deliciously sharp lemon sgroppino. @angelafrenda @cucina_corriere

Heavenly lunch with friends, new and old. Limoncello semifreddo, wild strawberry Eton Mess, amaretto poached peaches and sugar topped biscuits for pudding. And the loveliest company. @romilly_mca @gianlucalongogg @hamishbowles @sidneyfinch @sophieconran @shazzagoldsmith @londonrossgirl @anthonysantospirito
Higgledy piggledy flowers from the garden. Few things make me smile more.
My favourite breakfast: brioche filled with sticky apricot jam and still warm from the bakery. @ayamomochan @stephie_howard
Pretty views on an early evening stroll. I love how long and light the days are now.
Lazy potter-in-the-kitchen and curl-up-in-bed-with-a-book mood today

Colomba cake (kind of like panettone, but the Easter version topped with sugared almonds and laced with candied citrus peel), Easter bread and a pot of tea for breakfast before hitting the garden for an epic chocolate egg hunt. Happy Easter! Hope you have a wonderful and spoiling day xx
We went for a stroll in the sunshine this morning and stumbled upon this pretty hidden corner. I love how the streets of Venice are endlessly filled with surprises.
Good Friday breakfast: strawberries in lemony syrup, pears with creamy ricotta cheese and sweet pastries from the bakery
Playing with many happy variations on the theme of asparagus in the kitchen today

Inspiration for Easter Lunch in my column for the @sundaytimesfood today: creamy baked cannelloni with ricotta and mint, roast rack of lamb with baby tomatoes and artichokes... and a glorious torta paradiso (my favourite!) - lighter than air sponge layered with honey and lemon scented whipped cream

Improvised, but heavenly lunch of cold bits with @rumatkinson and @susie_sioux: poached langoustines with thick mayonnaise, white and green asparagus with egg sauce, tomatoes, and baby artichoke salad with salty pecorino
Chaos in the kitchen: recipe testing a champagne custard, asparagus and egg tart and a lemon meringue pie with just a hint of saffron. Leftovers for supper

Thank you @claridgeshotel and @paulafitzherbert for the wonderful feature in your magazine. Heaven reading the issue today with my afternoon tea - and honoured to find myself in such fabulous company as @clerkenwellboyec1 @iamlaurajackson @adammhyman @clodagh_mckenna @ewanventers @markwogan13 and Tom Parker Bowles.
Today is a desk day
Fried eggs and crispy prosciutto (fried like bacon by @anthonysantospirito - so good!); toast with pistachio butter; freshly baked pastries; and custard filled doughnuts for breakfast

Today has been taken up with a trip to the market and a lazy lunch at home: poached langoustines with saffron mayonnaise (a favourite recipe from my cookbook), new potato and lemon salad, baby artichokes with pecorino. And to finish it off: meringues, strawberries and a wobbly vanilla panna cotta with syrupy black cherries. Dream Saturday. @mccormickcharlie @benpentreath
All set for a very special cookery workshop Im excited to be hosting for @bastianello_morigi9 in support of @avapo_venezia and all the wonderful work that they do. @barrivabene
Working to a tight deadline today - so have spent a disproportionate amount of time staring vacantly at this quiet corner of the living room, when I really should have been furiously writing.
Happy to be home for a few days and loving this beautiful Spring weather
Making new friends over breakfast at @hotelderussie
Celebrating my birthday with lots and lots of cake.
Preparations are underway: buckets of flowers, chaos everywhere and a pistachio cake baking in the oven
A quiet, but sunny corner at my desk and some orchid inspiration from @bruceoldfield.
Recipe testing some lovely Easter recipes for the @sundaytimesfood today: roast lamb and baby artichokes, amongst other Spring delights, for supper tonight

Weekend lunching. In pyjamas with friends who feel like family. Roast beef with heaps of mustard; broad beans, sweet peas and baby artichokes with pecorino; and a big, juicy tomato salad. Torta paradiso and homemade ice cream (coffee, rum and raisin, and creamy pine nut) for pudding

When a dear friend turns thirty and you make her a birthday cake. Pistachio butter sponge (one of my favourite recipes - online on the @sundaytimesfood website) with Italian meringue buttercream and heaps of sweet scented mimosa. Happy birthday, darling @delilahkhomo
A happy day spent pottering in the kitchen, testing a new recipe for pistachio, mascarpone and salted caramel cheesecake

A quiet, dreamy corner at @hotelendsleigh. We were there for the weekend to host a Table In Venice dinner; back in London now for a couple of days but could happily have stayed on for more walks through their idyllic gardens, afternoon tea with cream and scones, and lazy naps by the open fire

Recipes for Sunday Lunch - with a capital S and a capital L - in my column for todays @sundaytimesfood. Baby tomatoes gratin; roast pork loin in pistachio crust; lemon roasted potatoes; and a candied orange treacle tart (SO good!). Find the recipes in todays paper or online
One of the perks of recipe testing is eating the leftovers: green panzanella made with baby artichokes and sweet peas, followed by lemon meringue pie

Blissfully lazy Sunday lunch with @jo_rodgers, @subtlegoose and their adorable baby boy: cte de boeuf (cooked to pink perfection by @anthonysantospirito), tomato salad, and leeks baked in cream, mustard and heaps of melted Parmesan. For pudding I made a lemon meringue pie: the yellow custard filling (made with a tin of condensed milk and a generous splash of lemon juice) was rather too runny - but I had second helpings anyway

My column in the @sundaytimesfood today is all about the pleasures of cooking with red wine: creamy Gorgonzola and red wine risotto; tortellini in nourishing chicken broth with a good splash of red; wine and star anise cookies; and - my particular favourite - a recipe for spiced red wine jelly with mascarpone cream and pears. You can find all the recipes in the magazine today and online. Happy Sunday

Early morning baking in the form of a spinach and ricotta pie with anchovies and eggs. We had it for lunch with a sweet tomato salad and a big dish of salty bresaola. Strawberries in balsamic syrup and sugared ricotta cream for pudding

It might be cold and foggy outside, but feels like Springtime in our kitchen. Cooking lunch for friends who feel like family today: roast pork in pistachio crust, potatoes, blood orange & black olive salad, and baby artichokes drenched in olive oil. Frittelle filled with zabaione and whipped cream for pudding

Thank you @thegracetales and @clairebrayford for the lovely feature on A Table In Venice. Such fun to chat all things motherhood, Venice and buttery breakfast pastries with you... ( @theyoungonesportraits

As Carnival gets underway, its the season for sweet treats: galani (tissue paper thin sheets of pastry, deep fried and drenched in icing sugar) and frittelle (pillowy doughnuts filled with grappa soaked raisins and pine nuts, then rolled in sugar). So unbelievably good. Theres a recipe for both in my cookbook A Table In Venice, but these are from our local pastry shop

Blissfully clear blue skies in Venice today. And in other news: Ill be hosting a special A Table In Venice themed dinner at my favourite English country hotel @hotelendsleigh on Saturday 9th March...there will be dishes from the book and well be talking all things bella Venezia. There are still a few spots left and you can book tickets through the events page of the @hotelendsleigh website. So looking forward to it and really hope to see you there
Late afternoon tea in our new kitchen. @hamishbowles

Improvised picnic lunch in our new kitchen with @cgconsultancy. My favourite kind of food - the kind where you buy pick-y bits and just throw them together on a plate: salty bresaola, juicy tomatoes, grilled aubergine and courgette topped with feta and fresh mint. Heaps of bread and grassy olive oil to go with it

So excited to be spending my first night in our new home here in Venice. Theres of unpacking and plenty of work still to do before it will feel properly like home...but I cant wait to get started. And in the meantime am padding around in my pyjamas writing to do lists and cobbling together mood boards like theres no tomorrow

Sharing some veggie recipes in the @sundaytimesfood today: gnocchi with taleggio and radicchio (so good!); buttery leek tarte tatin laced with mustard and thyme; and a scrumptious carrot, ginger and almond cake with mascarpone and cinnamon icing. Grab a copy of the paper or find the recipe online

Im delighted to be hosting a table styling workshop at Petersham Nurseries Covent Garden next month. There will be mocktails and canaps... and we will be talking all things fruit, flowers, vintage crockery and table linens (basically my favourite things), as we walk through how to lay a table that feels wonderfully opulent but also relaxed and inviting. Its going to be a very special evening and I would love to see you there! March 12th, 7-9pm. Tickets available on the workshop page of the @petershamnurseries website - otherwise just follow the link in my profile. Have a wonderful weekend!
A curl up in an armchair with a good book and a cup of tea kind of day
Second breakfast of the day: rose scented macaroon with raspberries and lychees. And a fruit salad for good measure

Sunday night blues after the most magical weekend with @mccormickcharlie and @benpentreath in their stunning home in Dorset. We were spoiled rotten: the very best company, so much glorious food (@mccormickcharlies orange marmalade and Victoria sponge: still dreaming of it!) and walks with @mavisandsibyl through the beautiful countryside
Chocolate chestnut meringue pie on a Thursday evening. Feels like the start of the weekend
My view today. Have been curled up on the sofa all day with a pile of books, my laptop and a pot of hot tea, working on an exciting new project
Sheer delight when recipe testing coincides with dinner: radicchio, pancetta and goats cheese pie and a leftover slice of carrot and ginger cake

Sharing some warming, comforting recipes in the @sundaytimesfood today, including these heavenly saffron poached pears... my favourite cabbage soup topped with crunchy bread and oozy melted cheese... and roast loin of pork with fragrant bay leaves and juniper berries. Grab a copy today or find the recipes online
All packed up for Christmas.

The happy aftermath of a very indulgent supper - in which we polished off many roast potatoes, copious bottles of Prosecco and almost an entire zucotto (panettone filled with whipped ricotta cream, candied peel, glac cherries and drenched in chocolate). Bliss

Delighted to be sharing my tips for simple entertaining at home in the latest issue of @wardrobeicons: how to throw a supper party with ease, inspiration for planning the menu, and ideas for how to dress up a plain old panettone (my go-to at this time of the year).

Spent this afternoon happily pottering in the kitchen. For supper tonight: orange blossom treacle tart with clotted cream. Still roasting in the oven: chicken, potatoes and leeks laced with mustard and cream
Delighted to be sharing my recipe for puff pastry pizzette online with @townandcountryuk... along with inspiration for festive cocktails and parties

Edinburgh friends, Im going to be in town tomorrow! Please join me at the @anthropologieeu store on George St from 6pm until 8pm. Ill be in conversation with Mary Contini, signing copies of A Table In Venice and there will be Prosecco aplenty... Would love to see you there! The event is free but to reserve your spot please email community@anthropologie.eu. by the wonderfully talented @sarahmaingotphotography
Christmas baking. Carols playing on full blast

So thrilled to have contributed to the beautiful @sundaytimesfood Christmas issue. Sharing some of my most favourite Italian Christmas recipes, including this snowy panettone cake with whipped brandy cream, soft meringue and sugared redcurrants. Its out today - grab a copy or find the recipes online

My dream Christmas wish list in the December issue of @houseandgardenuk: Ruffoni copper pans, rococo candlesticks, @chiarastellacattana linens and a beautiful pink painting by @carolinepopham... Also eyeing up @williamsmalleyribas chair and @bridierhalls bar trolley

Daisy biscuits from my cookbook - made into tiny snowflakes (because its Christmas) and filled with raspberry jam for a festive A Table In Venice themed afternoon tea and panettone decorating workshop with @anthropologieeu this afternoon. On the menu: fried cheese and ham sandwiches, frittata, candied peel and raisin pastry twists, and chocolate filled meringues

Recipes for comfort food in the @sundaytimesfood today: orecchiette with cheesy cauliflower and broccoli (kind of like an Italianised cauliflower cheese); puff pastry pies filled with melted mozzarella and tomato; and Nutella tiramis

Lunch yesterday for twenty utterly fabulous friends. We ate confit duck and potato pie, honeyed carrots, wild rice salad, followed by meringue with whipped cream, marrons glac and chocolate. Then tore into our Christmas crackers. The dreamiest start to the weekend. Thank you to everyone who came and made it so special.
Chocolate and sugared chestnut meringue cake in the making for a festive lunch with twenty brilliantly inspiring women. Feels like the start of Christmas.
Wishing all my American friends a very happy Thanksgiving xx

A very exciting delivery arrived this morning: beautiful French and Dutch editions of A Table In Venice. Available now to buy on Amazon, should it tickle your fancy...or maybe as a Christmas present @editionsulmer @lsamsterdam @bloomsburycooks
Pistachio butter cake with lemon marzipan icing for dinner tonight. Chicken and baby potatoes still roasting in the oven
Friday afternoon: a pot of jasmine tea, finishing off a few bits and bobs, and waiting for the weekend to start

Cooking for supper with friends tonight. Got carried away and ended up making up two cakes for pudding... Panettone cake with mascarpone and almond buttercream (from A Table In Venice) and a soft Italian meringue confection with sugared redcurrants. Then blood oranges poached in Marsala syrup with whipped brandy cream to go with the cakes
Monday afternoon baking: certosino (a spiced fruit, honey nut cake - the recipe is an old favourite in the archives of my blog) covered in glac fruits and blanched almonds
Spending today at home: organising, tidying, cooking and catching up on (my long overdue) emails.
A pretty perfect London Sunday: an unbelievably good dim sum lunch on Queensway, followed by a lazy stroll through Kensington Park Gardens. And the sun was shining

Happy Halloween! Its butter roasted pumpkin with sage and flaked almonds for us tonight. And I wanted to say thank you - a very big thank you! - for your sweet messages about the floods: were all well, the water has subsided, our kitchen amazingly survived and were back to business as usual! Xx

Terrible acqua alta in Venice today: some of the highest water in decades. The water almost never comes into our house because its in a very high point of the city, but its at least seven inches deep in our kitchen, dining room and Aeneas bedroom. We spent the afternoon lifting up furniture; now hiding upstairs with hot ginger tea
Happy birthday to this little pumpkin. Six years old today and as cheeky as ever. Celebrating with chocolate cake and jammy biscuits
A beautiful, bright sunny day in Venice today. Felt like the last day of summer. Rain is forecast for the rest of the week - which somehow made me appreciate the sunshine all the more.
Autumn comfort food: roast chicken with thyme, red onion and roast grapes. And fennel baked with Gorgonzola cheese and walnut until bubbly and golden and all round heavenly

Earlier this year, I went to Sicily on holiday and fell in love with the food. I came home with a bag full of cookbooks and a long list of recipes to try. Some of my favourites - linguine with rosemary and caper pesto, tuna alla Siciliana in a rich tomato sauce, and pistachio and rum cookies - are are in the @sundaytimesfood today.

What a treat to have been a guest at @priors nomadic clubhouse at @heckfield_place: what a magical and memorable weekend... beautiful setting, the very best company and the most exquisite food cooked by @skyegyngell and @james_edward_henry_. Came home with a basket full of chestnuts that we collected in the woods and which Ill be roasting tonight. Thank you darling @davidprior - bravo
When recipe testing turns into dinner: a panettone, whipped cream and soft meringue confection for supper with @scribbleanddaub @lucyirby @edit.58 and @carolynasome

The dreamiest afternoon tea at The Lanesborough with @bruceoldfield. Iced lemon sponge cake, finger sandwiches, a sea of pink roses and Bruces fairytale gowns on show. Bruce is like a godfather to me: Ive known him since forever, feel very privileged to count him as family...and nearly ten years ago he made my wedding dress. I dont think I can (or will) ever love another dress as much as that one
In the mood for a little baking. What do you think...apple and amaretti cake? Baked apples with vanilla custard? Pie? Tart?
Sometimes flowers are so pretty they dont need any fancy arranging. Plonk then in a bucket (or throw them in a jar) and they still light up the room

Sunday morning treat: Italian brioche - kind of like croissants, but softer, breadier, topped with a smattering of sugar and filled with sweet apricot jam at the centre. I cant tell you how good these are (and how sweet they smell) still warm from the oven. One of my favourite recipes in my cookbook, A Table In Venice: one for when Im in the mood for a little spoiling
Magical view from the top of the Accademia Bridge

Chocolate chestnut meringue pie for supper with @holdsknifelikepen @paulafitzherbert and @thechicshopper. As you might have guessed, I have a sweet tooth (!) and a penchant to plan menus around the pudding... but for the rest of dinner: confit duck and potato pie, buttery honeyed carrots, fried artichoke hearts and a peppery red chicory salad

After two wild and wonderful weeks travelling in Asia it feels good to be home: back in my kitchen, cooking with all the glorious autumnal produce that seems to have sprung up while I was away, and making myself buttery, warming ossobuco (my idea of comfort food). Tomorrow (Tuesday) Ill be at the Guildford Book Festival, 10-11.30 for A Table In Venice themed coffee morning. London friends, if you like cake and books, please come along and say hi! Would love to see you there! Link to tickets in my profile

Plums, apples, grapes! Cooking with beautiful autumnal fruit in the @sundaytimesfood today. Sharing my recipes for a crisp apple, fennel and walnut salad; buttery fried pork chops with heaps of rosemary and roasted grapes; and plum and sweet amaretti galette for dessert
Nine years today happily married to the love of my life. @anthonysantospirito
Like a burst of welcome sunshine in our kitchen. These have to be the happiest flowers of all - dont you think

Pudding is my favourite part of any meal: this pistachio butter cake with mascarpone icing and these sweet pistachio and almond cookies being no exception to that rule. We had roast chicken, roast potatoes and a pink radish salad with mustard dressing to go with it

This Wednesday Im excited to be taking part in the Red Smart Women Week, talking about how to throw a fabulous dinner party (and enjoy it) with @pipmccormac @melissa.hemsley and @cookinboots. Click the link in my profile for details and tickets! Really hope to see you there... its going to be a super fun evening! @redmagazine
A luxuriously lazy start to our Sunday: Aeneas playing with his Lego, while I potter in the kitchen (also still in my pyjamas) baking pistachio butter cake for lunch

An explosion of fall colours and fruits. All stocked up for the weekend... Im in Abergavenny tomorrow morning teaching a Venetian cookery class at the @afoodfestival, and then looking forward to cooking some kind of roast for lunch on Sunday with friends. The best kind of weekend ahead

These flowers sitting on the shelf in our kitchen make me so happy: the most spoiling and thoughtful gift from @milliproust. She picked them from her own garden and they smell like a walk in the countryside. Prettier and more precious than anything you could buy in a florist - anywhere.

London friends, Ill be in the beautiful dining room at @spring_ldn this Monday afternoon, talking about all things Venice and food... would love for you to join me for a chat and afternoon tea! For full details follow the link in my profile. Hope to see you there

In the mood for comfort food tonight. Also feeling too lazy to cook, so: roast beef that you pretty much just put in the oven and let tend to itself; and new potatoes with thyme and garlic that you drench in olive oil then roast until golden (so good

One of the most utterly magical festivals in Venice is the Regata Storica, which happens every year at the beginning of September. All the grandest old boats are brought of retirement and rowed in procession up the Grand Canal. Here they are coming out of the Arsenale, just round the corner from our house, getting ready to set off

Please join me at the Red Smart Women Week! Ill be in conversation with fabulously stylish @pipmccormac, @melissa.hemsley and @cookinboots talking about pretty much my favourite thing to talk about: how to throw the perfect dinner party...what to cook, where to go for inspiration, and how to make it all feel fun and effortless. 19th September, 6.30pm at 10 Carlton House Terrace. Come say hi - would love to see you there! Tickets available through the link in my profile @redmagazine
Shopping for this weekend at the Rialto Market this morning. Heaps of apples, plums and grapes...it really feels like Autumn is on its way now

Rushing home from a meeting, head down and in a hurry. Then I looked up to this view and just had to just stop for a moment to enjoy it. Venice is always full of surprises. Ps the utterly over-the-top building to the right is the hospital - would you believe it
My insider guide on how to navigate Venice during the film festival is up on @voguemagazine now: where to go, what to do and the dreamiest spots for a peachy bellini... The link in my profile
Loving all the figs right now: my favourite fresh fig and mascarpone cream tart. Recipe from A Table in Venice

And then it poured... And poured and poured. Late summer storms that feel like the beginning of Autumn. Excellent excuse to pop into a caf for hot chocolate. @aleka_l @tommystadlen @anthonysantospirito

Last month we visited the Aeolian islands - and were beguiled by mulberry granita, the clear blue seas and the jammy figs that seemed to be growing everywhere. I wrote a travel diary for @voguemagazine which you can find (along with a recipe for pasta with creamy pistachio pesto) in the link in my profile, should it take your fancy. The most perfect place for a holiday: I cant recommend it enough

Waking up to this magical view at @hotelilpellicano. So excited for my book presentation and signing tonight! 7pm at the Pool Bar... there will be cocktails... Come along and say hi if youre nearby! @marielouisescio

Monday 10th September, 2-4pm: please join me for afternoon tea at @spring_ldn. Ill be talking about how Venice came to be my home, and what it is I love so much about the food and life there... And Ill be signing copies of my cookbook. Im so looking forward to it - its going to be a very special afternoon! Follow the link in my profile (or go to the @spring_ldn website) to book tickets (and have a look at the other fun events they have planned for September). Cant wait to see you there! @skyegyngell @spring_ldn ( by @gilchristanna4)

Im in London for work for two days - and my husband spoiled me with roses that smell like Turkish delight. Theyre from @london_flower_farmer and what I love most about them is that they dont look florist-y or arranged, but feel like theyve just been picked from a garden. So dreamy. Happy Monday and hope youre week is off to a lovely start! Xx

How to make the perfect picnic in the @sundaytimesfood today - pretty much my favourite way to spend the day at this time of year. With recipes for baby tomato, black olive and provolone tart; new potato, caper and lemon salad; and a dreamy pistachio butter loaf cake (am completely obsessed with this cake

Lunch on the terrace at the Cipriani. Juicy king prawns and salad followed by sweet chocolate biscuits and a strong espresso. Best of all: the dreamy views out over the lagoon, which somehow I never ever tire... Also these chocolate brown and white poles, which Im completely obsessed with (cc @benpentreath @mccormickcharlie
Playing with flowers
Saffron pannacotta in the garden, under the dappled shade of our fig tree. One of my favourite recipes from my cookbook - so quick and simple to make, and somehow so perfect on a hot summers day

Dinner on Pellestrina, a little fishing island to the south of Venices lagoon. Seafood antipasti (baby shrimps with polenta, scallops, clams cooked in white wine, and more...), followed by roasted sea bass with crisp potatoes, olives and slithers of zucchine... then a long ride home (!) in our little boat

Delighted to be sharing a summer-y menu from A Table In Venice in this months edition of @waitrose magazine. Grab a copy for my spinach, mint and ricotta pie; roasted sea bream with figs, rosemary and almonds; saffron panna cotta; and more

Its a long day travelling back home to Venice from Filicudi (boat-car-2 planes-then another boat). Stocking up on picnic supplies (baby pears, flat white peaches, pistachio filled pastries, tomato and mozzarella panini) to keep us entertained along the way
Our last day on Filicudi: Im in love with the colours, the sea and the scrumptious granita here. Never want to leave
Pasta with pistachio; tomato and buffalo mozzarella dripping in olive oil and capers; a massive chunk of salty pecorino cheese; and the jammiest figs for pudding
A morning spent in this dreamy corner, reading and lazing and thinking about lunch

Breakfast in Filicudi is mulberry and prickly pear granita, freshly baked brioche buns, croissants filled with vanilla custard and rich ricotta cake. With views onto the clear blue sea. I think Ive found paradise
The view from the Rialto bridge while rushing around town running errands. Its devilishly hot today and the air feels thick like a blanket

Next month Im super excited to be at @hotelilpellicano: August 23rd, 7pm by the Pool Bar, Ill be talking about life and food in Venice, and signing copies of my cookbook. If youre nearby, please come say hello and join us for a cocktail! Cant wait @marielouisescio
Many shades of pink
Sunday afternoon and on our way for gelato: chocolate (two scoops in a cone) for Aeneas; and hazelnut for me

One of my absolute favourites in the heat of summer: creamy burrata topped with slivers of preserved lemon and fresh thyme. I cant tell you how good this is. Find the recipe and more summery supper party inspiration in the archives of vogue.com. @vogueliving_us
A very spoiling lunch with @dbgilman in the dreamiest dining room in town

After last nights late night and firework extravaganza, a lazy lunch with some of my favourite people under the shady pergola at Locanda Cipriani on Torcello. Utter perfection in the form of salty prosciutto and sweet melon: bliss on a hot summers day and evidence (if evidence were ever needed) that when it comes to food, simple is very much best. Crpes Suzette filled with custard and drenched in Cointreau for pudding: also very good
Summer holidays and sunny days
Fig and mascarpone cake, lightly dusted in icing sugar: one of my favourite recipes from A Table In Venice, either for breakfast or afternoon tea
One of my go-to puddings at this time of year: crumbled meringues, layered with whipped cream and strawberries swimming in lemon sugar syrup. No recipe, just pile everything together in the bowl
Delicious blue skies and a happy day spent driving around on our boat. Lunch on the picnic benches at Le Vignole, sunbathing and a dip in the sea. @anthonysantospirito @cultofg
Buttery pistachio cake for breakfast
Baby tomato and cheese tart for supper. With a little wilted spinach and broad beans to go with it
Baking kiefer (almond paste croissants, of sorts) from A Table In Venice before everyone else in the house wakes up
Hazelnut and chocolate tart: early morning baking for supper with girlfriends tonight. @maria.kastani

One of my go-to supper party menus at this time of year is roast poussin. With barely blanched asparagus, served cold with copious quantities of good olive oil and salt; and new potato salad with lemon. Strawberries and clotted cream for pudding. Wonderfully quick and simple to throw together - but none the less yummy for it
This chicory, cherry and goats cheese tart is fast becoming a real favourite: Ive made it twice this week. Beautiful recipe from @leah.hyslops lovely new book, Made In London

Drawing to the end of a busy and exciting week, and really looking forward to a quiet night in tonight with a good book. A proper page turner that I can get completely lost in: do you have any recommendations? Am very grateful for any suggestions

Leftovers for lunch: roasted fennel, tomato and chickpea salad (a beautiful @dianahenryfood recipe that I made for the first time last night and will now be making again and again) with saffron cous cous

The recipe book is out now and Im honoured to have contributed a recipe: this pomegranate and rose water semifreddo. Bravissimi @lily_vanilli_cake @clerkenwellboyec1 and @serenaguen: what an inspiring book! Friends, if you can please buy a copy (its available on Amazon and in U.K. bookstores) to support the children affected by the crisis in Syria.

Summer supper: lemon roast chicken, new potato salad, chicory and cherry galette (a beautiful recipe from @leah.hyslops new book) and panzanella aplenty. Champagne and the very loveliest company to go with it all

Birthday cake for my Mamma: two tiers of coffee walnut sponge (an old recipe, which you can find hidden among the archives of my blog) layered with a thick vanilla buttercream (I used the recipe in the @violetcakeslondon cookbook - and have decided its my all time favourite). Peonies for decoration. Leftovers for breakfast the next morning

So excited to see this beautiful feature of A Table In Venice in @youmagsocial today! With recipes from the book for a laid back Summer dinner (or party! Why not?!): courgette puff pastry tart, artichoke farro salad, a lovely strawberry vodka sorbet and more... In the magazine today and online

Chilled almond soup: one of my go-to recipes at this time of year. Partly because its so quick and easy to make, and partly (mostly) because its such a treat to eat. Im sharing the recipe, along with a few other summer favourites in the @sundaytimesfood today

Table laid for dinner to celebrate my beautiful mothers birthday. Such a special night with wonderful friends and family. We ate chilled almond soup; roast poussin; broad bean, mint and lemon salad; juicy summer tomatoes and heaps of green asparagus. Birthday cake (lots of it) to round the party off. @romilly_mca

Sharing my tips for effortless summer entertaining in @voguemagazine. Along with recipes for an almost impossibly simple Summer menu: burrata with preserved lemons and thyme; panzanella; fennel and black olive salad; and strawberries in red wine syrup. The link is in my profile. Photo by @hannahmai.eats
Theres something deeply gratifying about leftovers. Last nights roasted rhubarb (with all its sugary pink juices) and the last of the meringues
Summer is in full bloom. And I cant get enough of it
Theres a lovely piece in @graziauk this week about our London home

A snap from the first of two dinners Im delighted to be hosting for @hermes to celebrate the launch of their new perfume, Eau de Citron Noir.
