In this season of gathering Im finding myself most often gathered with my three favorite little friends; my kids. As they have evolved into their own selves I just want to be with them, know them and hang out with them. Loving them is a joy, liking them is a gift. . Ivy got on board when I declared the elaborate theme for our cookie boxes this year. She has been in the kitchen alongside me and has eagerly been passing out our sweet mushroom cookies. . I must give a hearty thank you to @twiggstudios for inspiring the theme for our cookie baskets. Its been such a fun and satisfying project

It happens when we enter the joy and the sorrow of the people we love, and we join together at the table to feed one another and be fed, and while its not strictly about food, it doesnt happen without it. Food is the starting point, the common ground, the thing to hold and handle, the currency we offer to one another. - @sniequist from Bread & Wine

One of you lovely people asked about assembling a large and satisfying party platter and perhaps this is not what you had in mind but when I read party and platter I immediately thought of my version of Le Grand Aioli. Its a classic dish from Provence usually made of fresh or poached vegetables and fish all served with a heaping bowl garlic laced aioli. I prefer my vegetables roasted and my aioli is usually wearing some sort of seasonal flare. This is my favorite casual meal for feeding a crowd and it is a perfect dish to invite your guests to contribute. Whatever vegetable they happen to have in the fridge ask them to roast it up and bring it with. The work of a gathering does not all need to fall on the hosts hands. There is something so unfussy yet festive when many hands are reaching and grazing from the same abundant platter. The recipe is found in Lets Stay In but really its as simple as scouring the vegetable bits from your fridge and your friends, boiling some eggs and serving with a roast chicken or fish (or just vegetables is fine too) and some aioli (otherwise known as mayonnaise in its fancy holiday ensemble

GIVEAWAY It is a strange thing for my job to mostly exist on the internet but my heart is for gathering. Because of that I write books to inspire and give confidence so that more tables will be full. I created a cookie mix - something tangible from my hands to yours and I opened a space in Seattle to bring people to the table. Now Im in a season of shedding and simplifying so were saying goodbye to the mixes and the shop. This holiday season is the last chance to purchase our mix. We have a limited quantity available. I want to send a cookie mix to three people here. Gather in the kitchen around butter and sugar. Pour a glass of milk and break into that cookie while its still warm. Watch the chocolate reflect and puddle. A simple, glorious moment perfect for sharing. To enter simply leave a comment or emoji or tag a friend who youd like to share some cookies with. US residents only please. If youd like to purchase the cookie mix Ill post a link in my profile. Thank you for sharing this space with me. Its a gathering too, virtual as it may be. But were here.

Im absolutely loving all the questions and cheers coming from you all regarding our twelve days of gathering. With this series in mind Im noticing myself being more intentional about how Im thinking about gathering this holiday season and Im loving it. Im not fretting about freshly laundered linens or clean floors, its more about thinking about how we can be light and share love. Thinking about the people who walk into our home this season and how I can see the light in them. Whether its my kids coming home from school, a neighbor stopping by or inviting someone over for a drink. Speaking of drinks, lets start there. Its seems fitting to start with a toast. This simple drink called the Adonis is a more drinkable Manhattan. Where rye usually lives there is sherry. Stir with ice equal parts sherry and sweet vermouth. Add a couple of drops of orange bitters and squeeze a bit of orange peel over the top. No one says a gathering needs to be a full meal. How about a simple cocktail and light snack? Its a busy season but there is always time for a drink. Inviting over a crowd? Make a large batch of the Adonis and keep in the fridge

Our kitchen and our table, like many of yours Im sure, are the center of our home. So often its a far cry from the picturesque Norman Rockwell paintings but I dont expect perfection, I long for relationship. Food brings us to the table and my goal in life is to spend as much time there as possible. And thats my goal for all of you as well because, for me, nothing in life is more beautiful than time spent at the table. From Lets Stay In Here we are at the beginning of a twelve day adventure with the purpose to inspire us all to stay in and gather. I believe in the table so passionately that I want to do whatever I can to make gathering there as easy as possible. So over the course of the next couple of weeks ask questions, tell me about the challenges you face with gathering or inspire us all with your tips and tricks for bringing people to the table. I will also be announcing some very fun giveaways so stay tuned!

Welcome to the twelve days of gathering. Throughout the next 12 days I will be sharing recipes, ideas and inspiration for gathering around the table. Whether youre setting a table for one or a table for fourteen there is heart, soul and a purpose behind it. Ask questions, share your favorite ways to gather, lets chat. I believe in the power of the table and I want to bring this to the center of the conversation this season. Listen, dont get me wrong I too love the shopping and gifting but each holiday season I strive to keep the real purpose and joy of this season at the forefront. Its a season of hope, anticipation and seeing the faces of those around you. Really seeing them. Your family, your friends, neighbors, strangers. They all have a seat at the table. Lets gather

Earlier this week I asked if you thought I should make a classic pumpkin pie or add a twist. The results are in and although the vote was close were adding a twist. . Its always a good idea to test new ideas before there big day (although I rarely do) so I headed to @fredmeyerstores where I picked up all my ingredients and things I didnt even know I needed. . So may I present you with the pumpkin pie of 2019. Roasted pepitas in the crust (1/2 cup ground pepitas to 2 cups all purpose flour). Then I burnt a cinnamon stick, let it cool then ground in a spice grinder with 1 teaspoon ground ginger, 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg and 3 cloves. . Pepita seed brittle for garnish and plenty of lightly sweetened and spiced whipped cream. . Oh and for the record, grandma taught me to stick to the Libbey can recipe. She never steered me wrong. @krogerco

Its the season of gathering and Im here for it. The beauty, the mess, the intention, the gratitude. Food brings us to the table where the real magic happens. . This cake is a family favorite. Cranberry date cake from Lets Stay In. Still looking for your thanksgiving menu? That book as a whole menu with a grocery list and timeline. Use the menu, share the recipes. This is meal meant to be shared - the work of it and the deliciousness of it
Feels like a triumph. When humble assorted leftovers turn into a feast. Little victories.

The kids and I have declared this weekend our Do Good, Feel Good weekend. Were starting off by watching @mrrogersmovie Friday night, then heading to @rei on Saturday to join @wildsteelheadcoalition in the fight to increase the return of wild steelhead to our waters. Then Sunday were watching @abeautifuldaymovie. In between there will be books and Im sure some video games and if course good food. . What would you do for a Do Good, Feel Good weekend?

When my art education and my career path collide. If I only knew back then just how incredibly satisfying it is to draw on buttery pastry. Just glad I figured it out now. // This was the cap to our salmon pot pie. Ive linked to the recipe I adapted it from and other recipes Im into right now on my site.

Cheers to Monday. May we make our dreams a reality, love well and help make the dreams of others their reality. Were in it together. // Also, I cant quit the New York Sour. It was my fall drink last year and Im happily finding myself in a delicious rut. // 2 parts whiskey 1 part lemon 1 part simple syrup Shake with ice then carefully pour red wine over the back of the spoon right on top of your glass.

Wild food in our own backyard. Last weekend @radriguezinc and I took the kids downtown to the waterfront to go fishing. There was a crowd of people already lined up in the dark with fluorescent jigs already deep in the water. We joined the line up and after a bit of patience and of course some trial and error we pulled up our first squid. The next day we feasted in fried calamari with pepperoncini aioli (Mayo, diced pepperoncini, dill, sea salt). Squid are sustainable, delicious, and if you live in Seattle they are practically in your backyard.

Everything in my body relaxes and floods with joy when I remember this moment. The push and pull of the river. The wonder of what dances below and the subtle tug of the line when Ive managed to mimic a meal for the trout. Ive felt a shift. Subtle changes that slowly evolve over time until I look at something from the past that is also me, but a little different. The kitchen still calls and is a place I feel most me. And now so is the river. The woods. Under a big open sky. Leaning into the shift and figuring out how to adjust. My reality remains the same; three kids, two dogs, bills, laundry, ... but you can not ignore the call, the curiosity, the truth of your spirit.

Heres to the weekend. To a pace that slows, to a bit of indulgence, to small celebrations that ignite the soul. To days where we can ask ourselves what do I WANT to do today? Instead of what do I NEED to do today? I hope there is a bit of that for all of us this weekend. Breathe it in.

Puff pastry, pears and sugar. Everything you need to make one of my favorite fall desserts (or breakfast). // The recipe can be found in Lets Stay In but really all you need is puff pastry, pears and sugar.
In fall their brightened leaves, released, Fly down the wind, and we are pleased To walk on radiance, amazed. O light come down to earth, be praised! - Wendell Berry
This beauty of a cake is ready to greet us when we return home from trick-or-treating. // Its a super simple olive oil pumpkin cake (or loaf or bread) and the recipe is on the blog now! @caoliveranch

Theres something about this season and baking that just go hand in hand. // Baked Apple Cider Donuts. Recipe via @nytcooking
Five days unplugged from a screen but more plugged in then Ive felt in a long time.

Weekend ready. . FYI - cardamom buns on @food52 are so good you too might make them two days in a row with zero regrets.

When things dont seem to be working out as you like them to its so wonderful to be able to take a few simple ingredients and turn them into something that brings so much joy. The house smells good, I feel accomplished. Its not big but its something and thats often all I need.

Pasta al Limone with crispy finocchiona, chanterelle and parmesan. A masterpiece worthy of the @barillaus ? You be the judge. . The recipe is on the blog right now. Follow @BarillaUS to get a peek of the Pasta World Championship in action this week

No, no were not going to fry the potatoes ourselves were simply going to warm a bag of crispy, kettle cooked potato chips we already have and toss them with some ranch dressing mix (or some garlic, onion and buttermilk powder and dried dill) throw on some lemon zest, Parmesan and fresh dill and call it a party. // Quite possibly my favorite way to start a party or celebrate the middle of the week. Inspired by @bonappetitmag

It always feels like a small miracle.

Monday morning. Coffee in hand, calendar overwhelms and the tasks are mounting. But I sit, read, enjoy the brunt bitter drink of coffee and will gratitude into the present. In the midst of the to dos, the schedule and the deadlines I hope for all of us this week also brings moments like the one reflected in the image. Simple beauty, a warm banana cake, sweet conversation with friends and a moment to deeply inhale. Setting my intentions for the week before jumping into it. More of this forever and ever amen.

Weekending. Coffee with a side of stroopwafel. A buttery, crisp yeasted cookie sandwiches between toffee-like caramel. // There are a lot of recipes that have failed me but I found the one and Im making a note of it here because while I went through several failed batches to get to the winning recipe last year, I basically repeated the process this year because I couldnt remember where the winning recipe came from. So let me save you the trouble @prueleith makes the best stroopwafel. Her recipe can be found on @thegreatbritishbakingshow website. Just in case your coffee needs a friend this weekend.

Happy birthday to Lets Stay In. Thank you to all of you who have brought a piece of me into your home. The messages I get about recipes youve tried and shared and loved fill my soul to the point where words can never touch the gratitude I feel. The work I do is an honor. Being a small part of your table is a gift. Thank you, thank you. // To honor this day I think this oven baked squash risotto is in order. Get the recipe on the blog.

This humble little beauty is a showstopper in disguise. Olive oil dappled (go with it) focaccia is given the royal treatment with alternating paper thin slices of delicata squash and potatoes. Tucked in a few of the cracks are bay leaves. Once baked the crisped layers are capped with frilly grated pecorino and then I went and put a bit of arugula from the garden on top because pizza salad should absolutely be a thing. Get the recipe for this squash pizza (which got rave reviews from even the squash hating members of the family) on the blog now. @caoliveranch
"Live in each season as it passes; breathe the air, drink the drink, taste the fruit, and resign yourself to the influence of the earth." - Henry David Thoreau

Some version of this focaccia-style pizza happens at least once a week in our house. The dough comes together real quick and you can throw whatever you have in the fridge on top. This one is leeks, mushrooms and smoked mozzarella (the recipe is in my book, Lets Stay In) the one Ill be dropping on the blog this week is delicata squash, potato, bay and pecorino. So get your pantry stocked because you want this in your life. @caoliveranch

Never underestimate your influence. Here I was mindlessly scrolling through my feed when I stumbled upon @taraobradys stunning shot of doughnuts (fritters specifically). The urge was immediate and when I remembered the buttermilk I bought yesterday (to make Danish Rye Bread for my hunting trip this weekend - Ill explain later) I left my feed and headed to @nytcooking and set out to make @alisoneromans Buttermilk cake doughnuts. Mine are more bar-like with a thin buttermilk nutmeg glaze but other than that I stuck to the recipe. Now @radriguezinc are drinking coffee and eating doughnuts and Im thankful for all the people who shared what they did to make this magic moment happen. Its a small thing but man, it really was a nice boost for my Friday.

This is the time of year when a stick of butter is always softening on the counter and the pantry is full of flours, sugars and of course vanilla. Its baking season. Im so excited to team up with @nielsenmassey to help you this baking season with through their campaign. In this series youll learn tips and tricks to make sure your baked goods come out as delicious as your house will smell while this apple cake bakes. // This cake starts with the scent of browned butter and just gets better from there. Its loaded with tart apples and has a sweet crisp crust thanks to pure vanilla sugar. // Head over to BetterYourBake.com to learn how to perfectly brown butter with their easy to follow how-to video. Makes 1 small loaf or an 8-inch round 1 1/2 cups flour 3/4 teaspoon baking soda 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon 1/2 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg 3/4 cup sugar 3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) butter, browned and cooled 2 eggs 1/2 teaspoon Nielsen-Massey Indonesian Pure Vanilla Extract 2 medium tart apples, peeled and diced 2 tablespoons Nielsen-Massey Madagascar Bourbon Pure Vanilla Sugar Preheat your over to 350F and butter your loaf or cake pan. Mix all the dry ingredients in a large bowl, then whisk together the butter, eggs and vanilla in a separate bowl. Add the wet ingredients to the dry then fold in the apples. The batter will be thick. Add the batter to your prepared pan, then top with vanilla sugar. Bake for 45-50 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the middle of the cake comes out clean.

Rare is the meal that is quick, comprised of pantry ingredients, nutritious and receives cheers from around the table. These coconut tomato and curried lentils with gingered yogurt is such a meal. The recipe is from Lets Stay In but with an onion, curry powder, lentils (1 cup), a can of diced tomatoes and coconut milk youre nearly there. I add cumin seed and chili flake then serve with rice and yogurt gently stirred with fresh minced ginger.

Well, hello there. // Chanterelles are carpeting (not quite that abundant, I wish) the forest floor and if you happen to be a lucky forager (or you bought some at the market) then may I suggest a Chanterelle Chowder. My favorite version is in my book, Lets Stay In but theres also a recipe on the blog. Its just the sort of thing for these days that feel like fall but tomatoes and corn are still lingering on the market shelves.

Green beans vinaigrette from the new stunner of a cookbook by @canalhouse. These beans are cooked until tender then doused in a shallot vinaigrette before getting showered with herbs. A simple new house staple. // Congrats on the new book @canalhouse!!

Fall is here and so is my recipe for a simple pear tart with salted maple caramel. Get the recipe in the current issue of @womansdaymag. This tart works just as well with apples, plums, peaches - or whatever else you happen to have lying around. Also, perfectly suitable for breakfast I say.

Theres a word in Dutch that I heard so often growing up that it wasnt until well into adulthood I realized it wasnt an English word. Gezellig cant be translated in English but the closest word is probably cozy. All I can say is that after spending a week in the Netherlands (Friesland specifically) when I think of that country gezellig is the word that always comes to mind. Its an incredible feeling to travel across the world to feel at home. Thankful to my grandparents for giving us such strong roots to this country that is so very gezellig.

Its not over until the peaches are gone. Isnt that what they say? Summer is still here as long as these locally sourced beauties are at the market. My favorite way to enjoy a peach is eaten outside with the juices dribbling down my face and hands or on this simple almond butter toast with a drizzle of honey over the top. Go watch the story to find out how to make your own deeply toasted almond butter for this peach toast. @fredmeyerstores @krogerco

A tomato tart to say goodbye. // My oldest and I are headed to the Netherlands for a week to be with family, honor the place and our people who called or call it home and to remind ourselves of deep roots. When we get back our home will be deep into fall and these tomatoes will be a distant memory. // So much change, transition and constant flowing. Its hard to keep up with at times. This morning as anxiety pushes in I am stopping to remind myself of the importance of pausing to grieve and feel gratitude before quickly jumping to the next season.

First course at last nights dinner. A chilled zucchini and buttermilk squash soup topped with fried potatoes and zucchini, pickled squash, chives, dill and salmon roe. Recipe from the latest @foodandwine. Although I roasted my squash instead of steaming it. While its still too warm for soup season this is a nice way to transition.

A love it when a fruit salad tip toes to the savory side. Here honeydew melon mingles with red onion and is simply dressed with olive oil and lime juice. Candies walnuts make this simple late summer side dish memorable. The recipe is posted for you on the blog @cawalnuts

I do love a salad thats casually assembled. Ripped and torn then gently rained on with olive oil and lemon juice. This one was enjoyed on a recent camping trip and inspired by a recipe on @bonappetitmag. Figs, watermelon, treviso, salt, olive oil and lemon. Thats it and thats all you need.

Were home now and scurrying to get ready for school tomorrow. Im not ready for this summer to end but seasons change and so must we. But here I sit looking at pictures from the road trip we just got back from instead of packing lunches. Soaking it in, letting the memories we created sink deeper into my soul. Tomorrow we shift back to routine and schedules but I do so feeling ridiculously grateful for the adventures we had. Summer, its not goodbye but rather, thank you.

Imagine this: a cake generous with lemon, studded with blackberries that puddle into the cake then capped with a shaved then caramelized white chocolate crust. Enough? Nah. Lets drizzle some grassy olive oil on top and add some whip cream because life is good and cake reminds us of that. // Get the recipe in my book, Lets Stay In.

I could eat this all day long. And with all the zucchini around these days I just may. You too can join me in feasting on this grilled zucchini or summer squash with Muhammara because the recipe is fresh on the blog @cawalnuts

Scenes from camping with family. A northwest inspired seafood boil with crab, mussels, clams and spot prawns we caught ourselves. All cooked over the fire. This scene, this memory, this food and these people make me so happy.

Do you ever go through seasons of flavors? Im on such a lavender kick right now. I love immersing myself in a scent or flavor because then every time I catch a whiff I will always remember this season. Leisurely sunny days, reading, dreaming and adventuring. // This cocktail has been on repeat. Lavender simple syrup with a heavy hit of fresh lemon juice and then gin and tonic water. Its not complete without a sprig of lavender so the scent and flowers tickle your nose with every sip.
Savoring summer one pie at a time. This one is blackberry lavender. Ill share the recipe on the blog real soon because it needs to be remembered.
Always and forever. The Blue Ribbon Tomato Tart from Lets Stay In.

A smoky tangle of fire cooked vegetables marinated in an oregano laced vinaigrette. Cant wait for you to get all over this recipe which has been on repeat this summer. The recipe is up on the blog. Made with our house favorite, @caoliveranch
A simple lunch that is worthy of note. Salted cucumbers, feta, tomatoes, grilled chicken, @ellenosyogurt, egg, and LandSea gomasio (sesame seeds, kelp and nettle).

Back from the island where my phone was only there to capture memories and my computer never saw my inbox. We fished, paddle boarded to get crab, hiked to the top of a mountain, smoked fresh caught salmon over the fire, picked blackberries for a cake and made memories to last a lifetime. Each moment felt like a gift. Slowly coming back to reality and trying to understand what that is. I always come away from vacation seeking to put a bit of that vacation feeling into my everyday. Today Ill turn my fresh picked blackberries into a pie and float with friends while eating leftover crab. And then Ill listen to Toni Morrison and remember a life well lived and continue to mourn for the lives tragically lost to gun violence and use my voice, my money and my time to fight. Because thats reality but it doesnt mean that we cant find the beauty in the midst of it.

The smell of good bread baking, like the sound of lightly flowing water, is indescribable in its evocation of innocence and delight... [Breadmaking is] one of those almost hypnotic businesses, like a dance from some ancient ceremony. It leaves you filled with one of the world's sweetest smells... there is no chiropractic treatment, no Yoga exercise, no hour of meditation in a music-throbbing chapel. that will leave you emptier of bad thoughts than this homely ceremony of making bread. - M.F.K. Fisher

I may not be super productive this summer but I did manage to find my ideal shortbread recipe. Feeling pretty damn accomplished. Its crisp and yet tender, buttery (duh), not too sweet, a bit salty and perfect with my morning coffee. // 1 1/2 cups all purpose flour, 1/2 cup rice flour (I grind rice in my spice grinder then sift), 3/4 cup powdered sugar, 3/4 teaspoon sea salt, 2 sticks unsalted butter (cold). Pulse everything a food processor until it comes together. Press in 8 inch square pan and bake at 325*F for about 45 minutes or until golden around the edges. (Adapted from @nytcooking).

Summer; the season when ingredients are at their prime and I dont feel like being in the kitchen to cook. So we either get out of the kitchen to cook or we keep it real simple. // Tomato salad with avocado ranch dressing from Lets Stay In.

May I present to you the Summer Sour. Remember that New York Sour I was so smitten with in the fall? The one with the red wine float that sits so striking against a base of whiskey, lemon and simple syrup? Well this one, perhaps not quite as striking, floats ros on top and is now deemed my cocktail for the summer of 2019. // 1 3/4 oz whisky, 3/4 ounce fresh lemon juice, 1/2 ounce rich simple syrup (1 cup sugar, 1/2 cup water simmered until sugar dissolves). Shake with ice then strain and pour into highball glass with ice. Slowly pour ros over the back of a spoon right on the surface of the cocktail. Garnish with lemon peel. Recipe adapted from @food52 (from @mollyorangette and @delanceyseattle).

It was a bountiful day out on the water yesterday and quite possibly the most thankful Ive ever felt to live in the Pacific Northwest. Did you see the fish I caught?!! (In my stories). // If you find yourself with spot prawns (lucky you!) I highly recommend @chefreneeericksons recipe for Renees Messy Prawns on @mollyorangettes blog. So simple and eyes closed, thank the good Lord good.

This is a homemade pop tart the size of a sheet pan. Not sure why I felt like this is what our holiday weekend needed but definitely no regrets. // Double the pie dough recipe from Lets Stay In. Omit the oil in the crust and just add a bit more water (makes it easier to roll out this massive pastry). Its filled with a tart strawberry rhubarb jam then topped with a simple icing of powered sugar, lemon juice and a touch of cream. Rainbow sprinkles to finish. Hope you all had a lovely time celebrating however that looks for you.

Very special thanks to @chefranga.p of Laurians Table for sharing this place with us. Last night. Over the fire. Charred local tomatoes for a salad with greens and herbs, heirloom tomatoes, burnt corn, roasted lemon, wild flowers and Parmesan frico. // Now were off to go launch of sixth episode of @kitchenunnecessary @outdoorretailer.

Kumamoto oysters, rhubarb mignonette. Lemon for those who prefer it. // Im really loving Bren Smiths book, Eat Like A Fish, and learning about aquaculture and how these beauties are like a natural filtration system for the ocean. Eat incredible food that helps clean our waters?! Yes, please.

Next week were launching our sixth episode of @kitchenunnecessary. First to an audience @outdoorretailer then online. So incredibly proud of the heart and soul behind this episode. I am a different person after this experience in Montana with @chefranga.p. This quote sums up the experience for me, They say you forget your troubles on a trout stream, but thats not quite it. What happens is that you begin to see where your troubles fit into the grand scheme of things, and suddenly theyre just not such a big deal anymore. John Gierach // A very hearty thanks to @stanley_brand for partnering with us on this adventure. Were so fortunate to have your support.

Head to the blog to get my latest recipe for Whole Grain Linguine with Asparagus and Salmon then inspired by @BarillaUS Italian Recipe Builder that helps you create hundreds of pasta dish combinations

Water does not resist. Water flows. When you plunge your hand into it, all you feel is a caress. Water is not a solid wall, it will not stop you. But water always goes where it wants to go, and nothing in the end can stand against it. Water is patient. Dripping water wears away a stone. Remember that, my child. Remember you are half water. If you can't go through an obstacle, go around it. Water does. - Margaret Atwood

Well call this the 10 minute neighborhood bbq salad. // 1 can white beans, drained and rinsed, arugula, cherry tomatoes, shallot, lemon zest and juice, olive oil, flake salt and ricotta salata generously shaved over top.

These days our dinners arent happening around the table but rather on a hand-me-down blanket at the baseball fields while we cheer on Roman. I wouldnt change a thing. // Parenting feels so different in this stage. In the younger years our days were so physically demanding and often defeating. Yes, they had their beautiful moments and I would give just about anything to squeeze their little sausage thighs again but these days are the best. These little people of ours are becoming themselves and yet still will fall asleep in my arms. They are brave, strong and opinionated and everyday I think what an honor it is to know them. // Parents of the littles it gets easier. All those challenging days are so worth it. Give yourself unlimited amounts of grace, dont even attempt to enjoy every moment because well, they arent all enjoyable. Squeeze those baby thighs and know there are so many great and rewarding days ahead.

Gathering ingredients from the yard for a batch of amaro. Im sharing the process on my stories and for those who are attending our Nourish Through Nature workshop in June Ill share the amaro with you!

Know the ways of the ones who take care of you, so that you may take care of them. Introduce yourself. Be accountable as the one who comes asking for life. Ask permission before taking. Abide by the answer. Never take the first. Never take the last. Take only what you need. Take only that which is given. Never take more than half. Leave some for others. Harvest in a way that minimizes harm. Use it respectfully. Never waste what you have taken. Share. Give thanks for what you have been given. Give a gift, in reciprocity for what you have taken. Sustain the ones who sustain you and the earth will last forever. - Braiding Sweetgrass, Robin Wall Kimmerer. // A recipe for lilac infused honey is fresh on the blog.

This pea salad, on repeat. Pea vines charred (over the fire is best of course but a broiler works mighty fine too), English peas, sugar snap peas then a mess of herbs, lemon, olive oil, pecorino and pistachios. Sometimes there has been shaved radish on top but mostly we let the green shine in all its spring glory. The recipe is up on the blog.

Have you tried the radish toast from Lets Stay In yet?! Im a big fan of the classic combination of radish, butter and salt but my version uses olives for that puckering salinity. Black olive butter is magic and I think we all should know it. Radishes are shining bright right now so lets do this!

Behind the scenes we have been planning our dream workshop for months and its finally time to let you all in on it. Nourishing Through Nature is an afternoon spent honoring and savoring the bounty nature offers. You will spend a day exploring nature through tactile experiences. Local floral designer, @teressajohnson , will guide the us through a flower crown demonstration where we will play with florals and foraged goods to create a stunning crown. A natural dyeing enthusiast, Hina Mughal, will lead the us through the process of creating a unique silk scarf or head wrap. Then well head to the table for a lunch cooked (by me!) over the fire using local, wild ingredients. The entire event will be held @oxbowcenter. There they grow food and native plants, learn about nature and how we can protect it while benefiting from it, and they educate children and the general public about food, farming, and the environment. Im not exaggerating when I say this event is a dream come true. June 23, 10:30-2:30. For more information click the link in my profile. I can not wait to share the table and this incredible experience with you.
Over on the blog Im sharing the winning recipes from the @barillaus . Go be a champion and make some pasta!

Same cake, another year. Our baby turned 13 this weekend. A teenager. The age we parents tend to dread and approach with anything less than eagerness. I may only be two days in so perhaps not the most reliable expert but if being a teenager means raising $1,000 to help 40 lives escape human trafficking and gathering some of the coolest kids to play games and eat salted peanut butter Rice Krispie treat cake than I am all in. This age is less about hand holding and more about sitting back, being present and to witness the unfurling of a life. It can be awkward and painful and beautiful all in the same moment. I am ridiculously honored to walk through life with this kid. Were going to be okay if the next generation is in the hands of humans like him.

Toast for all. This photo is not exactly as it seems. You see this toast is 100% plant based. @justforall asked me (a skeptic) to try . I did and Ive got to say Im impressed. It cooked beautifully and really tasted delicious. Im an egg fanatic so this is high praise. If you want to give it a shot find JUST Egg near the eggs or in the plant-based protein section at your local grocery store. // For the recipe: Set a non-stick skillet over medium low heat. Add about 2 teaspoons olive oil then 1/2 cup JUST Egg to the skillet. Gently stir to create a fluffy texture. Cook until no liquid remains, about 3-5 minutes. Add to a thick cut piece of toast then finish with shaved radish, dill, mint and any other herbs you may have on hand. Finish with another light drizzle of olive oil and a pinch of flake salt

Im home from spending a few days cooking over the fire in Montana. I still smell of smoke and I couldnt be happier. From the incredible high of the @beardfoundation awards then gathering over 60 people at the table for a fire cooked feast I am feeling so damn happy to be doing this work. // If cooking over the fire intimidates you lets start here. Fire fondue. Put a large wedge of creamy, meaty cheese like a Brie or even better yet, triple cream in a cast iron skillet then set over the fire. Set rosemary directly in the coals and let that fragrant smoke wash over the cheese. Once melted add the rosemary ash and sprigs to the cheese then serve and be loved.

My blog, Not Without Salt, got its name from a James Beard quote, where would we be without salt? Yesterday I stood under this powerful James Beard quote the day after we attended his namesake awards. And while we arent coming home with the medal around our necks I am coming home more in love with my industry and deeply inspired by the people who push the boundaries and strive to love and make life more beautiful using food as the medium. I want to too. Food is our common ground. Common ground is a great place to start. // Also, do not miss the tacos at Los Tachos No. 1 in Chelsea Market. Ridiculous.

Hey friends! I read an article yesterday about the new Instagram trend of posting very real moments and bad photos. What was supposed to be a Valentines inspired lamb feast turned into a spring lamb feast (thank you Seattle snowpocolypse). But we made it happen and it was exactly what it was suppose to be. Twelve people came to the table as strangers and they left as friends. I mean it got real. By the end we were going around the table sharing secrets and asking intimate questions of one another. Lets do it again!

Im one part peas! Radish! Spring greens!! And also, lets just cozy up on the couch with a heaping bowl to mushroom risotto. You get it?! // 2 tablespoons butter 8 ounces sliced mushrooms 1 1/2 teaspoons sea salt, divided 4 garlic cloves, minced 1 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves 1 1/4 cups arborio rice 4 cups chicken or vegetable stock 1 cup white wine, divided 1 cup grated fontina 1 cup finely grated Parmesan Add the butter to a large skillet set over medium high heat. Stir in the mushrooms along with 1/2 teaspoon sea salt. Saut the mushrooms until deeply caramelize, about 10 minutes. Stir in the garlic and thyme and saut about 2 minutes more or until fragrant. In a 9x13 baking dish add the rice, stock, and 1 teaspoon sea salt then stir in the mushrooms. Place the dish in the middle rack of your oven. Turn the oven to 400F. Bake the rice for 30 minutes stirring about halfway through. The rice should still be ever so chewy. Remove the rice from the oven then stir in the remaining 1/2 cup white wine, fontina and the parmesan. Serve while warm. // : @radriguezinc

Current favorite taste of spring: slice snap peas, herbs, flowers, pecorino, pistachio, lemon and olive oil. Styled and shot @thepantryseattle food styling workshop I taught with @basilandpoppyseeds. The inspiration I needed to jump into this new season of newness and light.

You guys! If you love vinegar as much as I do well, then lets be friends and eat this sandwich together. Its a sort of toss everything in the pot situation and let time and vinegar work magic. // 6 to 8 chicken thighs 1 cup red wine vinegar 1 cup olive oil Salt and pepper 1 lemon, quartered 2 sprigs rosemary 1 dried chili 1 teaspoon cumin seed 4 cloves 1 small head garlic (or 6 cloves, peeled) 1 onion, peeled and quartered Throw it in a pot and simmer for about an hour. The chicken will fall apart. If youre smarter than me youll tie together the spices in cheesecloth instead of going fishing for them later. Make some pickled red onions (recipe in both of my books and on the blog) and whip of a dill mayonnaise by stirring the two together. Boom! Wednesday wins. : @radriguezinc

Gabe and I took ourselves to @dinosseattle last night and the moment I walked in I wondered why we arent here more often. It fills me with an electric delight to watch good people creating beautiful things. People who create and take the big step to make a dream a reality. We all benefit from that bravery. On the other side of town a dear friend Ive known since elementary school is also building her dream with @lovespruceshop. So damn proud of these people and the millions of others who are sharing their dreams with the world everyday.

Im adding another lesson to my list from my last post (which by the way, made me so happy. You all are the absolute best people). // Gather stories, not things. These plates tell a story that brings me to tears and inspires me to be better. Each one is hand made by a woman in Oaxaca named Valentina. They are from the earth and to the earth they return. These plates represent her livelihood and generations of skilled artisans sharing their craft. To touch, feel and eat off that plate felt like a sacred honor. We need things but I want the things I surround myself with to be fueled with intention and bathed in story, just like these plates. // Forever grateful to @shelleyarmistead for introducing me to the story and @barebonesliving for giving it a stunning platform. More stories soon.

37 today. Yip yip!! I started a list of 37 things Ive learned. Hopefully the list will be complete before I turn 38. Heres what I have so far: 1. Youre never too old to make a big deal of your birthday. 2. I thought Id have more things figured out but instead Ive learned that figuring things out is not the goal. Being okay with the unknown is a much more fruitful pursuit. 3. No one has it figured out its just that some people are better at pretending. 4. Being okay is actually okay. 5. Stay hydrated. Who am I kidding? Im still working on that one. 6. Take small steps towards your curiosity. It will eventually reveal the path. 7. God is so much bigger and kinder and more loving than you can imagine. 8. Stay clear of people who only see things in black and white. Embrace the gray. 9. Gather your people, love them fiercely and be loved by them. 10. Laugh more.
Dinner plans made. Happy Monday!

I often underestimate the satisfaction of a skillet of baked eggs. It helps that there are leeks, olives and goat cheese in there as well. I also often underestimate the power of the table even though its one of the things I most believe in. Yesterday we gathered a group @notwithoutsaltshop to learn how to take better food photos on your phone but as often happens it quickly felt like so much more than that. In an instant class was done and we all felt like friends. // This week Ive witnessed the power of being an online community and so many people rallied around my dear friend @withlovekacie and her family after everything they owned was stolen and yesterday we created community around coffee, scones and some eggs. Today Im just feeling so grateful to be a part of it all. // This place is noisy and I dont want to just be a part of the noise. Clinging to the reminder than in the midst of the noise there are real people, real lives and real opportunities for connection and community. Thats what Im into.
Biding my time until rhubarb takes over this feed.

Today I have a little story to tell. One that I have been scared to attempt to put words to it for fear they would not be enough. But here it goes. // When she was in the hospital Grandma remained her beautiful self, beaming from her bed and eager to boast of her grandchildren and great grandchildren each time a nurse was there long enough to listen. She also insisted on wearing lipstick. We dutifully kept her lips lacquered each time she asked. My mom applied her own color to her mothers lips and we all knew that was grandmas color. Her cheeks blushed and her blue eyes sparkled even brighter. Later in the day, while grandma rested, Baron and I went to the mall and got grandma root beer (as she requested) and her very own tube of @maccosmetics lipstick in the color called Ravishing. She wore it as she was getting prepped for surgery. She wore it in recovery and she wore it as she took her last breath. I stood in front of a crowded room at grandmas memorial a week later and told the story of the lipstick and reminded everyone just how ravishing this woman was. Delightful and entrancing. Charming, lovely and wonderful. Shortly after grandmas death I reached out to @rebekahgoughjewelry to see if she could help me create a necklace to remember such a ravishing life lived. The handwriting is grandmas writing. I copied each letter from various handwritten recipes swooping the cursive R in Grandmas way. The way she wrote it on her recipe for Rhubarb Pie. Ive worn the necklace every day since with no plans of taking it off. She would not love the attention this story brings to her life but a ravishing life is one worth sharing.

Snowmageddon is upon us here in Seattle. (Its cool, we do not know how to deal with snow, so we talk about it. A LOT!) But Im over here packing my bags getting ready for our trip back to Palm Desert next week. We will be spritzing. Yup, its a verb. Come on and spritz with me!

So you know, we have oranges, wine and all the ingredients to make the 3 oclock cookie (have you made it yet? Check my highlights). Storm or no storm, follow my lead friends.
In my happy place. Outside, by the fire. : @radriguezinc @kitchenunnecessary

Introducing the 3 oclock cookie. // My 3 oclock sweet tooth is strong and sometimes I just need a cookie. This is that cookie. Its sweet, a bit salty and quite hearty loaded with oats, peanuts oh and m&ms too. But heres the real magic: Just before going into the oven the cookies get a drop of honey. The honey puddles and pools then caramelizes in the oven for a crackly crust and lacy caramel that gathers at the cookies edge. Its what your 3 oclock needs. This recipe is adapted from @twopeasandpod. Get the recipe in my stories.

Its all citrus all the time over here. This platter of oranges and grapefruit was sprinkled with raw sugar then broiled until caramelized and a little bit charred in parts. I wouldnt mind a sprinkle of vanilla salt over the top but you know thats me.

NYC Ashley walks out in the crosswalk even when the red lighted hand tells her no. Shes a bit punchier and loud. She thinks twice before always blaming herself first. She is a little braver and more confident then her west coast self. She still hasnt conquered the subway system. She prefers to walk anyway. She plans to take a bit more of her east coast self home with her. So watch out west coast. Watch out world.

Staged (but delicious) oranges and this year Ive been thinking about reframing in the hope that a subtle shift might not create such a vast space between hope and reality. What if instead of creating goals or intentions for the new year which are often weighty words that in the back of our minds we already know that down the road theyll be ditched alongside the Christmas gift we needed what if we wrote down our curiosities. Like goals, we could use our curiosities to act as a road map but unlike goals, curiosities feel a bit more playful, more childlike and more easily adaptable to the inevitable shift when the collision of fantasy and reality hit. // More thoughts on this on the blog if youd like to read on.

Carrying on your tradition, grandma. // Grandmas Banana Bread - 6 ripe bananas, 1 cup oil, 2 cups sugar, 2 eggs, 1 teaspoon salt, 2 teaspoons baking soda, 4 cups flour. Makes two loaves. Mix in order and bake 350 F about an hour.

Our thanksgiving meal always begins with a tray of vegetables with plenty of ranch for dipping. Like many traditions the repeated nature of it elevates the simple to holy status. Ours is the sort that comes covered in plastic and the first thing to go is always the black olives because even at 36 I cant resist capping each fingertip with a shiny black olive. What are some of your most cherished thanksgiving traditions?

// For easy holiday cocktails I always look towards a punch. This tequila-based punch is festive in color thanks to the help of blood oranges and hints at the holiday with a rosemary and spice simple syrup. Its a hat tip towards a margarita with a warming and unique twist. Guests can customize their punch with the help of the handy tap on every box of @BlackBoxSpirits. Cheers and happy gatherings! // Make the simple syrup by combining 1 cup water with 1 cup sugar, 3 cinnamon sticks, fresh ginger, 5 cloves and 2 rosemary sprigs. Simmer until sugar dissolves. Add cool simple syrup to a punch bowl along with 1 cup fresh lime juice, 1 1/2 cups fresh blood orange juice, 1/2 cup triple sec and 2 cups Black Box Tequila. Add ice and top with club soda. A pinch of salt is highly recommended. For21+

I always like to shake up my Thanksgiving menu a bit. The classics are there with a few twists. This year I created two menus and I cant decide which one to go with. Help me choose in my stories! If youre still looking for a menu our go-to classic is in my new book, Lets Stay In. It comes with a plan so you wont end up in the kitchen all day. Although really, is there a better way to spend the day?! No matter the menu Im grateful for the time at the table. // Styling by @lauren.michelle.day

You will lose someone you cant live without, and your heart will be badly broken, and the bad news is that you never completely get over the loss of your beloved. But this is also the good news. They live forever in your broken heart that doesnt seal back up. And you come through. Its like having a broken leg that never heals perfectlythat still hurts when the weather gets cold, but you learn to dance with the limp. @annelamott // Thinking about loss and the holiday table. Struggling with the idea of needing it to be the same when its completely different. How do we honor the lives that are no longer at the table while continuing to move into the newness. Im finding my way with the Buttermilk Pumpkin Streusel Pie from @sisterpiedetroit // More words and the recipe on the blog.

Nothing can wipe the smile off my face after coming home with this award for @kitchenunnecessary in the Best Food Video category. @saveurmag has always been an inspiring source for food stories and culture so to get this nod from the editors means the world. With the season of gathering and celebration ahead of us I give you this incredibly simple yet festive appetizer. Start with blue cheese on a plate. Then saut walnuts with olive oil, honey, rosemary and a pinch of cayenne. While warm add the walnuts to the blue cheese. Finish with a drizzle of honey, flake salt and pomegranate if you happen to have them in your fridge like I did.

Despite not catching a single fish while in Alaska the entire trip changed my life. I know that sounds clich and perhaps a bit dramatic but I stand by it. Our Alaska series launches in Seattle @filson1897 in November 29 and to the world the next day. And follow along next week as we head to the @saveurmag awards in Memphis! Its Thursday which is practically the weekend which is why we need a New York Sour. Its my self-proclaimed fall house cocktail. So come on over or follow this simple recipe // 2 ounces bourbon, 1 ounce fresh lemon juice, 1 ounce simple syrup. Shake over ice then pour in a rocks glass over ice. Slip about 1/2 ounce of red wine over the back of a spoon hovering just above the glass. // Quite possibly the prettiest cocktail around.

Hosted a lovely group in the @notwithoutsaltshop where @mcreativej was teaching us some of her embroidery magic. No class in the shop is complete without some delightful snacks. I made us the spiced raisin scones from . All in all a banner Sunday. Whats happening out there in your world, friends?

One pan fall dinner. Whats better than that?! Squash, chanterelles, potatoes, onions roasted along with sage and thyme. Olive oil, salt and smoked paprika to coat. Roast at 400 degrees for 25-30 minutes then add a few sausages on top if youd like and roasted until those are cooked through, about 15 minutes more. Done!

Putting my second book out into world has been so much more freeing than the first. The recurring mantra in the my head with my first was its not enough. Major joy killer. This time Ive scheduled less things that give me angst and put in more time to breathe and take it in. And I am taking it in. You guys have no idea what it means to me when you share photos of what you are making in your homes. The emails, the lovely reviews, the tags - all of it fill me with such delight and gratitude for this work I get to do. // This photo is a perfect example of joy in what could be (and honestly, still is) a very vulnerable season. @joythebaker welcomed me into her home, we fed people around the table, we baked together, ate beignets and the most delicious sandwiches of my life (thanks, @turkeyandthewolf) made paper flowers, and did yoga. As I sat there in the yoga studio paying attention to my breath tears streamed down my face as I felt a deep calm and enoughness. Thats more than I can ever ask for. : @trevor_mark

To honor what would have been my grandmothers 95th birthday yesterday I made pie. Pie for sixty in fact as I brought them with me to @booklarder for my signing. They all graciously listened and waited as I choked my way through my essay in the book about grandma and her pie. She would be proud of this pies perfectly imperfect stature and the heaps of butter dotting the top. She also would be proud of me. I miss hearing her saying those words but I feel them deeply.

My favorite way to begin a meal currently: Camembert baked with blackberries and rosemary. Would work well with figs, plums, pears, cranberries, etc. The recipe is in the new book but really its as easy as it sounds.

What an overwhelming week. I cant put words to whats happening in our country. I hate the divide, I loathe the black and white thinking and my heart breaks for those who are triggered on a daily basis. At the same time last night was the first night I got to celebrate my book at the table. Overwhelmed by generous compliments as I signed their books, I went home beaming. As I get older I get more and more used to the idea that life is both joy and sorrow and often at the same time. One emotion doesnt take away from the other. We all know what we can handle and how to best care for ourselves. Literally as Im typing this a calendar reminder popped up reminding me that today is blocked for sanity. Thanks to a wise friend @julieahubert who urged me to create that space. Today is fishing and foraging with my family and our friend @cocotteblog , a long time blog reader who flew in to help me with all the events this week. Tomorrow I bake. Willing myself the energy and bravery to fight but first today I rest and focus my energy on the three little lives entrusted to me. Raising honorable people who are empathetic, strong, know how to stand up for themselves and know when to say Im sorry. // Pie styled by @basilandpoppyseeds

Do you ever get overwhelmed with a bite so delicious, a moment too perfect, a place so beautiful you gasp and shriek even when walking alone? Im in that moment. Pinching myself with the goodness, feeling so loved and hoping I could share just a sliver of this feeling with you all. Im spending a few days @grandhyattbahamar brought me here. Its not you its me. No no, were not breaking up but I am saying goodbye to what Ive turned this place into in my own mind. Ive become fearful of the people who click unfollow. I cringe when the post numbers are low. I cower when the numbers decrease and I immediately sing the chorus of Im not enough! I refuse to turn my back on this platform and declare its all bad! No way, Im reclaiming it for good; caring less about the numbers and more about the connection. Reconnecting with you all - my beautiful online friends and community and following my heart to post the things that make my insides flutter. Not to say that what Ive posted hasnt been me but it hasnt been fully me because I approach cautiously and fearfully. No more. No matter the numbers Im here with full heart and am grateful for every single connection. You all inspire me and it is my hope to do the same with boldness and no apologies.

Soaking up summer the best that I can. // Jamoca Almond Fudge: Whip 2 cups heavy cream to stiff peaks with 2 tablespoons instant espresso and a hefty pinch of salt. Slowly whisk in 1 14 ounce can of sweetened condensed milk. Layer this mixture in a loaf pan along with your favorite chocolate fudge and deeply toasted and salted almonds. Freeze for at least 3 hours.

I have one foot in summertime grasping at missed sun-filled experiences and one foot in fall water for sweaters, soups, and candle lit evenings with the fireplace roaring. Normally I cling to the sun filled days until the very end but I finally admitted to myself that this summer was so hard. Grieving in what should the sunniest and happiest of months. Pulled between emotions, trying to exist in both places and I realize Im tired. As I gear up for another cookbook release I also realize that the need for self care is greater than ever. A creative releasing their creation into the world is quite possibly the most angsty creatures. Its all part of the process. In the meantime Ill seek the beauty in these days while - not hard to spot when I turn down the noise. And then Ill get the soup pot ready #

This is the image used on the cover of Lets Stay In and I really love it because its real. I do love pretty things but more than that I want real life to happen at the table. Theres mess in this photo and not food styled mess. Pasta noodles that didnt quite make the plate while the 7 year old helped herself. Parmesan flecks dot the entire table as we help ourselves to more and its a simple pasta dish like the ones we eat so often. Whats not real is the amount of greens on certain plates of the particular eaters. Oh well, what can you do? My copy of the book arrived yesterday and I had a hard time putting it down. I just held it, not looking too close fearing that Id find something in there that would ignite my inner critic but squeezing it and resting in the accomplishment. Feeling proud

If you watched my stories over the weekend you saw that I took a painting class. What you didnt see was the adult size tantrum I threw after Fridays class. I wanted it to be easy, I wanted to breathe deep and escape the resounding inner critic whose voice has been so damn loud lately. Shes relentless and brutal and she didnt leave me alone this weekend like I asked her to. I thought about not going back to Saturdays class. I had a house to myself so why would I want to spend an entire weekend putting myself through torture? Because things worth doing are hard. Growing is uncomfortable and a little pain, fear and terror is not something to run from. Yesterday, as I showed up to class, to a blank canvas, I listened to the book Art & Fear. I found myself feeling proud for showing up as I listened to these words. The function of the overwhelming majority of your artwork is simply to teach you how to make the small fraction of your artwork that soars. One of the basic and difficult lessons every artist must learn is that even the failed pieces are essential. X-rays of famous paintings reveal that even master artists sometimes made basic mid-course corrections (or deleted really dumb mistakes) by overpainting the still-wet canvas. The point is that you learn how to make your work by making your work, and a great many of the pieces you make along the way will never stand out as finished art. The best you can do is make art you care about and lots of it! Any creative endeavor will leave you with a pile of unfinished work. Or youll think its finished, share it, then years later youll see your growth. But you have to show up. Ive been so inspired hearing the stories of people around me showing up. Were all scared, we all dont know what were doing but the people who acknowledge the fear then leave it in the dust amaze me. Lets keep showing up. Say hi to fear, acknowledge that its presence means were doing something that we care about, then keep on walking to the task &fear

A year ago those walls were green and yellow. It was a hair salon but I saw the potential of a long table where people could linger for hours and I would stand behind the stove and take it all in. Inspired by that fava scene I shared a couple posts back, Ive rediscovered my love for classic panzanella. It doesnt hurt that with my new found passion for sourdough baking my house always has a loaf of bread lying around. // Use stale bread or toast in a 350 F oven until slightly dry, about 10 minutes. Using your hands squeeze roughly chopped tomatoes into a large bowl. Add a bit of red wine vinegar or aged balsamic, salt and a bright grassy olive oil. Toss the bread with the tomatoes then add thinly slice sweet onion. If the onions have a bit of bite soak in water for 30 minutes. Finally add a flurry of verdant basil @thefeedfeed

This weekend was everything and more. Tomato soaked bread with sweet onions and a flurry of basil, a sunny morning on the farm getting dirt in our fingernails and taking photos of our bounty, bike rides that left our legs feeling like jello and boating adventures speckled with the hopes of pulling pounds and pounds of fresh crab into our boat. In spite of our lackluster bounty we had such a great time (and not all was lost as we did have plenty of cool ranch chips and ice cold cherries on board for snacking.) Hello, Monday. I think I can handle you because Im still reeling from the weekend

My daily bread. // That summer project born out of boredom has grown into beautiful bread. My son and I started a basic flour/water starter, fed it with great care and then just over a week later we have these gorgeous loaves. For the recipe and method I have been using @tartinebakerys recipe from their bread book

While on Lopez this past weekend we stumbled upon a scene Ill not soon forget. A small group sat at an aged wooden table with a heaping pile of brilliant favas, chartreuse in color and so young and tender they instructed us to eat them straight from the pods. There was prosciutto thinly sliced and thick with fat, homemade wine and a wooden cutting board marred from years of use, covered in tomato and onion soaked bread with ruffled basil leaves scattered throughout. Its no surprise that much of this bounty was from one man who moved to the island from Italy. We joined them for a few minutes. Long enough to drink some wine, indulge in several pieces of prosciutto, eat bread dripping with ruby tomatoes and forever be changed by a group of people and a pile of favas

Every winter I regret not preserving enough of summers bounty. Well, this year I turned preserving into a party. A few of us gathered in the shop and spent a day making pickles, jams, relish and bourbon-soaked cherries for those cold evening old fashioneds. Fun time with people I adore and a pantry stocked. I highly recommend

While the kids are away ... the mama will eat a giant salad with smoked chicken, raspberries, garden grown green beans, herbs and greens and a tahini ranch dressing. There were also pink bubbles and a I got to choose the show to watch

Hard to get my head in the vacation game right now. These last two weeks have been some of the hardest of my life as I lost three of my precious grandparents. No matter the age loss is devastating and yet at times beautiful. Ive learned how closely related laughter is with tears. And Ive been reminded again and again that my love is best seen through the food I prepare. While on Orcas I wandered the town on a Babettes Feast sort of exploration gathering the perfect ingredients for dinner. So much joy in feeding and gathering people at the table. At times Ive just sat in silence stunned by the loss, I have no words and then I turn on the oven and bake a pie, or a loaf or banana bread or slowly smoke salmon over the fire. Its something

The @notwithoutsaltshop exists to love people through food. Sometimes that looks like filling our table with 14 people who walk in as strangers and leave a family. Weve also given a portion of our cookie mix and salt purchases to @firstaidarts who uses creativity as a tool for healing and hope. Through July 1 we are giving all of our profits of purchases from our retail shelves to @raicestexas and @together.rising as they fight to reunite the thousands of children tragically separated from their families. My heart is broken and I cant sit back and watch. Give to these organizations if you have any to spare. Capping off a lovely staycation weekend with my lifers (friends for liiiiife) @unionsaloon. So fun to vacation in your own city, discover new places, hang in a neighborhood dive bar and laugh, cry and connect with some of my favorite people on this planet

A day with no plans is my favorite sort of day. I love the way it unfolds naturally and becomes just what it needs to be. Today we turned a patch of grass and weeds into an open fire pit where I made us a feast of smoked trout, grilled oysters with butter and dill, steak with fresh horseradish sauce, roasted potatoes cooked under a bacon wrapped pork tenderloin and this pasta with charred asparagus, lemon oil and burrata. // This day is beautiful and hard. I spent much of it fighting through the voice in my head that tells me Im not enough as a mom. That my mothering is somehow less worthy of affirmation because it doesnt look like the model we so often see presented in our culture. And then I hurt for the motherless, for those who desperately want to be a mother and those who have a strained relationship with their mother. Its a day filled with expectation and as a mom Im always torn between spending this day doing the things my heart desires, being completely present with my children and making sure my own mother feels my immense love and respect for her. But as I sit here in bed trying to write something to caption this pasta Im reminded of a word that has been continually whispered into my consciousness lately; delight. Currently Im delighted in the sunset we watched with the soft pattering of the waves hitting the rocks. Im delighting in my child who went to the beach however reluctantly because he knew how much I would enjoy it. Im delighting in the smell of smoke in my hair from an afternoon cooking over the fire and Im delighting in the man sitting next to me who let this day be whatever I needed it to be, tears and all. Joy and sadness are such dear friends and are content to be in each others company. Today I felt all the feels and am going to bed choosing to delight in it all.

Stirring up a big bowl of cheesy carbonara-like pasta. Or maybe I should say, in the style of carbonara. However you say it doesnt change the fact that it is so freaking good. I love clean-out-the- fridge meals in the shop after events. // Mushroom Orecchiette with Blue Cheese and Thyme. // Here is a *very* rough recipe: 8 ounces Orecchiette boiled to al dente in heavily salted (should taste like the ocean) water. Add a tablespoon of butter to a hot skillet then stir in 8 ounces thinly sliced mushrooms. Add a sprig if thyme then leave the mushrooms to sear for at least two minutes over medium high heat before moving them around in the pan. Their edges nearly char while the flesh turns to the color of bittersweet chocolate. Add a couple of cloves of garlic that have been thinly sliced and a hefty pinch of salt. Add the pasta to the skillet along with a good bit of the pasta water then stir in about two ounces each of crumbled blue cheese and cream cheese. Stir until creamy and well combined. Finish with roughly chopped parsley

This one is big. Behind the scenes weve been working on a project that makes me feel all fluttery every time I think of it. @kitchenunnecessary is a video series created to inspire adventure and enjoyment of the outdoors. And of course theres food. We team up with some of the most talented and knowledgeable foragers, hunters, farmers, fishermen, etc. to guide us to the best ingredients. Then I take what weve found and prepare a meal over the fire. Our feast is cooked with little more than a hot pan, a camping knife and an open fire. This is Kitchen Unnecessary. : @radriguezinc

Use the same spices to make the maple caramel. Simmer maple syrup until slightly thickened, about five minutes or so. I can imagine this would also be quite nice for breakfast over yogurt

Somehow I think these lemons may have just revealed the resolution or intentions Ive been so desperately seeking for 2018. Hear me out. They are a far cry from beauty pageant contestants. In fact they came in my @imperfectproduce delivery this week. They are speckled, bruised, soft in parts and incredibly inconsistent. (Sounds familiar ) They would never make it to the supermarket shelves and yet today I covered them in a flurry of salt, tucked them into a jar and in one months time they will be fragrant, floral and the star ingredient in a Moroccan dinner Im preparing here at the shop. (If you want to watch the process of making preserved lemon watch my story). // Beauty from imperfection and joy in it all. These are not Instagram worthy lemons and yet they deserve a place too. We all do.

Thank you all for being here and honoring all of it. I appreciate you more than you know. So excited for whats next

These Maple Rosemary Walnuts were a big hit at our @gatherseattle party @notwithoutsaltshop last night. I didnt write down the recipe but Ill do my best to get as close as I can because I do think your holiday festivities need these. // Toast 2 cups walnuts for 10 minutes in a 350 degree oven. In a medium saucepan combine 1 1/2 tablespoons olive oil with 2 tablespoons maple syrup and 1/4 cup sugar. Bring to a boil then add 1 1/2 tablespoons finely chopped rosemary, 1 1/2 teaspoons grapefruit zest. Stir in the walnuts until coated and add a few hefty punches of flake salt. Transfer the nuts to a parchment lined sheet tray then roast for an additional 10 minutes or so. Store in an airtight container

The time of year when I warm the house with the heat of the oven. These spiced golden raisin scones are on repeat. // Want those luscious layers in yours scones or biscuits? Give them three turns as if you are making puff pastry. My recipe uses no eggs but gets fluffy layers from a few good folds. // 2 cups flour, 3 tablespoons sugar, 1 tablespoon baking powder, 1/4 teaspoon sea salt, 1 stick cold butter, 1 cup heavy cream, 1 teaspoon cinnamon, 1/2 teaspoon ginger, 1/4 teaspoon nutmeg, 1 cup golden raisins

In her new book @brenebrown showed me the necessity of the inhale in order to effectively exhale. We give, we serve, we create, we fight, we make our voices heard. And then we rest, we refuel, and recharge so we can go and create and fight some more. After Date Night In came out I started to realize that my career has seasons of pouring out and filling up. While my next book is far from finished the manuscript is in and Ive started to switch my mindset from giving myself and my creativity to refueling and learning more so when the next season of giving comes Ill have more to give. So yesterday I took a cooking class. @david_tanis has long been a cookbook hero to me and yesterday he taught @thepantryseattle. When your passion becomes your work you sometimes have to fight for your love of it and yesterday I was giddy with love for food, the table, and life. And today Im heading out into the woods to forage and cook for a project that has me tickled with excitement. Inhale. Inhale. Food and the table are my medium and I must continue to do the work that feeds my family and fuels my heart. But this morning I'm wrestling with the voice that says "why? What's the point?" I fight hard against the despair and the pointless pitty party that only further points to my own privilege. I turn the questions to "how can I use my voice? How can I help?" This quote my friend @evan_e_kearns shared (via @Cleowade) is helping me to action instead of dread and despair. // "And may the appalling hate of others fuel you to step more deeply into the work as a warrior of love, justice, and freedom in the fight against oppression and bigotry." // Eager to learn, use my voice as a megaphone for love, and as always will bring people to the table to refuel.

One more from vacation. Heading home and I'll admit I am a bit nervous about the reentry. I needed this vacation and I dug deep into the rest. I thought I'd do work, I thought I would plan future endeavors, I thought I would write. But instead I rested, read and stayed away from the internet. After a week of that I feel happy - deeply happy. Something I've not felt for awhile. This year has been a struggle for me mentally and I think so much of it comes from the internet. There are other factors too I'm sure but it's so noisy and I've fallen deep into the comparison and competition of it all. This vacation showed me that I can unplug and that it's necessary. I'm still here and always thrilled to inspire you all to the table. Thank you for being here. You all make this place such a joy for me. // : @hogstoneswoodoven

Grandma's banana bread recipe needs no adaptations but I just couldn't help myself. Peanut butter and chocolate add a bit more heft and decadence and yet I still can't help but slather salted butter over a warm slice. // Chocolate Peanut Butter Banana Bread 3 bananas, ripe 1 cup dark brown sugar 1/2 cup peanut butter 1 egg 1/3 cup neutral oil (canola, vegetable, rice bran) 2 cups all purpose flour 1 teaspoon baking soda 3/4 teaspoon sea salt 1 cup chocolate, roughly chopped Preheat your oven to 350F. In a large bowl mash the bananas then stir in the sugar until well mixed. Stir in the peanut butter, egg, and oil. Add the flour, baking soda, and sea salt and stir until the batter just comes together. Fold in the chocolate then pour into a greased loaf pan and bake until a toothpick inserted comes up clean, about 1 hour : @radriguezinc

After two baseball games in the cold yesterday soup was definitely necessary. This one follows my simple soup "formula" which basically starts with an onion then some sort of vegetable - in this case carrot with a good bit of ginger - and water to cover. It's really that simple but the key to this delicious simplicity is salt. Plenty of it and at every step of the process so you're extracting the flavor in each of the few ingredients involved. It's also helps when you cap the bowl with yogurt, olive oil, micro greens and our new Seedy Salt that will be in the shop (@notwithoutsaltshop ) soon! Check out the my story (soon - before it expires) to watch the soup process.

I can think of no better way to start a Monday: Coconut Date Shake. Tastes like a milkshake but it's totally not. Serves 2 1/3 cup creamy peanut or almond butter 5 pitted, soft medjool dates 3/4 cup coconut milk 1 1/2 cups ice pinch salt Combine everything in a blender then blend until completely smooth.

Making space in my days for hobbies. Parents of little's, you're probably dragging yourself into bed right now and really brushing your teeth is all you can muster - if that. But someday you'll have a bit more space in your day and your brain and you can attempt to have hobbies again. Sure, sometimes you'll miss those sausage thighs on your babes but you inhale their sweet scent now, commit it to memory and then enjoy the space that exists when they can manage to dress themselves, entertain themselves and they become more themselves. Every part of it is good. Hard but good. Right now I'm happy to be painting.

Teetering towards spring with this simple pasta. // Creamy Spaghetti with Bacon, Peas and Mint 8 ounces spaghetti 7 slices bacon, cut into 1/4-inch slices 1 cup frozen peas 1/2 cup heavy cream 1 cup finely grated Parmesan 1/2 cup mint leaves salt and pepper Cook the pasta in heavily salted water. While the pasta cooks saute the bacon pieces until crispy. Drain off the bacon grease (save it for your eggs in the morning) before adding in the peas. Saute until just warmed through then stir in the cream. Add the pasta along with a splash of pasta water and toss the pasta around in the sauce. Simmer gently until the sauce coats the pasta. Stir in a pinch of salt and a good bit of freshly cracked pepper. Add more pasta water as needed. Stir in half of the grated Parmesan. Transfer the pasta to a serving dish then tear the mint leaves over top. Finish with the remaining parmesan. // Get the printable version on the blog.

It's Sunday! So let's bake a cake with my personal favorite frosting - italian meringue buttercream. It's gloriously smooth, full of flavor and endlessly adaptable. You start with a sugar syrup cooked to soft ball (which is why you see me blowing a sugar bubble in the video) then add that to whipped egg whites before finishing with a hefty bit of butter. I finish mine with a shot of espresso for coffee buttercream. You can do the same, or add a vanilla bean, a scoop of caramel or jam, etc. Get the full recipe on the blog. : @gaber008

I had a strange vision last night. It wasn't really a dream but I also wasn't awake. There was a table and there was pie - apple to be exact. The sort I like where the apples are still crisp under the cover of a warm buttery crust. Then there were other dishes that I couldn't quite see but in my mind I kept saying "there is room on the table. There is always enough room at the table." All day I've thought of this table. I imagine grandma's Stamppot next to the pie. The sort with sauerkraut, not kale, and plenty of diagonally sliced kielbasa mixed in with the mashed potatoes. Next to that there's this dish my friend Sara has made for me a few times; soft baked eggplant with cumin and coriander and a mint spiked yogurt sauce. On the other side of the eggplant the enchiladas Gabe's grandma Emmy taught me how to make. I fry each tortilla in a shallow bath of oil just liked she showed me. It's a strange sort of feast that I've gathered and yet it's perfect. // I've tried so hard today to find more words. I sat down to write but instead I grabbed my paintbrush. I tried to read, cry, feel, pray and every time I came up short I heard the words whisper; there is always enough room at the table.
Kale's still cool right?! Especially when it's bathed in that lovely LA light. // Shot during a super fun food styling session I led here at TechMunch.
So much baking happened this week. Comfort.

That's my boy right there with his wild hair blowing and the grimace on his face. Back in November he said "mom, I want to raise money for my birthday." And that's just what he is doing. After reading about the deadliest animal on the planet - the mosquito - he decided he wanted to do something to help the spread of malaria. So he's trying to raise enough money to provide nets for 2,000 people. Mosquito nets are the best way to prevent against mosquito spread illnesses. We're coming beside him in this mission and watching our son shine goodness and love all over the world. If you want to check out his page and feel inclined to donate I will put the link in my profile. Kids these days, right

Thank you, Saturday Ashley, for making a giant pot of soup for us to dip into throughout this entire chilly weekend. // This soup could not be easier. I mean, sure if it came from a box that would be easier but you get it. Cut up a large, hairy, root creature that is a celery root and coat it with olive oil, salt, and pepper. Roast until the edges teeter towards burnt. Add the roasted celery root to a pot with a roughly cubed potato and half an onion. Save yourself the hassle of dicing. Cover with water, add another teaspoon of salt then simmer until the potato is falling apart. Blend, taste (season as needed) and top with all the things. In this case goat cheese, olive oil, and chili flakes. PS you can replace the celery root with pretty much any vegetable and it will be delicious. Guaranteed or your money back.

Citrus; the sunshine of winter. These are showered in a simple syrup laced with cardamom, clove and cinnamon. These days I'm often in bed before the kids so our evening date nights have become few and far between. This morning I made us breakfast and we sat in a quiet house eating breakfast blt's, oranges in spiced cardamom syrup, donuts with plum jam dip and breakfast marg's (it's a thing). We come to the table broken, empty, imperfect, human and we are met there with grace, love and sustenance. The table is the place we revive ourselves so that we can exist in a world away from the table. Its our fueling station, an anchor in a world that makes us feel like a boat ripped and pulled in towering waves. We crash and slam against the shore, our wood splinters, were thrown about but the table is the calm. At least thats what I want it to be. // More words and the recipe for @taraobrady's Everyday Dal (so good! So easy!!) on the blog.
