The tree is up and the house is feeling extra cozy these days. We're celebrating with a drink that feels oh so festive. // Line the rim of a 70 mm glass ornament with honey then dip in crushed candy cane. To a cocktail shaker add 1 ounce vodka, 2 ounces @baileysus and a few drops of Peppermint extract. Add ice then shake. Using a small funnel carefully pour the cocktail into the ornaments then top with heavy cream. Garnish with a small candy and a straw. Enjoy near a warm fireplace

We don't come to the table to fight or to defend. We don't come to prove or to conquer, to draw lines in the sand or to stir up trouble. We come to the table because our hunger brings us there. We come with a need, with fragility, with an admission of our humanity. The table is the great equalizer, the level playing field many of us have been looking everywhere for. The table is the place where the doing stops, the trying stops, the masks are removed, and we allow ourselves to be nourished, like children. We allow someone else to meet our need. In a world that prides people on not having needs, on going longer and faster, on going without, on powering through, the table is a place of safety and rest and humanity, where we are allowed to be as fragile as we feel. @sniequist Bread and Wine: A Love Letter to Life Around the Table with Recipes // Styling by @lauren.michelle.day

Holiday baking tip (I just made that up) Always, and I mean ALWAYS make extra pie dough. It freezes beautifully and turns humble pears into a spectacular galette. Simply slice pears, arrange in a lovely way and sprinkle with sugar. Serve with whipped cream or crme fraiche.

Thursday we hopped on a plane and flew to LA. There we picked up a car and slowly drove ourselves home. Along the way we watched fog creep up the cliffs of Big Sur, ate many cheese burgers, drank wine, bought wine, talked about our world and what our presence in it means, not talked, laughed, learned more about ourselves and each other and we rested. It's a gift I don't take lightly -especially these days. With him my voice is louder, my love is deeper and my cheeks hurt from all the laughter. So much love to you babe. Thanks for riding in a car with me for 21 hours and still wanting to do life together

The trust and assurance I have in my body is beautiful. My body cares for me, has served me so well and in return I try and feed it what it needs to do its job. Im not an overly healthy eater in the way our society now views healthy eating (paleo, vegetarian, all whole grains, etc.) and yet vegetables are probably my favorite thing ever (especially when there is cream and cheese involved). I eat white sugar and white flour and currently theres a bag of cool ranch doritos (almost empty) and mint oreo cookies in my cupboard. Everything and I mean EVERYTHING in moderation. Honestly, to me, this is healthy eating. The sort that believes nothing is off limits, no food is evil and any food can be used to bring joy and health to my body. That looks different every day but each day, each meal, each bite is a gift. // Read more on the blog and get the recipe for this seared steak with herb and caper relish.

Im suppose to be sharing a recipe today. Talking about our food and showing pretty pictures of it all. But today I just cant. Ill return to the food because its part of the beauty of life and I want to foster beauty and remind people that in spite of all the hate and ugliness in this world there is also always beauty. But today I cant. Today I need to do more and not ignore what is happening in our world right now. The boys are downstairs. Theres clapping, constant whistling (which is driving me a bit nutty, Ill admit) cheers and joy. They are playing a video game. Upstairs Im scraping off last nights pasta from our plates, scrubbing red sauce off the stove, waiting for my coffee to bubble up and wondering what the hell do I say to my children about the devastation that has happened in the last few days. Families have been broken. Friends have lost friends. Beds will be empty tonight where a warm body should lay. Children wont get the snuggles they so desperately want. Two women are suddenly without their partners. A future they knew that included a teammate has been violently taken from them A dad was killed, his son weeps. My boys are downstairs getting riled up about a missed home run by some pixelated ball player. I want to protect, to shield them from the gross realities of this world. I wonder if they are too young to know how broken this world is? I want them to stay that way. Wouldnt it be nice for them if their hardest part of the day was that their brother didnt give up his turn at the game when he was suppose to? No. I want to raise children who are sickened by a world who sees people as a color. I want our family to collectively stand for love and to be a loud, clear voice that advocates for that. How do I teach them to not see color, sexual orientation, religion, level of education, gender, age, etc. as a way to define, rate, and judge people when the world teaches them otherwise? We can do better, we can do more. We get to show them how to love. We get to teach them to fight hate with love. Thats our job and some days its just really damn hard but NOTHING compared to what some peoples realities are today.
Going out with a bang with this one. If I don't hop on that plane tomorrow you'll all understand why, right @thewestinexcelsiorrome @westin by @gaber008
Please don't make me leave

We've had many misses in restaurants on this trip. When the hunger strikes it strikes hard so we duck into whatever is nearby - which is often not the best. But these are the dinners that winning for us. Gathering a few things here and there throughout the day. It helps when you happen upon a farmers market and grab a wheel of Camembert for less than $5! A rare photo of just me. But this is a special one because of my pants. Seriously. My beautiful friend and sister @deborahb03 made them for me. We worked together to find the right style and then went to @drygoodsdesign to get the fabric and then Deborah worked her magic. I kept my wardrobe rather slim for this three week trip (no joke, @gaber008 and I shared a carry on) but I'd be happy living in these pants for the rest of my life. @deborahb03 your talent amazes me. Thanks for helping me carry a special piece of home with me

Right before we left we kicked off summer and our trip with a ridiculously epic milkshake featuring our Salted Chocolate Chip Cookies and @BaileysUS for the adults. // Mix 4 cups vanilla ice cream with 1/2 cup milk and 1/3-1/2 cup Baileys. Blend until smooth then add in 2 large or 4 small fresh baked chocolate chip cookies. Blend just to break up the cookies. Serve with more cookies, whipped cream and salty sprinkles

So hard to choose. I'm quite proud of my restraint actually - I walked away with three. When I'm overwhelmed with decisions I always ask "What's your favorite?" To the woman @ottolenghi at Spitafields who insisted I take home the cheese cake - thank you.

So proud of these little travelers (and @gaber008 too). We walked over five miles today despite some jet lag sleeping woes last night. Snack often, a park cures most grumbles, plan for sitting breaks, and come home with meat pies and English cheddar.

This lady, she constantly inspires me. @floretflower is incredibly talented but more than that she's generous and always willing to put her heart out there for the sake of inspiring others and helping them on their path. Together we created this taco salad of sorts with arugula dressed in smoked olive oil, ground beef with an accidental heavy hand of chipotle powder, black beans, lime, cotija, pickled jalapeos and sour cream. Big fancy well thought out meal or clean out the fridge taco salad - it doesn't matter, it's the intention that does. Thanks for the lovely date, babe.

I'm having overwhelming FOMO (fear of missing out) as I try to plan out our three weeks in Europe with the kids. Am I planning too much? Too little? Will they love it as much as I do? It's such a ridiculous gift that we get to do this and I'm just trying to breathe that in and let this time be what it wants and needs to be for our little family. Having said all of that I would LOVE any traveling with kids tips or suggestions on what to do while we're in London, Paris, Normandy, Florence, Umbria, and Rome. Only 12 more sleeps!!

Dinner, a few nights back. Simple steak sandwiches: Equal parts butter, blue cheese, and cream cheese whirled together in a food processor, seared flank steak (salted then a good squeeze of lemon juice while it rests) and arugula. Spicy pickled peppers for the adults.

For those of you who tuned into our Facebook live episode yesterday you now know that @mollyorangette and I rely heavily on a can of beans for quick dinners. I thought I'd share tonight's bean doctoring; can of chickpeas (yes, Ivy's worst enemy bean) shaved fennel, herbs (mint, dill, basil), arugula, sharp cheddar, nigella seeds, olive oil, lemon juice, salt and pepper. Platter of cheese, bread and other veg goes with it. A healthy dinner so we can all indulge on popcorn, candy, and ice cream for family movie night. Balance.

For this incredibly visual person over here Instagram has been a source of joy and inspiration (and yes, sometimes envy and self-doubt). I'm determined to not feel anxious in the changes but also want to be sure that I let you know how much it would mean if you would tap on those three dots in the corner and be sure you, I don't even know what you click - maybe it's something like 'see notifications from this person'. Anyways, I don't want to lose any bit of this community with the changes. I'm doing my part by tapping as many hearts as I can in my feed and engaging as much as I can. Thanks for being here! You all brighten each of my days.

Sometimes I think my work is so trivial. I mean, I take pictures of pretty food and try to get you all excited about. Meanwhile there's kids without food, women being treated as objects, millions without clean water, and a political system that leaves you disheartened and so, so, so, at a loss for words. But then there's cake. And honestly, somedays I think it's one of the best things we can do. Find small joys and dig into them deep. Make it a quest in your day to find and celebrate the small beauty because it's really all around us. We just have to go on a hunt to find it and some days the hunt likes to play games with us and make it real hard, but we push in and find the joy. And we eat cake and we share cake and we pick ourselves up and then, when we're ready we can help others find the beauty in their day we do that too. Because we are in this together. One piece of cake at a time. // The recipe for @doriegreenspan's yogurt cake with blood orange caramel on the blog.

Seriously @joythebaker, how did you know this is just what my afternoon needed.?! And @sweetlosicecream I'm in awe of your ice cream skillz. I fancy myself an ice cream aficionado and this is, I'm gonna say it, the BEST! Thank you both for the sweet pick me up.

Last week I soaked up some California vitamin D while sipping on some serious vitamin C. Because the work never stops around here I took it upon myself to devote some of my vacation time to cocktail research. Now I'm back to reveal some of my findings: Squeeze the juice of half of a blood orange into a tumbler. Top with a shot of rum (Plantation 5 year is a favorite around here), crushed ice, soda water, squeeze of lime, bitters (if you've got them) and a cherry (@luxardousa cherries are in my opinion, among the best). Shall we call it the RED RUM spritz?!

Healthy dinners call for a little cake after. This one is an olive oil chocolate loaf with sprinkled with Turbinado sugar. // One of those magical one bowl recipes. Combine 1 1/2 cups flour, 3/4 cup sugar, 1/4 cup cocoa powder, 1 teaspoon baking soda, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1 tablespoon cider vinegar, 6 tablespoons olive oil, 1 teaspoon vanilla extract, 1 cup warm water. Bake in greased loaf pan (350 degrees) for about 45 minutes or until it gently bounces when pressed. Sprinkle with Turbinado before baking for a sweet crunch. So glad I never made one of those silly "no cake" resolutions.

I'm on such a soup kick these days. Today's version is adapted from Richard Olney's book, Simple French Cooking. Squash and Bread Soup. Squash (2 pounds) and garlic (5 cloves) are simmered in salted water (3 1/2 cups) (I also added fresh thyme) and then once tender a few pieces of stale bread are added. Pure until smooth and then drizzle with olive oil, and sprinkle on a bit of Espelette (or other red chile powder) and fresh thyme leaves. So simple, so satisfying.

Vacation food continues with this blackberry skillet cake. And yes, I totally traveled with my cast iron skillet. The cake recipe is Grandma's apple cake from my book and the blackberries are from the bushes outside the house where we're staying. Leftovers made for a delicious breakfast.

And those ribs I mentioned. Three hours at 300 F with a dry rub of smoked paprika, dry mustard, cayenne, garlic powder and salt and pepper. Then finished on the grill with my Muscovado BBQ sauce from my book. Not a clean face in sight.
Tomato salad with lemon cucumbers, red chile, cilantro, olive oil, lemon, and salt. Most everything came from the farmer's market on the island. Went beautifully with our BBQ ribs.

Such a sweet morning with this big kid. I know how important one on one time is for them but it's equally important for me to hang with them on their own. It's then that I get to know who they really are as individuals and can really give them all my attention. When it's just me and the three of them I get so quickly overwhelmed with all their needs ("Mom. Mama. Mommy. Mom." On repeat) and fail to see them as little people but rather a single three headed monster attempting to take me down. This is not on them but speaking as their highly introverted, easily overwhelmed mama. // All of this to say, I will cherish my sweet morning with this one hearing about his idea for a flip-flop that wears more like a shoe, his goal to see all 50 states before he turns 18, and counting crab shells on the beach (52).

Just as she was going to bed she, while bouncing up and down in delight, told me her breakfast plans for the next morning. She calls it Berry Soup. First you put some cut up strawberries in a bowl, then add cherries. Raspberries and blueberries would have gone in too had we had them. Mash them up with whatever utensil you see fit (we used a juicer plunger) then top with softly whipped cream. She and I think you'll love it.

Since teaming up with @frontiercoop for the month of June I've been finding myself reaching for the spice cabinet more often. This morning I'm so glad I did as caraway, poppy seeds and chili flake really stepped up my avocado toast game. The tomato, lemon, salt, and olive oil didn't hurt either

Imagine this alongside your grilled steak. A summer stunner of grilled peaches, grilled scallions and crumbled blue cheese. And because it's me, there's probably some flake salt in there too. Unexpected and freaking delicious.

I've teamed up with @frontiercoop to add a bit more spice to summer and I think we've done just that here. It's a carrot cucumber slaw with Harissa dressing. Peel long strands of a couple carrots and half a cucumber. Add cilantro, mint and scallions then toss with a bit of olive oil, lime juice and dried Harissa. Salt to taste and top with black sesame seeds. Perfect to shimmy up next to something grilled on a plate or to top a sandwich which we did with grilled lamb, pita and feta. Dried herbs and spices give a simple dressing such a flavorful punch. Make a big batch and keep in the fridge for quick meals - the flavor will intensify as it sits because of the dried spice
New home. Old recipe. Fresh raspberry scones are up on the blog
She still climbs into bed with us.

It's pickle season!! These zucchini spears are first soaked in ice water and salt so they stay nice and crisp. After an hour give them a rinse then cover in a hot brine of cider vinegar, a little salt, sugar, mustard seeds, and juniper. Really anything goes but I'm really into juniper with my pickles lately. How do you pickle? @frontiercoop

Thrilled to be partnering with @frontiercoop to ! This month I'm playing with seasonal produce and dried herbs and spices - so pretty much my favorite thing ever. Currently I'm really into these black sesame seeds. They are topping flatbread, adding crunch to salads, garnishing dips and capping ice cream to give it an exotic finish.

More picnic scenes from the other night. Couscous salad with fresh cherries, fried almonds and pomegranate molasses dressing. Grilled vegetables with mint yogurt and spicy grilled chicken with grilled lemon and parsley. And loads of sauces. It's all about the sauces

I love it when I find a vegetable that the kids are just as excited about as I am. We've been going crazy over artichokes lately. This one was drizzled with olive oil, sprinkled with salt, covered in aluminum foil then roasted in a 400 F oven until tender (about 45 minutes). We love dipping the leaves in melted butter or mayonnaise. This dip is mayo laced with horseradish root powder. Slightly spicy, completely delicious. @frontiercoop

Rethinking the classic potato salad: halved boiled baby new potatoes and arugula tossed with olive oil, sherry vinegar and salt and pepper. Topped with toasted dill seed, caraway, and mustard seeds then capped with crispy bacon and its drippings. @frontiercoop

So, it's 5 o'clock (yesterday). The kids are starving and I'm trying to wrap up an article ( @food52 ). They want dinner and the cupboards and fridge are nearly empty and yet somehow dinner emerged: lentils with roasted poblano and pepita pesto-ish dressing. To that I added poached chicken, scallions, parsley and celery. There was also some smoked paprika croutons. These are my favorite dinners.

The moment I saw a picture of a chocolate cake with chocolate frosting I knew today needed cake. No occasion. No real reason. When the butter started softening I was feeling blah; not good enough, comparing myself to others, questioning my work. By the time I had the first bite the day had turned around. Sometimes just the simple act of turning simple ingredients into something indulgent and beautiful is enough but really I think it was the satisfaction of sharing it with others that gave me the greatest joy.

I learned a lot this week. Mostly that starting a new business is exhilarating, exhausting and hard. There are so many little details to get right. So many things that seem so clear and simple and then turn into something complex. Such a good reminder of how imperfect I am and how much I have to learn. Two big things I'm taking away this week; surround yourself with people who are good at the things you are not good at and grace, lots and lots of grace. So I'm taking a step back, eating a lot of mussels and drinking a good bit of beer. It doesn't make it all better nor does it solve the problems but I'm learning and growing and giving myself this grace. The problems will be solved and I'll move on. For now this, a wedding and a weekend away with my forever date, @gaber008. Thanks again for all the support this week. You're the best

From up here it looked like a perfectly formed quilt lay over the earth. As we descended the imperfections started to show; the lines blurred, the colors weren't as brilliant and it looked messy. I want to go back up and see it from above, I thought. But then it hit me: the work happens on the ground. It's messy, imperfect and dirty. I think the trick is to be able to have the perspective as if you're looking down on top of it all while you are in the mess and on the ground. It takes getting above it all to realize there is a method, pattern and plan. I'm always in need of a good dose of perspective.
I wish lunch always came with this view.

Weve officially reached potato salad season here, and Im starting it off with a good one: Aleppo Pepper Potato Salad w/ Garlicky Labneh Basically spicy, crisp-roasted fingerlings sitting on a pool of creamy garlic yogurt, with a few squeezes of lemon juice, a bit of fresh chives, and some flaky salt. Add a glass of wine and youre good to go (Grab the recipe link in my profile )

NEW RECIPESmooth & fluffy, bean-less Horseradish Hummus for a mid-week pick-me-up! Here we used soaked sunflower seeds (in place of chickpeas), and then a few of the usual suspects: tahini paste, a couple cloves of garlic, and lemon juice. To add a savory, full-bodied flavor I added a few tablespoons of fresh Wisconsin grown @silver_spring_foods Prepared Horseradish for a nice little kick, which was such a welcomed addition. I think youre going to love it Peep the recipe below. And heres my promo code for all your @silver_spring_foods needs! Code: LINDSEY20 / RECIPE / - 1 cup raw sunflower seeds, soaked for at least 4 hours, rinsed & drained - 1/2 cup tahini paste - juice from 1 lemon - 3-4 tablespoons Silver Spring Foods Prepared Horseradish - 2 cloves garlic, skins removed - 1 1/2 teaspoons fine salt - Fresh cracked pepper - 1/3-1/2 cup filtered water, to thin / METHOD / 1. Combine the seeds, tahini, lemon juice, 3 tablespoons Silver Spring Foods Prepared Horseradish, garlic, salt, a couple cracks pepper, and 1/3 cup water in the container of a high-speed blender (if you dont have a blender, a food processor will do, but the hummus may not have a silky-smooth texture.) Whiz everything together on high, scraping down the sides of the blender as you go. Add more water, 1 tablespoon at a time if needed to get everything blended and smooth. 2. Once its blended to your desired consistency (I tend to like it on the thinner, silkier side), taste and adjust the salt, and lemon juice, if needed. Add an additional tablespoon of Silver Spring Prepared Horseradish if you like a little more heat. 3. Scrape the hummus into an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 3-4 days. 4. Serve with a sprinkle of zaatar, a swirl of olive oil, a pinch of flaky sea salt, and grilled or toasted gluten-free bread is optional, but very much preferred

A peppy little bev - went something like this: 1/2 grapefruit, juiced. 1/2-inch knob of ginger, grated. 1oz Tequila. (Roughly) 1/3 cup soda/mineral water (@topochicousa is my forever choice). Mix grapefruit juice and ginger together, strain. Pour over ice, then add tequila, top with soda, and enjoy that sucker

In tonights dinner: an enchilada bake aka, my new favorite meal Shredded up some leftover chicken breasts, tossed in some salt & a few spoonfuls of enchilada sauce (love @sietefoods brand) to season it quickly. Sauted red onion & 2 zucchinis with ground cumin, and chili powder. Here are the layers: roughly 1/3 cup enchilada sauce, then tortillas (again, love @sietefoods almond flour tortillas), spread half the filling and a handful of spinach, drizzled more enchilada sauce on top. Continued for another layer, and ended with sauce to cover the tortillas. About 30 mins in the oven, then topped it with sliced avocado, pickled red onions, and cilantro. As long as you have enchilada sauce, and tortillas you can pack whatever fillings you want in between for a super flavorful and happy little meal

Want to make a recipe together tomorrow morning!? Ok, cool I thought we could make a vegan coffee creamer that Ive been making weekly - its got 3 ingredients, nothing weird or fancy, and its something that just makes me really happy and I thought it might make you happy too. Sound good? Ok, heres what you need: - 1/2 cup raw almonds - 1/2 cup raw cashews - 2 tablespoons GF rolled oats - Pinch of salt - 2 cups filtered water - (Optional: monk fruit extract/maple syrup, and/or vanilla extract) - a blender - a nut milk bag or cheesecloth TONIGHT - Cover the almonds & cashews with water, and soak overnight. TOMORROW - In the morning have the remaining ingredients/tools GTG and youll be all set Tune in to my IG Stories around tomorrow, 4/2, at 8am PST (11am out east) and lets make some yummy creamer So excited to cook (blend) together! Let me know if you have any questions so I can answer them ahead of time

Creamy pesto pasta bake . Literally took everything I had laying around to make this: half red onion (roasted in olive oil & balsamic), asparagus & spinach sauted w/ garlic, pesto made creamy with unsweetened coffee creamer (sounds gross, but it does the job in a pinch), lentil pasta, buffalo burrata, salty toasted pignoli nuts, and lots of s&p Moral of the story

Sharing our go-to vinaigrette on today, especially during this time quarantined at home. It makes the most of a lot of pantry items, as well a few kitchen counter staples (shallots/garlic), to make what we call: A Really Good Dressing What we love even more is that it can repurposed for all kinds of meals throughout the week - mixed into cooked lentils, or chickpeas; into pasta for an epic pasta salad. My favorite: tossed into canned tuna for a super tasty tuna salad (Recipe link in my profile) Healthful, happy wishes to you all

Either way you wont be disappointed with these - theyre chocolate-y and crumbly just like a good scone is, theyre also filled with healthy fats (almond flour, coconut milk, etc.!), and they bake up quick and can be enjoyed pretty much right outta the oven - I got you **Recipe link in my profile**

Everything we need, and nothing we dont. Its taken a while for me to shop intentionally and only spend money on what we really need to keep the boys thriving and frank and me nourished. We do a big shop on Sunday morning. Then, while the kids nap, I prep a sauce/dressing, a few easy-to-put-together meal components, bake off some sweet potatoes, and cut some fresh vegetables for snacking. We keep plenty of greens and berries for smoothies/salads, along with a few go-to condiments and were all set for the week. (You can tap the photo for the brands we love, and I also have a fridge tour saved to my highlights if youre interested ) Happy Sunday, all!
Happy 6 months to you Joey You are pure happiness and joy and curiosity rolled up into the sweetest little human. We love you beyond measure

Our definition of Valentine's Day is enjoying a big old pizza pie and a bottle of red , preferably with @robertmondavi Napa Valley Cabernet Sauvignon, to make it an extra special Valentine's Day date-night-in. Jammies on, feet up and a classic movie playing on the TV is how we do these days (and the kids sleeping soundly - hopefully!). This pizza is my go-to (and ) crust, with caramelized shallots, garlicky kale, sauteed baby shiitakes, almond ricotta, pinches of red pepper flakes and flaky sea salt. It's hearty and perfect for this time of year, and it couldn't pair better with a bottle of red

Taking it back to 2015. To our little Brooklyn apartment . I used to shoot everything in our bedroom. We had one small exposure, and I would wait until the right time of day before a shoot. I never knew how lucky I was, the light in New York is moody, and has character. Here in LA its constant (which is nice in its own way), but you have to bend to its rules. Im having a bit of nostalgia (if you cant tell), for work life before babies, and before my life was filled with a wonderful, ping-pongy chaos. Were in the midst of some change and while were working with it, and continuing to have some perspective on things, its been difficult. Sleep deprivation, a toddler whos been requiring more attention, and mine and Franks relationship which seems to be on the back burner. Im finding that the word balance doesnt really exist in my vocabulary, what keeps us grounded is having perspective. Knowing days will get easier, our life together will find its way, and that having peace with the moment were in is what we can choose to focus on (however hard that it at some moments).

Almond Thumbprint Cookies!! This recipe couldnt be easier, and more kid-friendly, they also happen to be and Heres the recipe: 2 1/4 cups almond flour 1/4 cup tapioca starch 1/2 tsp salt 1/4 tsp baking soda 1/2 cup coconut oil 2 tablespoons maple syrup 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract or almond extract Jam, dark chocolate, etc., for filling - In a large bowl, whisk together the dry ingredients. - In a saucepan over low heat, melt the coconut oil with the maple syrup. Remove and let cool. - Mix the wet ingredients, along with the extract, into the dry ingredients until a stiff dough forms. Gather dough into a large round, flat disk. Wrap in plastic wrap and refrigerate for about 45 minutes, until firm. - Preheat oven to 350F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. - Scoop dough using a tablespoon measure, roll into balls and flatten them a bit with your hands. - Place balls on baking sheet, use your thumb to make an imprint, squeezing the dough back together if need be. - Bake for 12-15 minutes, until lightly golden on the edges. If using chocolate, place pieces in the center immediately, if using jam, wait for cookies to cool. Enjoy!!

Prepping some whipped tahini for the week. Ive gotten a lot of questions in the comments in past posts about what all is involved in whipping tahini. And while its pretty basic, its also one of the very best techniques for a super smooth, fluffy, and majorly flavorful tahini. All we do is add tahini, lemon juice, garlic, salt, and water to a food processor and whip away until everything is creamy and smooth. How to use it up throughout the week? Add it to dressings for a creamy consistency, use it as is for a dip, (or my favorite) add your favorite yogurt to it and make a yogurt-y tahini sauce Cant go wrong with this one! (Recipe link in my profile )

I'm always on the lookout for a salad that's fun and flavorful. Whether that's adding caramelized onions, creamy dressings, spiced nuts, or some punchy chopped fruit.While delicious, Caesar salads are drowned in dressing and covered with cheese.So Ive partnered with @wholefoods in the spirit of the the New Year to show you and Ive remixed this classic salad to help you enjoy it in a new and delicious way. I pared down your typical Caesar to still offer all that creamy goodness with a vegan dressing, some gluten-free croutons, and I swapped in shaved brussels sprouts because they're a good source of fiber and hold up in the fridge for a few days. Follow the link in my profile to find more gluten-free options for you to add to your meals Here's the recipe below: RECIPE: Brussels Sprouts Caesar Salad: -2lbs. brussels sprouts, shaved thin on a mandolin or with a sharp knife - drizzle extra virgin olive oil - squeeze lemon juice - fat pinch salt -1 ripe avocado, sliced - gluten-free croutons (optional) - walnuts shaved on a microplane, to garnish (optional) Dressing: -1/2 c Plain Kite Hill Greek-style yogurt -1 tablespoon lemon juice -1 tablespoon apple cider vinegar -1 1/2 tablespoons nutritional yeast -2 teaspoons Dijon mustard -2 teaspoons capers -1 clove garlic, grated on a microplane -Salt & pepper, to taste -1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil 1. Toss shaved brussels sprouts with the olive oil, lemon juice, and salt. Use your hands and mix everything together for about 1 minute. Set aside. 2. Make the dressing. In a food processor fitted with a metal s blade, combine the yogurt, lemon juice, vinegar, nutritional yeast, Dijon, capers, garlic, and salt and pepper to taste. With the machine running drizzle in the cup of olive oil until everything is combined. Remove the lid and check the dressing, if its too thick, add the extra 2 tablespoons of olive oil and combine once again. Taste and adjust salt if needed. 3. To the shaved brussels sprouts, add roughly half the dressing and mix. Taste, and add more dressing and salt if needed. Top w/ sliced avocado, gf croutons & shaved walnuts

Regardless of the season, I always keep cookies on hand. Ive teamed up with @wholefoods to show some of my favorite picks for the New Year and this recipe is one of my all-time go-to options. I particularly like having these almond butter cookies around they're full of fats from almond butter, and they're made with monkfruit sweetener, which can replace added sugars. But they totally fill the 3-4pm void when I need a cookie! Get the recipe for these delicious babes below @wholefoods RECIPE: Almond Butter Cookies: - 1 1/4 cups almond butter - 1/2 cup monkfruit sweetener - 1 large egg - flaky sea salt, for topping 1. Preheat oven to 350F and line a cookie sheet with parchment paper. Set aside. 2. In a large bowl, mix together the almond butter, sweetener, and egg until thoroughly combined. 3. Using a cookie scoop, or by hand, portion the cookie dough into 1 tablespoon balls and place them on your cookie sheet leaving about an inch between each cookie. Using a fork, gently press the cookies cookies down making an imprint. 4. Bake the cookies for 12-14 minutes. Let cool completely before eating.
Our new way to Caesar is an all brussels sprout version. No apologies for loving shaved brussels in 2019 (or ever)

Getting back to the basics with my typical grocery for about 3-4 days.Im teaming up with @wholefoods to show you my favorite staples for the new year. Buying all of our groceries and prepping for an entire week has never worked for us. Instead I buy groceries for 3-4 days. Our schedules inevitably shift and change depending on the week, so this little system actually saves us money and our food never goes bad. Believe it or not, this is what groceries look like around here regardless of what month it is. December looks pretty much the same as January. I make meals that simply make us feel good, and if they dont, then they dont have a place in our home. I love this way of eating - no cleanses, detoxes, or diets when the new year rolls around, just back to the basics that nourish us

Theres still time to make this all vegan cheese board! Grab some crackers, your favorite vegan cheeses, fruit, nuts, compotes/preserves/conserves, and youre good to go! Happiest 2019 to you all! So grateful to share this little corner of the crazy thing that is Instagram with you

(In partnership with @CountryCrock) I'm so excited to share this little video with you! We're making that yummy Christmas morning cake that I teased yesterday. Im using Country Crocks buttery sticks - which I love because theres no need to let them soften - I hope you love it! You can also find the recipe below! From our family to yours, Happy Holidays Cranberry Coffee Crumb Cake - 1 cup brown rice flour - 1/2 cup oat flour - 1 teaspoon baking powder - 1/2 teaspoon baking soda - 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon - 1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg - 1/2 teaspoon fine sea salt - 4 tablespoons unsalted Country Crock baking sticks - 2/3 cup coconut sugar - 2 large eggs - 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract - 1/2 cup dairy-free cultured yogurt - 1 cup whole cranberry sauce Crumb Topping: - 1/2 cup brown rice flour - 1/3 cup old fashioned rolled oats -1/3 cup coconut sugar -1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon -1/8 teaspoon fine sea salt - 4 tablespoons unsalted Country Crock baking sticks Method 1. Preheat oven to 350F, oil an 8-inch springform pan and lime the bottom with parchment, set aside. 2. In a large bowl, whisk together the flours, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt; set aside. 3. In another large bowl, use an electric mixer on low to beat together the butter and sugar, then add the eggs and vanilla. Mix on low until combined. Add 1/3 of the flour mixture and beat on low until combined, then add 1/3 of the yogurt and beat on low until combined. Alternate between the two until fully incorporated. 4. For the crumb topping. Use a fork to whisk together the flour, oats, sugar, cinnamon, and salt. Add the butter and use the back of the fork to mix everything together until crumbly. 5. Pour half the batter into the pan, evenly spread the cranberry sauce over top, then add remaining batter and smooth with a spatula. 6. Distribute the crumb topping evenly. 7. Bake for 60-70 minutes, until a cake tester comes out clean. Remove from the oven and place on a rack to cool completely before removing the sides of the pan and cutting. Dust the top with a bit of powdered sugar before serving. (: @flovephoto )

More of a collection than any conscious prep of sauces. Im lucky to have a few good shops nearby that carry really great sauces/dips/spreads. Case in point: pesto and toum (the smallest jars) from @cookbookmarket . I also supplement throughout the week when I have time/ingredients to make others: fiery green tahini (from @bonappetitmag ), homemade spinach pesto (made with leftover basil and spinach), and tomato, shallot, garlic confit (a combination of @whatscookingoodlooking_ recipe, and @ciaosamin recipe from their respective cookbooks). I add them into whatever were eating: toum and pesto in dressings, frittatas, marinades, etc. Confit goes into pasta, onto pizza, and plopped onto any cooked grain/legume. Its a mish-mosh but gives me an easy start to any of our meals, which is so key especially at the end of the day

) Raise your hand if you have a deep love for California Avocados !? . They've been a staple in my diet for years. I find them to be one of the most versatile foods you can eat. From desserts, to dressings, jazzing up salads, etc., etc.! . But another way I love using avocados is in dip. Yes, I love guacamole just as much as you, but during the height of spring, when everything's so fresh and green, and tasty, I usually take kitchen leftovers from the end of the week and blend them into a creamy, herby dip for the weekend. . This time, I've got some leftover peas, dill, cilantro, lemon juice, salt, EVOO, and of course, @Ca_Avocados are my choice for the tastiest avos. What are you making with avocados these days?

) Real life: wakes up, throws California Avocado into a smoothie . Mid-day lunch: smushes avocado on toast . Supper: slices avo on all the dinner things . But seriously, between morning smoothies, Amesy's lunch, and dinner for Frank and me, we can easily go through 2 @ca_avocados a day. I buy a bunch ahead of time (usually 4-5), and after a couple days in a dark cabinet, or in a brown paper bag, they're nice and ripe! And even though they carry a heavier price tag than most other produce, they are a nutritional mainstay in our diet, and well worth the cost (in my opinion). . Our dining space has doubled as my work space for years now. Anyone else with me? () Its the place I attempt to get meals on the table in hopes of nourishing my family. Its also the place where I attempt to nourish myself; work ideas, plans for the future, thoughts of where I want to be in 5 years - those plans are hatched, and contemplated here, too. Im not the best at making decisions about furniture, weve moved so often in the past 5 years, and every space has demanded something different. But when we moved to LA last year, I made the decision that we were going to really live in our space and make it a home. No more transitional pieces. My first purchase were these @roveconcepts chairs and I havent looked back since. Durable for a messy little toddler, sleek enough for meals around the table, and comfy enough for hours spent sitting and working in them.

Hi guys! I took a (longer than planned) Instagram hiatus the past few days. Between the flu and moving weve just gotten back on our collective feet. Weve moved now 3 times in about 4 years, and while they were necessary, they have left me feeling anxious about waste. Packing materials, boxes thrown in the recycle bin, the excess of personal belongings, and the amount of plastic in our house! Ive felt completely powerless to make a change at times. But @sasha.swerdloff and @thefirstmess got some bloggers together to help spread the word about reducing the use of plastic for Here are some ways Ive been slowly incorporating more reusable resources in my home: 1. Ive purchased reusable cloth bags for produce at the grocery store and farmers market. 2. Ive started making my own nut milk more consistently (almond-macadamia shown above ), instead of using plastic bottled milk from the store. 3. Less takeout!! Frank and I have been a making concerted effort the past couple of months. The amount of packaging that comes with an order is super excessive and wasteful, and its something we can easily do to have less of a footprint. How do you reduce waste in your home

I think I found the key to eating crunchy green salads even in the depths of winter! And it's called: put-some-warm-toasted-cracker-crumbs-on-it! Use your favorite greens- in this case, chicories - peel and slice some grapefruit. Whiz some @GerminalOrganic crackers in your food processor, then toast them with a bit of oil on the stovetop. Then smother your salad - done and done! I used @GerminalOrganic 's ) chickpea & rice crackers - the perfect addition to make salads worthy of eating when you're freezing. Go to the link in my profile to get a 30% discount offer! And catch the recipe below: Dressing: 1 T Mayo 2 tsp Dijon 1 tsp Coconut nectar 2 T white wine vinegar 1/4 c oil Salt & pepper Salad: 1 pound mixed Chicories (radicchio, frise, Treviso, etc.), torn 2 grapefruit, peeled and sliced into thin rounds Half of a small red onion, sliced thin Cracker crumble (recipe below) Toasted sliced almonds Cracker crumble: 1/2 cup Germinal Chickpea cracker crumbs, ground in a food processor or blender 3 T extra virgin olive oil Salt and pepper Method: 1. Whisk together the vinegar, mayo, Dijon, and coconut nectar until combined. Drizzle in the olive oil while whisking until the dressing is mixed emulsified. Season with salt and pepper. Store in a lidded jar in the refrigerator until ready to use. 2. In a large skillet on medium high heat, toss the crumbs and oil, stirring frequently to avoid scorching, until golden brown, about 3 mins. Season with salt and pepper and let cool on a paper towel lined plate. 3. Add the grapefruit rounds and red onion to a bowl with the torn chicories, drizzle the dressing over top and give it all a good toss. Add the warm cracker crumble and toasted almonds, and serve

) Were putting cookies aside (just for today ) to set the stage for this holiday chocolate tart! Its a (raw-ish) Chocolate Coconut Cashew Tart with the most luscious coconut cashew cream filling made from cashews, macadamia nuts, @NatureWayBrands Coconut Oil, some dairy-free chocolate, and a bit of cacao powder. Totally made easy by it being a make-ahead dessert (which Im all about), the filling and tart shell can be made days in advance, and then assembled the day of! Easy-peasy! Heres the recipe: Crust: 3/4 cup gluten free oat flour 1/2 cup almond flour 1/4 cup cacao powder 1/4 teaspoon fine salt 3 tablespoons Natures Way Coconut Oil, melted 3 tablespoons pure maples syrup Filling: 3/4 cup cashews, soaked overnight and rinsed 1/4 cup macadamia nuts, soaked overnight and rinsed 1/4 cup almond milk, room temperature 1/4 cup chopped chocolate (preferably non-dairy), melted 1/4 cup Natures Way Coconut oil, melted 1/4 cup pure maple syrup 2 tablespoons cacao powder 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract Pinch of fine salt 1 cup toasted cashew and macadamia nuts, roughly chopped Instructions: Preheat oven to 350F and grease an 8-inch round tart pan. In a large bowl, whisk together the flours, cacao, and salt until combined. Add in the oil and syrup, and mix together until combined and mixture forms a dough. Press the dough evenly into the bottom and sides of the tart pan with your fingers. Use a fork and prick the dough all over. Bake in the center of your oven for 20-25 minutes, until cooked through. Set aside and let the tart shell cool completely. Make the filling by adding all the ingredients to a blender (preferably high-speed), and whiz on high until the mixture is smooth and creamy, stopping a few times to scrape down the sides. Add the filling and use a small offset spatula or the back of a spoon to evenly spread the filling into the bottom and sides of the tart. Spread the chopped nuts evenly over the top of the tart. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight, or at least 7 hours, until the filling is set and firm. Slice and serve

It doesn't really feel festive until there's a good waft of simmering soup floating through the air. I've made countless winter squash soups, but never with a pumpkin. So this was far overdo. This new favorite is a Coconut-Lime, Pumpkin Soup with a nice amount of coconut flavor thanks to sauting all the aromatics in @NaturesWayBrands Coconut Oil first, which was so key. And I love that the lime cuts through a lot of the sweetness from the pumpkin Recipe here: 1 sugar pie pumpkin (roughly 2 1/2-3 lbs), cut in half 1/4 cup Natures Way Coconut Oil, plus more coating 1 onion, chopped 1 stalk lemongrass, root end trimmed and 2 outer layers discarded 2 cloves garlic, minced 3 cups vegetable broth 1 (14 oz) can light or full fat coconut milk, reserving 1/4 cup for topping Juice from 1 lime, plus a couple of wedges for topping Fine sea salt & freshly ground pepper Chopped cilantro, for garnish Toasted sesame seeds, for garnish 1. Preheat oven to 375F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Coat the cut sides of the pumpkin with coconut oil. Bake the pumpkin cut side down for 50-60 minutes, until tender. Once the pumpkin halve are cool enough to handle, scoop the flesh out and set aside. 2. Meanwhile, heat a large soup pot over medium heat. Once the pot is hot, add the coconut oil, onion, and lemongrass, stirring every few minutes until the onions are soft. Add the garlic and stir, cooking until fragrant, about 1 minute. Stir in the pumpkin, vegetable broth, and coconut milk, turn up the heat to a steady simmer and cook for 30 minutes, stirring every few minutes. 3. Carefully transfer the soup to a blender (preferably high-speed) and blend until smooth. Add it back to your soup pot and add the lime juice, season with salt and pepper. 4. Divide the soup between 4 bowls, top with more coconut milk, chopped cilantro, toasted sesame seeds, and a squeeze of lime juice.

I roasted up some pumpkins from @RalphsGrocery ) and really got into the spirit of things with these pumpkin-y personal pizzas. The pizzas are topped with bit of za'atar oil, some roasted pumpkin and shallots, dollops of vegan mozzarella, toasted pine nuts, and castelvetrano olives (for those of us who like olives ). A seriously tasty combo - maybe one of faves to date! All I did was take one portion of dough (mine was gluten-free), and slice it into 6 pieces. Then sliced and roasted the pumpkin and shallots (about 20 mins @ 400F), mixed za'atar with olive oil and a bit of salt, par-baked the pizzas, then topped them and baked them for another 5 minutes (@ 500F). Ralphs has a great selection of winter squash varieties too, which could totally be used here if pumpkin isn't your thing

As soon as spring hits Im all about small gatherings. The best conversations seem to be discussed around a table set of food. I tend to go a similar route each time: lots of fresh greens, a few different dishes to choose from, some sort of bread for dipping, and a vegetarian-friendly main. The ingredients are always a factor as well, and choosing ethically sourced goods is my common practice. Which is why I celebrate and feed my family with @LuciniItalias non-GMO, organic products. I used theirRustic Tomato Basil organic sauceto dress some zoodles, theirnon-GMO Balsamic with Extra Virgin vinaigrettefor a red leaf and avo salad, and theirPremium Selectextra-virgin olive oil to accompany the bread

I eliminated oats from my diet for the past few weeks but was really craving granola to top my morning smoothies, or to eat as a snack. So I made this grain-free, golden granola. It's a mixture of nuts and seeds, with some cozy @simplyorganicfoods spices! The recipe goes like this: 1 cup raw walnut pieces 1 cup roughly chopped raw almonds 1 cup coconut flakes 1/2 cup raw sunflower seeds 1/2 cup raw pumpkin seeds 2 tablespoons chia seeds 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon 1 teaspoon ground turmeric Pinch of sea salt 1/4 cup coconut nectar 2 tablespoons virgin coconut oil, melted 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract Preheat oven to 325F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. In a large bowl, combine the nuts, coconut, seeds, spices, and salt. In a separate bowl, whisk the coconut nectar, oil, and vanilla. Combine the wet ingredients into the dry and mix until everything is sufficiently wet. Spread out the granola in an even layer onto the baking sheet. Bake for 25-30 minutes, mixing the granola halfway through for even baking

Entertaining has been kept to a minimum around here since its all baby, all the time. Usually you can find some iteration of hummus on our table for friends to nosh on. This past weekend I served hummus and added some fresh ALDI SimplyNature baby spinach to the mix. All I did was blanch 11/2 cups of spinach for 20 seconds then pulsed it in with the hummus to give it a green, Spring-y vibe . I served it with an assortment of beautiful, fresh and roasted veg from @ALDIUSA to just add some flavor and texture. I love how the feel of juicy, crunchy cucumbers play off of the slightly charred cauliflower and Brussels sprouts

Also, @1915organic is hosting a sweepstakes- 1 grand prize winner will receive a chef-catered party for 10 at their home AND a $1915 donation to their local foodbank. Head over to the @1915organic IG page for all the details on how to enter Beet tahini sauce: Whisk together 1/4 cup 1915 beet juice, 3T olive oil, 3T tahini, 1 T fresh lemon juice, 1 minced garlic clove, salt & pepper to taste.

Super on the fly raspberry blueberry crisp. It went a little like this: 500g berries 1/4 c coconut sugar 1/2 T arrowroot powder 1/2 tsp lemon juice Pinch of salt Topping: 3/4 c brown rice flour 1/2 c rolled oats 1/3 c coconut sugar 1/2 tsp baking powder 1/4 tsp salt 5 T soft virgin coconut oil Preheat oven to 375F. Mix fruit with next 4 ingredients. In a separate bowl, whisk everything except coconut oil. Use a fork to mix in oil until clumpy and a bit wet. Sprinkle over top, and bake for 30-35 mins

The weather is getting hot. The fan is back in the kitchen. Summer is here. And Im going to live it.

Another cookbook recipe demo live on my stories (saved in highlights). Today I bring you, The Pandoras Box, an unicorn hybrid between French toast, Japanese shibuya toast and creme brulee! By using a skillet technique (instead of blow torch), Ill show you how to achieve a hardened candy-like caramel crust evenly around all six sides of a cube of toast, which is then hollowed and stuffed with fruits and vanilla custard. Glossy and candied on all surfaces, underneath which is a warm cocoon of stretchy chewy bread contrasted by cold and velvety custard and bursts of fruity juices. But it doesnt have to stop there. Think butter sauteed apple deglazed with rum in the winter, or filled with frozen bananas and ice cream in August. The recipe is on page 51 on my cookbook, The Art of Escapism Cooking. If you dont already have a copy, follow the link in profile to see purchasing options. Cheers

New cookbook demo: Check out my stories for a demo on my speed-folding laminated sticky rice bread cruffin! Without any fancy French croissant folding techniques and all those fussy temperature control and waiting, Ill show you how, with just two foldings and a quick chill, you can achieve this amazingly flaky and buttery layers with stringy and fluffy interiors. Its so crispy on the edges that you can hear them before tasting them. The stories are saved in highlights as well so you can go back to it when self-doubt strikes. The full recipe is from my cookbook, The Art of Escapism Cooking. Follow the link in profile on how to purchase. Hope you enjoy

For those of you who arent clear about the steps on how to flatten the bird (my latest blog recipe on ultra-crispy chicken), Ive uploaded a video tutorial within the post! So check it out if you need some visual guidance. Also check my stories for the the final result. And soon I will be doing another IG story cooking demo on a recipe from my cookbook. So stay tuned.

New recipe. Certainty is elusive at best in this insane reality we all find ourselves in, but at the very least, I can promise you this my friends, that youll never roast another chicken after youve tried this. Armed with a single kitchen shear and a flat skillet, youll show you how to de-scaffold with just a few cuts this hopelessly 3-dimensional animal that fixate on uneven cooking, and turn it into a 2-dimensional disk with an evenly crispy and blistered skin-cap on one side, and slow-cooked succulent meat on the other. Flatten the curve (bird) is now on the blog, link in profile

If youve been following my stories, youd know theres been a lotta bagelling going on. For those who are asking, the recipe is from @blackseedbagels, which I have halved and makes six bagels instead of twelve. I made my own toppings this time, with chopped apricot kernels, poppy seeds, and tricolor quinoa. I like. A lot. You can find the recipe following the link in my profile.

Time for another episode of . Congee, the ramen of rice, where versatility is its strength and strange ideas are welcomed. First make a base of fragrant oil by frying a few sliced shallots until crispy and caramelized. Remove the shallots with a slotted spoon then fry two handfuls of ground pork, pre-seasoned with fish sauce and cornstarch, until crumbled and crispy on the edges smelling like a glorious morning. Add the fried shallots back in and raise it with equal amount of thinly julienne ginger, and a couple cups of cooked short grain rice. Now add enough chicken stock to flood all the ingredients but reserve the option to readjust. Remember you can always add but you cant take away. Season with more fish sauce and good amount of black pepper, then simmer until the rice is soft but not dissolved. For more textural contrast, kindly consider Korean sliced sticky rice cakes to enter the scene towards the end. Readjust with more chicken stock to your liking. A very delicious case can be made for a consistency that is still soupy and not overly thickened. For toppings, boneless mackerels that are heavily seasoned with salt and white pepper and coated with potato starch, are fried until charred and blistered spots appear on both sides then flaked by forks and scattered on top of the congee. The crunch and sturdy oceanic profile brings not only contrast but excitements. Speaking of which, a touch of acidity like chopped pickled chilis along with their pickling juice would be an unforgivable crime if overlooked. That green youre seeing is hand-torn mint. But Im not gonna tell you where to stop

Tried my hands on making bagels the first time and Id say it turned out, all things considered, pretty pretty pretty good. The recipe is from @blackseedbagels, which is super simple and easy to follow, and amateur baker-proof. Ive included the link so just follow the link in profile if youre up for it. I only had sesame seeds and sunflowers seeds on hand which turned out to be a great combo, for your consideration

Hello strangers, this is me, someone who's never been comfortable being in front of cameras, let alone talking to one (swipe for outtakes). But hey, I guess strange times call for even stranger actions. And that is why this Saturday April 4th, at 10 am EST, me and @emma_louise_sophia have decided to make two fools of ourselves and go on Instagram LIVE to make a couple recipes from my cookbook . It'll be, I'm afraid, dangerously chatty as two of the most verbally diarrhetic commentators (or one, as I'll speak for myself only) converse in the only public area allowed to gather, the internet. Go to @emma_louise_sophias page to see what she'll be making. And as for me, it's going to be Crackling Pancake with Caramel-clustered Blueberries on page 68, except I'm going to do bananas instead of blueberries (something more easily accessible these days?). Swipe to see the ingredients list, and I'll see you on this Sat at 10 am EST (that's 10 pm for me in Hong Kong

Pork shoulder, or confusingly aka pork butt, has long been an underutilized yet perfectly adequate steak candidate. When cooked to a medium~medium-well doneness, it is juicy, fatty and succulent, made even more special when paired with a light toasted sesame oil and egg yolk emulsion. The recipe, plus a few words for the citizen of earth, is now on the blog. Link in profile

Hong Kong has temporarily banned the selling of alcohol due to the second wave of new cases coming from overseas, but after roughly two months into this, theres definitely a sense of nearing the final trimester in the air. Hang in there.

I read something that the price for beef and chicken in the US has soared due to the recent outbreak, whereas the price of pork has gone down? Well, lucky us then. Ive been making pork-centric recipes like this white ragu. I brown one pound of fatty ground pork in a wide pan with olive oil and fish sauce. Then I add about a couple cups of chopped mirepoix (onion + carrots + celery + garlic) and fresh bay leaves plus 1/2 tsp ground fennel and lots of ground black pepper, sweat them, and deglaze the pan with one cup of whole milk. Once the milk has cooked down completely and starts to brown and caramelize on the sides and bottom, I add another cup. Repeat until three cups of milk are cooked down, and finally I add the last cup and 1/4 cup plain yogurt and cook just until thickened. Toss this white ragu with 500 grams of your favorite pasta and serve with lots of pecorino, and extra dusting of ground fennel

New recipe. For the first time in the history of inadequate amateur bakers (this woman), I've formulated a bread recipe completely from scratch. And I did it without choice in the name of the greatest sandwich shop in the world, @allanticovinaiofirenze from Florence. Their Florentine flatbread, aka schiacciata, is the unsung hero in their expanding sandwich empire. And for far too long, it had endured the insult of imposter recipes that are all, more often than not, just fucking focaccia. Enough is enough. This schiacciata recipe has higher-than-usual hydration ratio of 85%, which kneads into a gorgeously glossy and almost fluid blob of a dough that spreads willingly, and yields elastic translucent crumbs and a terrain of air bubbles. The unconventional inclusion of a little bit of buckwheat flour and yogurt gives it depth of flavor and textures that you'll never have to look for another Italian sandwich bread recipe after this. The recipe for Florence-style schiacciatta is on the blog now. Follow link in profile

. Grilled whole fish. One of the most elegantly simple way to serve seafoods, yet so intimidating and easy to fuck up. Too much conoodling on the grill or in the oven, the delicate flesh loses its supple reason to be desired. Leaving the party too early, the pale skin deters appetite. But really, the perfect grilled whole fish is fuss-free and foolproof. Whether its branzino, sea bass or snapper, have it thoroughly scaled and gutted, cleaned and pat dry. Rub the fish inside out with appropriate amount of sea salt and ground white pepper, then let it slightly cure if you will, on a baking rack for one hour in the fridge. A process, often overlooked, that reduces excess liquid thus tightening and enhancing the texture of the flesh. Now pat the fish dry again, and reward its patience with a gentle rub of extra virgin olive oil on its skin and its cavity filled with your favorite herbs and couple slices of lemon. Place the fish on a baking rack set atop a baking sheet; the circulation of air is key. Now place it all into a cold oven. Yes, cold oven. Close and set to preheat on 300 F/150C. Strange, yes, but not really, when you realize that this method allows the delicate fish to slowly warm up, evenly and thoroughly, to reach its optimal doneness with minimal risk of overcooking in such low temperature. Once the oven finishes preheating, odds are the fish is also perfectly done. Relax because you can always check to see if the flesh easily separates from the bone. If not, back in the oven for another 10, 15 minutes or so. Regarding the crispy aspiration of the skin, this is where the fun part begins. Hover a blow-torch in a generous distance to the skin with a circular motion, and watch, in glee, the surface slowly blisters, hisses, cracks and crisps up to a beautifully charred landscape. Dont forget the other side, too. Serve immediately with wedges of lime and garlic thyme infused olive oil

Made this without aim a couple weeks ago and it turned out to be my new favorite winter dish. Crispy-browned chickens lightly simmered in a Thai-style coconut broth that is borderline too sour, borderline too spicy, and borderline too salty, but only borderline because I couldnt stop drinking it as its amazing aroma and punching flavors sits at the spearhead of all the sensations my tastebuds could handle. Chicken in hot and sour coconut broth is on the blog now

After taking a short break from taking a long break, Im finally rejoining the rest of the world with another episode of . Spaghetti with tomato sauce is the oldest thing on the menu, yet, it can still be exciting with a twist. Whatever recipe of tomato sauce that you dug up from your ancestors grave should work fine, but I make mine with simply olive oil, garlic, fresh thyme, but most importantly, seasoned with fish sauce with a good pinch of sugar. I reduce it down by 1/2 because thick tomato sauces agree with me. Then in another small pot, I shave 5 cloves of garlic using a truffle shaver and performed the same task with equal amount of pitted green olives, welcoming the irregular shapes and broken pieces as they add a rustic character to an intuitive homey dish. Two fillets of anchovies and enough extra virgin olive oil to flood all the ingredients later, I set the small pot over medium heat and fry until the garlics and olives become shriveled and slightly browned. I immediately transfer everything into a bowl to escape the possibility of over-browning, and added a pinch of chili flakes to celebrate. Let your spaghetti that is still slightly under-cooked finish cooking inside the tomato sauce, allow proper introduction and chemistry between the two before pushing them onto the stage. Then spoon the garlic-olive oil over the top, salty crispy and all that, and a few opened fresh cherry tomatoes with flakey sea salt to add juice and coolness. Grated parmesan cheese, dont forget that. All the Cooking Out Loud series are saved in the blog, under the main menu Cooking Out Loud

I feel really embarrassed that Im saying this but nonetheless I feel its too important to ignore. We have found a typo in the recipe in my cookbook, The Art of Escapism cooking, for Magic 15-seconds scrambled eggs. In the ingredients list where it says 1 1/2 teaspoon of cornstarch, should be 1 1/2 TABLESPOON of cornstarch. If you have made this recipe and it didnt turn out as promised, I sincerely apologize. The correction has been made in the ebook version and second prints. This is one of my favorite recipe in the book and I would hate to see anybody attempting it and missing the mark because of my fault. So sorry again. And hope you have a great weekend

The water-based miso congee is clean yet flavorful, and jolting with excitements from the luscious mouthfeel of the herbaceous oil and cool sweetness of cream, with sporadical brightness and pain from tangy pickled shallots and birds eye chilis. Its a hug and a spank at the same time, perfect for my current state of mind. The recipe is now on the blog. Link in profile

Being an Asian kid growing up in a family with hereditary festivity-indifferences, Im even-more-so fascinated with the annual ritual of holiday decorations around times. But it also means that without the guidance of family traditions, the embarkment of this massive endeavor had always felt daunting. And thus never really took place. Since the beginning when I set out to write my first cookbook, I sort of came to terms that it wouldnt exactly fit into the mainstream cookbook market which seems to demand a never-ending genre of 30-minutes or 5-ingredients meals, best if came with a free baby sitter. Not that theres anything wrong with that, but it was never what tickled me to go into the kitchen. My cookbook, with all its unsolicited opinions, bitter humor, and obsession-driven recipes that demands a mutual engagement like sex-addicts with porn, would probably only appeal to the sliver of fellow kitchen escapists to whom cooking is always about chasing a high. So in all honesty, I didnt write it with sales number in mind. If anything I only hoped that it would be recognized as a good read. Not just a cookbook, but a book merited of your emotions, worthy of the company of your armchairs. Or fine toiletries, no less. So thank you @nytimes, for doing just that by including my book - The Art of Escapism Cooking - in their selected holiday books section. I was never one whos comfortable with self-recognition. But today, I think Ill allow it this instance. And thank you, the rest of you, for all your support along the way. If you havent already, please pick up a copy for yourself, or your friends and families. I would be honored to be part of your holiday season, even if on pages only. (In photo: Fast and furious carbonara, in Chapter The Shit I Eat When Im By Myself) To purchase, follow link in profile

Nothing about the following three words together - scallion popover smore - makes any sense. Scallions and marshmallows? Have I gone mad?! But listen, inspired by a popular Taiwanese sandwich cracker, this recipe is going to change everything you think you know about, well, everything. This unlikely pairing, in the most incredible way possible, will open up a corner of your taste buds that you didnt even know exist. The salty, crispy-edged and fluffy-centered popover oozing with the aroma of scallions through its pores, somehow against all logics, clashes almost musically with the slightly bitter and buttery candy-ness of the burnt marshmallows in perfect unison. Its so bizarre, so absurd, yet so undeniably addictive. The paradox of scallion popover smore, is now on the blog. Link in profile. Make it for your holiday parties this season and you wont be sorry

Those of us who seek mental stabilities in the process of cooking know all too well what an unexpected recipe-flop could do to our wobbly Jenga state of mind. Today, I will disclose one just as such. This, was one of my cookbook flops. In the world where everything goes my way, it would have been called something along the line of Philly Cheesesteak Taco. But in this world where I actually exist, let me just say, if you dont already know, that Cheese Whiz is not a substance intended by mother nature, and even further away from simply melting cheddars in bchamel sauce. Any attempt to do so at home will end in an emergency therapist session or binging on day-old donuts. Wish I had known. For any other cookbook recipes that did not suffer such gruesome death, The Art of Escapism Cooking is now out on book stands. Get your copy now

I know what youre all thinking. Youre thinking, isnt this just an undercooked cheesecake, a mistake? No. No it is not. Is soft-boiled egg a mistake? Well exactly. This is the Japaneses answer to the Basque burnt cheesecake. It is served in the state between frozen and chilled, with an outer margin that is rich yet airy, while the center remains creamy and gooey, melting instantly around the heat of your tongue. It has the flavor complexity of a caramel flan, and is possibly the easiest cheesecake, perhaps the only cheesecake, youll ever bake for the rest of your life. The recipe for Japanese melty icebox cheese is on the blog now

The second installment in my BOOK BAIT recipe series: Squid Ink Ramen. Think of it as, as I tenderly do, a jet black bowl of slurpable crude oil but in the most edible and delicious way, using a paste made from squid ink built on the backs of the mighty pokiness of guanciale as its foundation, plus other indisputable toppings such as the long-braised charsiu warmed with star anise and cinnamon, the jam-like egg, the fried garlic powder and a house-blend of chili powder called helldust (yes! check previous post to win a sweepstake of helldust!). But no supporting role could carry a bowl of ramen without its core, the mother, the dame, the matriarch that is the emulsified thus milk-like bone broth to bind them all in a harmonious lagoon, and an umami-packed ramen seasoning harvested from natural ingredients to bring it all to life. And for that, well, youll have to buy the book. Thats life. Recipe on the blog now, and book ready for pre-order. All links in profile

There is only one month left until the publishing date for our cookbook, The Art of Escapism Cooking, on Oct 15! Today we are announcing a sweepstake to win a jar of one of the recipes in the cookbook called , a fiery dust-storm consisting of toasted ghost peppers (or Korean chili flakes for beginners) and six other strongly aromatic substances that will engulf anything that it touches - from pizza, noodle, salads, roast meats, grilled vegetables and etc - in a delirious, nutty, spiced up and chili-induced high. In an utterly self-serving campaign to entice anyone who hasnt already to pre-order our upcoming cookbook, Im launching a new recipe series I would like to call, The Book Baits. Essentially, they are brand new recipes that are NOT in the book, but will need a crucial component from the book to be completed which, as you spit, yes, wont be out until Oct 15. Yes again. The first recipe in this new series is, The Hulk, dry-fried green hot wings that uses fried chili verde sauce (in the book) as its base, and several other green herbs to bring a grassy, fragrant and complex flavor profile to this painfully pleasurable party. Within its smooth and creamy texture, the sauce delivers a forceful, savory and mouthwatering pepperiness, with just enough punishing heat for your naughty needs, and did I mention, the extra-browns browned butter that is poured on at the end because really, what are hot wings without butter? Recipe is on the blog now. Link in profile

What a summer it had been, dappled in homemade ice creams, ripen mangos, seafoods on crushed ice, the rugged mountains of the Scottish Highland and the secret courtyards in Paris. But it was anything but a summer of innocence. Because it was also a summer of great unease, of personal revelation, beholding, self-reflection and reckoning. As foolish of a hope it may be - as all the great ones are - I hope that this hot, sticky, bloody and teary summer, will trickle down into history as the birthday of great change

In a debate, the participants who feel innately that they do not stand on the ground of reasons, will most likely default to personal insults as an armor for their anxiety. It is the ultimate tell of someone losing their argument. Im not saying this to upset anyone. Im simply saying this because I want to bring to light for the commenters who were angered by my last post, that the fact they are able to criticize in this space is a direct result of the very thing that they are criticizing against. That the right of saying what they said in the place where they said it, is the fruit of the fundamental values of democracy. To say democracy is not valid is to say that their comments are not valid, and hence saying nothing. Those who screamed against the desire for democracy in their comments, are already practicing democracy without knowing. So welcome. You are already one of us. But democracy only works on the ground of - amongst other things - freedom of information and speech. And a well-informed speech can only be constructed and effectively delivered through facts, reasons, and the willingness to understand, sometimes even empathize with the opposition argument. So practice it. If you are already on Instagram, then it means you are treading beyond the firewall of censored internet in China, meaning that you already wanting more, that you have access to Google, to more than one side of the history, to the free-ranging vastness of informations, knowledge, philosophies and perspectives, the wilderness of forming your own thoughts, as scary as it is, as far as the willingness of your mind will take you. So go search, absorb, struggle, evolve, and form your opinion with this powerful tool that is outlawed by the system that you are currently defending. Be smart, be civil, convince me! And as you are doing it, know that, hey, that good feeling that you are experiencing right now, that is what the Hong Kong people are fighting for for the next generations to come #

I wasnt born in Hong Kong. Im not a Hong Konger. For the short four years that Ive lived here, Im not even eligible for permanent residency. I was born in Taiwan. A country where the gift of democracy has been pre-paid for, by many generations before me, by strangers in the distant past who have laid down their lives so I, and you, and all the ambiguous individual far far into the unknown future, could maybe, maybe have a say, a voice, a vote in the system that none of us can choose to be born into. Its a birthright that many of us have taken for granted, that many of us are too fortunate to have forgotten, that democracy had never come without a price. If you havent already heard, Hong Kong has been, for the past few months, in a uprising and sometimes violent battle for democracy against the authoritarian central government of China. They call it, the revolution of their time. A seemingly hopeless dignity. I dont know what will happen, nobody does, but I can only wish that whatever voice I am granted with in this world of social media, could help their voice be heard from a little bit further. Because I believe that authoritarianism only looks strong but is truthfully fragile. That once there is a crack, anything is possible. Share if you agree #

Its one of the recipes in our cookbook, The Art of Escapism Cooking - A survival story, which will be officially published in less than two months! Asian or Western, skinny or fat, wheat or rice, soup or dry, you name it, including a few that pays tribute to the ever-adaptive art of Japanese ramen. All the ramen recipes in this cookbook is tori paitan based, the chicken-equivalent of tonkotsu (pork broth) ramen where the broth has been through such intense boiling that the fat and protein has emulsified to be become milky and opaque, such as in this photo.
