Today Im remaking, or improving if I may, one of Edinburghs legendary ice cream shop @marysmilkbars unique ice cream flavors, one that was called goat cheese and honey. The original version was a smooth blended ice cream with a faint, almost undetectable goat cheese presence. But here, I introduced the goat cheese as frozen bits of surprises that are scattered throughout a dense, almost chewy cream base, creating appropriate bursts of untimed and irregular mild saltiness and cheesy aroma that is mellowed and balanced excellently by the sweetness, and further smoothed out by tangy and floral compote of black cherries and honey. Recipe on the blog now. Link in profile

. In this oppressive heat and humidity that seems to stretch on like a blanket of warm rubber on the skin, my mind is thirsting for meals that cools more than fills. And that brings us to seafood platters. More so than any other dishes I think, seafood platters are exceedingly cheaper and equally delicious to make at home than to order in restaurants. Seek out not the fanciest, but the freshest, most in season, ready in abundance variety that will thus excel in both taste and market price, such as these abalones, fresh water snails and shrimps all flirtatiously alive and twirling at the market today. I had one job and one job only, and that is not to fuck them up by overcooking. Bring pots of heavily salted water to a bare simmer, bare simmer!, and as many pots of water as the number of seafoods on hand so the flavors and impurities do not muddle with one another. After washing each type of seafoods, transfer them into each pots of barely simmering water, and poach them at such maintained, low temperature. The water should never boil, never!, so dont you fucking dare, and the cooking time will depend on the type and sizes of the seafoods, but as a rule of thumb, between 1 (raw) and 10 (fully cooked), I always aim for an 8, the state of supple plumpness with the assurance of faint translucency. Once ready, transfer them into a large bowl of iced water to chill completely. For abalones, take them off of their shells and remove the inner guts, then place them back for pretty sake. Serve over a platter of crushed ice. For condiments, I recommend mixing a big dollop of mayonnaise, Greek yogurt and Japanese mentaiko (cured spicy roe), small dollop of Dijon mustard, grated garlic and freshly ground black pepper. Something cold and refreshing to quench on the side, and my friends, summer is dealt with

. Preparation for small, delicate fishes like sardines, for far too long, have been subject to thoughtlessness and negligence, an insult on their sacrifices in extraordinary numbers to be on our dinner tables. Often times thrown on a grill in neglect where their slender build torn and overcook while their scales are left on the skins to frustrate whatever little excitement that is left. Look, small fishes will not accept your repentance of a lemon wedge, no more. First, scale them, however small and tedious they are, pay them the same respect taken as a given by any other fishes, scale them. Then clean them well, inside out, and salt them well, inside out no less. Then think, think about how the desire for a perfectly cooked, supple flesh as well as the charring of the skins can be achieved on a thinness this delicate? Warm, not scorch, but warm a few tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil in a non-stick skillet over medium-low heat. Gently arrange the fishes in the skillet before scattering a couple cloves of thinly sliced garlics and red chilis around and about. The skins should not brown, the garlics should not brown, nothing is allowed the aggression of browning at this point, almost poaching instead of frying, tenderly cook each side of the fish for about a minute only. Gently transfer the fishes onto a baking sheet, then with a blow-torch, blister and char the millimeter depth across the entire surface of each fish, on both sides, bringing the breath of the grill without the risk of overcooking. Reheat the skillet on medium-high heat and cook until the garlic slices are crispy, then add about 1/2 of a lemon zest and more dousing of extra virgin olive oil, brightening it back up. Spoon the oil mixture over the fishes, and serve warm or room-temperature, with your hands only. Now you may talk about lemon wedges

A disk pie, also called a couples pie, or The State of the Union Pie, or a valentines pie if you want to be really gross, is basically 1/3 (or 1/2, no judgement) portion of a regular pie made into a flat disk shape, and designed to be shared intimately with your better half on the same plate. Because, really, there is no better bonding activities to be had between partners and it will save you a lot of money on couple therapy bills. It is especially fun to throw a couples pie gathering for a couple of your couple friends, because it just feels really good to see your guy (or girl) saving the best corner of the crust or the last spoon of ice cream for you when the other didnt. And thats how you know the sated of your union is strong. Smile, and carry on. This is made from my blueberry and sichuan peppercorn oatmeal pie in the blogs archive, link in profile

. Continuing on this stream where I write recipes as intuitively as how I actually cook. You drain two cans of cannellini beans into a colander where you can rinse away the starchy solution under cold running water. Shake off any excess water with absolute resolve because you cant shake the fear that every single drop of water remaining is a drop of flavor that gets diluted, and youre not wrong. Reserve a small handful of beans in a bowl for topping, then usher the rest into a blender, along with a good pinch of freshly ground black pepper and a couple cloves of roasted garlic, or a fresh one, if you welcome the rush. Now, dont salt. No salt. Think fermented tofu, which is what I used, or feta, or something that is intensely savory, creamy and appropriately funky all at the same time to salt the dish. Whatever it is, use the appropriate amount to sufficiently season. Let the blender on high, and as it twirls away, slowly drizzle in just just juuust enough heavy cream until the mixture loosens into a thick, smooth, silky paste. Tilt the blender to help it along, but resist adding too much cream. This is not soup. Transfer into a bowl, then into the fridge to get it aaabsolutely chilled. Freezer if youre in a hurry. Why? You dont know. Because its melting outside and your face wants to be on ice. Perhaps this fixation will wonder as winter comes but for now, you want it cold cold cold. Meanwhile, in a small pot over medium heat, fry a clove of thinly sliced garlic, a handful of chopped cilantro, a pinch of chili flakes, another pinch of pepper inside enough oil to flood them, until the cilantro has lost all its moisture and becomes crispy. Pour the mixture over the reserved beans,with a pinch of salt, mix, then usher them into the freezer as well to chill. Serve the dip and the topping with saltn vinegar potato chips, because they spank and slap and crunch, on a chilled plate no less because you couldnt help yourself to want to be on razor point

Trying my hands on curing Taiwanese-style green plum. Legend has it that it has to be crystalized rock sugar. Legend has it that the salt:sugar ratio is a closely guarded secret of all the houses that carry this practice. Legend has it that a crisp bite of its crunchy, grass-green flesh will cut through the densest fatigue of your summer grilling meat-iesta like a samurai sword. Well, we will see about that

. Heres how I would write recipes if its documented as intuitively as I actually cook. Cut 1/2 a butternut squash in quarters lengthwise, leaving the beauty of the seedy chamber intact. Place inside a baking sheet with a handful of cracked birds eye chilis and garlic cloves, then rub evenly with extra virgin olive oil, fine sea salt and fresh black pepper. Let roast in a preheated 400F/200C oven, fan-on, until the edges of the squash are shriveled, caramelized, and the flesh is fork-tender. If you fancy more definition of brownness, a blow-torch is always ready. Remove all the skins from the garlics and place inside a mortar along with about 3 roasted birds eye chilis, more if you dare, then add a couple anchovy fillets, pinch of pickled green peppercorns, and mash into a smooth paste before flooding it generously with extra virgin olive oil. Serve the sauce with the roasted butternut squash with soft boiled eggs and a few hand-torn mint leaves

Anyone who knows me, knows that I dont drink. Psychologically, gastronomically and physically, I have yet to find any reason to do so, just like smoking. But in just 10 hours, I will be dragged onto a week-long whiskey tour to the mecca Scotland, by none but my husband who, since puberty, has had a irrational infatuation with this nonsensical practice. If I were to gather all the whiskeys he has in our apartment, it wouldnt even fit on this table. And apparently, that is still not enough. So yes, there will be kicking, there will be screaming, and the only hope that I have to remember Scotland other than the country where I was stuck with roomfuls of word-slurring, pupil-dilating middle aged men, is the the one good eat that is going to make it all semi-okay. So please, if you know of such redeemer, spill it in the comment.

My first non-recipe, a guideline of steps for an anxiety-free taco meat recipe and tortillas made from the very drippings. The recipe can be adapted to a variety of different proteins and marinate, but in this case, its bone-in beef short ribs marinated in red wine and onion puree. I certainly dont need to explain to you what happens when a well-marinated fatty cut is brought down to its sticky and gelatinous collapse inside an extremely low oven overnight, then the fat rendered from its very self is again reincarnated into a beautiful stack of tortilla that is then used to wrap itself back and send it into your mouth. I absolutely dont. Recipe on the blog now

I started collecting tablewares, kitchen things I consider beautiful when I started the blog back in 2012, and later on, learnt that theres a word for them called props. But I dont really like the word props. It suggests fakery. And that this is all just a set up. Maybe to a certain compositional photography extent its true. But I dont keep any pots other than these pots, any cutleries other than these cutleries, any ceramics other than these ceramics. I eat and live in them. When I look out for these things, Im not thinking about shooting a photograph, Im thinking about making a life. And life is very short. So live out every mundane moment in exquisiteness, whatever that is for you

I didnt include the ravioli recipe in my latest extra-browns browned butter post (psst, add milk), but I think it merits a mention after having it again for lunch today. Together with this ultra-intense and salty browned butter, it was another level. Thing is, I argue, that Chinese dumpling wrapper makes a better ravioli. Use whatever Italian fillings to make it as Italian as your conscience demands, but Chinese dumpling wrappers are chewier, silkier, and gods forbid, much more convenient when store-bought. In fact, some French versions of ravioli already adapts to a similar dough (essentially eggless). The filling I used here is about 1 cup ground pork, 1/2 cup chopped shrimp, 2 grated shallots, 1/4 cup breadcrumbs, 3 tbsp whole milk, and fish sauce and ground black pepper to season. I was going to lay a leaf of sage on top of the filling so it will glow through the translucent skin after cooking, but I forgot. Dont make the same mistake

Just add extra milk. Can you believe it? It is Brown butter 2.0, accompanied by twenty-times the amount of browned bits, salty browned bits, which pushes browned butters nutty sweet aroma to the point of outbreak. Youve never known browned butter this way, and will never know it any other way from this point on. I call it, the extra browns. Recipe on the blog now

, aka, Moroccan thousand holes pancake. I think, it pretty much explains itself. A recipe that was taught to me by Majda, the cook in the Marrakech riad where we stayed, whose foods I only felt privileged to have eaten. These yeasted pancakes are chewy, light and absorbent, like a bouncy sponge that particularly delights in the company of salted butter (It has to be salted butter, urgently reminded by the riad manager) and honey. Bring Majda into your kitchen, too. After this you might have to go to Marrakech to learn every other magical dishes she knows to cook. Recipe now on the blog

House plants and I, had never been in agreement. For reason I cannot fathom, they have always unanimously chosen death over my company. So for the past few years, I have all given up on forming a partnership, for their sake and also mine. But if theres anything true about humanity, is that it just couldnt help itself from repeating toxic histories. So please, meet my new victims, two bushes of European rosemary and English thyme, all too young and innocent in their formative years to die in the hands of a womens relentless perseverance. May gods help them.

There I was, a fool, thinking lime-plastering the entire apartment by myself would be no grander than my compulsive determination. Two morning shoulder spasms and a right hand that automatically goes numb during the sleep-later, I ultimately realized, I was a fucking fool. The sheer muscle strength and pressured needed to pull the plaster thinly across the wall, over and over again, in multiple different directions in order to get the right result, is no walk in the park for the mind and body, of even the most obsessive ones. Two weeks had gone by and by the most generous estimation, the apartment is about 1/3 done. I dont even know if I would have an arm left to tend the keyboard after this. If I were to be washed away like a whisper in the wind since this day forward, let them say that Mandy of House Lee, last of her name, mother of dogs, the caretaker of her keep, was defeated by the clay from the west, and shall rest her soul knowing the best was done

As the immensity and reality of plastering the whole apartment starts to set in like a looming Monday, the kitchen is at least, well, 99% there. Its still highly possible that we will repaint it with just a shade-lighter green, but for now, for all its worth, its kitchen. Will keep you guys posted as we go

Best food nourishes the soul and quiets a busy mind like relaxing a muscle. One of the best thing about a new neighborhood is peeling through all the nearby restaurants like theyre layers of an onion. It makes you cry, sometimes in a bad way, for sure. But in the case of Tai Hang, a little nook nestled in between Causeway bay and Tin Hou, they are often times tears of joy. Half Cantonese roast goose for 20 bucks only, where the concept of juice runs in the form of salty yet mildly sweetened goose grease, is certainly one of those moments

As of tomorrow at 9:30 am, this self-inflicted suffering that is the re-re-renovation of our apartment which will last 3.5 months long (fingers crossed), will officially kickstart. I will be documenting the entire process from start to finish on my story under highlight: LIVE Home Remodel. We are going to move years of physical and emotional shits out of our current apartment and into a storage, then bring the bare minimal necessities for survival into the temporary apartment, then absolutely knock the shit down of everything in our current apartment, and basically pray to the mighty god of constructions that things dont go awry for the next several months Should things go awry? Lets see. Ive hired a contractor off of the internet on an APP with zero references (because the first hung up on me cuz he thinks im crazy ha! wtf.). The entire project is going to be purely based on verbal communications with no drawings whatsoever. Im basically winging every single phases, determine every single measurements, materials and colors as I go. Best of yet, we will be stuck in a much smaller apartment with even smaller kitchen and even less natural lights, with three dogs, two of whom are both basically Lindsay Lohan on her good days. What could go wrong? Well follow our stories to find out. Hahaha..haha.hahaaaaaaaahuh..huh

What does one do immediately upon arrival of Paris? Hunting and Gathering

Tomorrow we pack our bags and head to Paris for a week then Marrakech for our holiday vacation. And thus sesame and SRB have begun their boarding/training which means living with a trusted dog trainer and his 20-plus pack of dogs for more than three weeks. We miss them so much that I wanna cry, but we also believe that this is the right thing for them, to be properly socialized with a stable group of dogs under supervision. We receive several videos a day documenting their progress, and today, for the first time in her life, SRB (in this photo) had her first playish (albeit nervous) interaction with another dog whos not Sesame or Shrimpy. its the best holiday gift I could ever wish for.

It seems, as scientific data suggests, that human beings give everything they got to curb all their immediate urges for fat-ingestion throughout the year only so that they could unleash the sum of its force all at once in a single, particular, annual event. If this behavioral distinction is what had aided the species to beat the curve and land at the top of the evolutionary food-chain, then well, this Christmas let me introduce you to, The Crazy Rich Asian Panettone. Lubed up with 12 egg yolks, coconut milk and an ungodly amount of butter and unrefined coconut oil, this fat-bomb (comes in both large or grenade-size) will not let your fat cells down. Its indecent amount of fat not only keeps the crumbs sinfully moist, but it serves as an aromatic, coconuty backdrop where speckles of dried mango and persimmons pops with a tinge of orange zest. It will enrich you and your family during the holiday season, as well as a gift to whom youd like to see de-shaped on that depressing day back to the office. Its a win-win. Get the recipe for coconut, orange and mango on now
This Crazy Rich Asian-y panettone is coming soon to the fat cells near you

I would like to thank all of you for the love, support and advice youve given me in the past week. As progress goes, Sesame (in this photo) and SRB have successfully, albeit reluctantly, learnt the fine art of walking on a suspiciously moving conveyor belt that the humans call the treadmill. It is widely claimed to be a device that not only provide physical but also mental exercise for poorly educated yet hyperactive dogs like mine. However 15 minutes of fast walking on such promise didnt seem to have tired a muscle. I may have Olympian-potential pups. Need to up the ante. Weve also started to give them both CBD supplements, which we jokingly call the space cake. As expected, it is by no means a magic pill. But it does seem to take a slight edge off of their hyper-sensitivity. Most evidently in that they stopped the daily, multiple midnight attempts to sneak up on our bed. Well, sort of. There is still a long way to go before Sesame and SRB can, if ever, become model canine citizens. Or at the very least, I would only ask, that they try not to want to kill each other every once in awhile. Thanks again, and I will keep you updated

Its been a tough week. Partly due to the injuries on my hands and partly crippled by anxiety, I barely stepped a foot in the kitchen in these past few days. Today, I put on two plastic gloves, planted myself into the kitchen floor, and for 30 minutes, forgot about everything else. I made lunch. Ha. I made lunch

Besides an emotional breakdown where I cried in the bathroom with the tap on, Im otherwise holding myself in one piece. I want to take this chance to say thank you for all the helpful advices and love you sent me on my last post. Professional trainer hired. Treadmill bought and coming. CBD supplements en route. A lot of hard works in the future to come. But I think, I hope, future is looking bright

Last Friday I was heartbroken. My two fur-children Rottweiler-mix sisters, whom were inseparable and shared an impenetrable bond when they were puppies, broke out into a fight that shattered my heart. Theyve always had disagreements and brawls growing up, which Ive always, perhaps wishfully, believed to be unavoidable sibling scuffling. But on Friday, the fight resulted in superficial cuts and bruises on one of SRBs ear, and several non-debilitating but serious punctures and tears on my hand and fingers a pure result of me sticking my arm in SRBs mouth to protect them from further hurting each other but NOT because there was any aggression towards me (they would never). It was probably a stupid thing to do. But love is a strange thing. Just when you think that theres a limit to its elasticity, when circumstances harden, it just expands. The general advice of re-homing one of them sent me into a spiral of gutting anxiety and depression. I immediately consulted with animal behaviorist, dog trainers, and are considering all possible aids including anti-depressant medications that would help them escape their natural tendency of fearfulness and anxiety, and hopefully opening them up towards all the future training and new perspectives. Wish us luck.
Everyone have a great weekend. Thats all.

Any family of Chinese descent, regardless entirely or partially, would have their own personal "red-braised" recipe, basically meats stewed in soy sauce with various aromatics and spices. Whose tastes better? Depending on who you're talking to, cautions may be recommended before you offer your opinions on such matter because friendships have been ruined for less. A long time ago, I wrote an article for @food52 about my mom's Sichuan peppercorn red-braised oxtail, which I consider to be worthy of being called a heirloom recipe that should be passed down -- since I will likely die alone and childless -- to you. Today I made a variation by using beef shank instead of oxtail, with added chunks of carrots for good conscience, and a little nub of freshly grated ginger after it's poured over a bed of rice. I think the case is settled. If you want to see for yourself, the recipe is in the link in profile

It took a 3 hours round-trip on a scooter, somewhere among the rice fields off of the east side of central , that we finally found what would like to call eating out of an open wound - Him Tang Pigs Blood Soup. Not thickened with blood, not cooked blood cakes, but raw blood that was rubbed vigorously with herbs and served gushingly with crispy innards and fried shallots. It tastes - even though I already knew it would be yet still - incredibly delicious and unlike anything Ive ever tasted. No trace in its magnificent complexity would tell you that it is running blood if you eat it blindfolded. An amazing experience and privilege to have had it. . Then a small note on a comment from my last post about saving elephants, which asked me why I, since I eat meat, seems to care about the welfare of certain animals and not another. To that Id like to say that Im not against food chain, eating animals. If every carnivores on earth decides to go vegan, wed have a bigger problem. But I am against driving a species to extinction just because we can. Do I think the industrial animal farming should improve on their treatments of livestock. Absolutely. Am I doing enough to make that happen? Definitely not. And I believe that even If there is an answer out there, it would not be without contradiction either. To be morally indisputable is not the point. The point is to try to be better, however that is possible for me. And I give credits to those likewise

Im sorry we take your homes. Im sorry you wake up in cages. Im sorry we torture, abuse, ride, display and use you like slaves. Im sorry we find you spectacles. Im sorry we are in fucking awe. Im sorry we butcher you for your husks and decorate with it our ugliness. Im sorry we leave you to rot. Im sorry in the wake of our shame, we put you in sanctuaries where you can only survive as our feel-good day trip, make you eat bananas, make you take mud bath, make you touch us. Im sorry we are high as kites. I know you shouldve been free. I know you shouldve had a say. I know there shouldve been more. I know there should be a better way. But instead, Im sorry, your survival is at the ironic mercy of our petty amusements. Today you, despite all, even if reluctant, were so gentle to my touch. I was, again, in fucking awe. Im sorry

Here's an unexpectedly successful recipe in recreating @freedmans_la's (featured in this month's @bonappetitmag's cover) genius potato latke waffle fries. Not only magnificent in its final result, but perhaps more significant that it eliminates the lengthy soaking/blanching/frying process that is conventionally necessary in creating perfectly crispy potato fries. The granular makeup of the pre-cooked potato latke waffle disbands slightly inside the hot grease, creating gloriously crispy edges and surfaces where the interior is captured and sealed in its creamy and molten state, awaiting for an audible fracture. Serving it elegantly with smoked trout and whipped creme fraiche butter, or simply dunking it ketchup, you'll realize the perfect homemade French fries, after all this time, is actually not French fries. Mayo-free chicken salad that tastes like chicken pho? See for yourself. Toast 1/2 small onion, 20 grams of sliced ginger and 1 tsp of Thai shrimp paste on open flame until charred and shriveled. Transfer into a blender along with 1 small box (297 grams) firm tofu (drained and pat dry), 2 lemongrass white parts only and finally chopped, 2 small star anise, 7 whole cloves, 1 tsp fennel seeds, 1/2 tsp group cinnamon, 2 tsp fish sauce. Blend until extremely smooth. Toss with gently poached and diced chicken breasts, 2 finely minced shallots, finely chopped Thai basil, and serve with a wedge of lime, toasted bread, and Sriracha sauce. You're welcome

I don't even have to eat it (egg intolerance, long story). Because a sufficient rush of ecstasy is harvested from the act alone. But I did sneak in a small bite. And it tastes, indeed, even better than it feels

One of the obstacles home-cooks face in our home kitchens is the inability to turn a wet sauce, into the form of dry spices, which could then be used to season dishes that need to stay dry and crispy, like fried chicken, French fries, popcorns, fritters and etc, whose precious crusts we so lovingly forged could be in complete ruin when contacted with a wet sauce. That is why I was genuinely excited to be introduced to @coleandmasonusas collection of dried spices which are inspired by some of my favorite wet sauces. Take this fried chicken for example, marinated in yogurt then fried to crispy perfections in Japanese-style crusts, then tumbled in a finale of their Sriracha spice mixture, giving them an orange-red coating of powdered chili flakes, garlics, onions and vinegar powder. The result is a sprightly seasoned fried chicken where the coatings can remain crispy and brittle throughout. Heres how: In a spice-grinder, grind 1/2 bottle of @coleandmasonusas Sriracha spice mixture until finely powdered. Cut two skinless/boneless chicken legs (500 grams) into large bite-size pieces, then mix them evenly with 3 tbsp of plain yogurt, 1 tbsp of Sriracha sauce, 2 tsp of the finely ground Sriracha spice and 1/4 tsp of ground black pepper. Cover and let marinate in the fridge for at least 4 hours to overnight. Heat 2 deep of canola oil over medium-high heat until it reaches 340 F/170 C, or until it bubbles up immediately around an inserted wooden chopstick. In a bowl, evenly mix 3/4 cup of potato starch, 1/4 cup of fine cornmeal and 1 tsp of ground white pepper. Drench the marinated chickens in the starch-mixture until thoroughly coated, then fry until golden browned on all sides (do not crowd the pot). Drain the fried chicken only briefly before immediately tumbling them with a generous amount of the ground Sriracha spice. Repeat with the next batch. This recipe will be equally awesome with Chipotle Mango spice mixture as well. Go to coleandmasonusa.com/sweepstakes (link in profile) to learn about , and enter to win up to $1,000 of free spice and product, valid for US residents only

Yesterday I made my Monday blue-berry oatmeal cookies and was reminded again of the sacred mission that cookies carry in this dark dark world. Something I wrote about cookies three years ago and still stands true today. Most cookie recipes stop me cold at words like cream the room-temperature butter and sugary until smooth and fluffy. NO, NO I SHANT! I mean cookies have social responsibilities, man! The first-responders suited in sugar and fat. The last defense between let-me-work-this-out, and fuck-this-world-and-burn! As someone walking the cliff of a mental meltdown and beginning to caress the keyboard on a suicide.doc, does it sound like its a good time to ask them to cream shit? Does it feel like a good time to fluff it? No, theres only one type of good cookie and thats a fast cookie. Ok so what I went a bit overboard at my supermarkets buy 1 get 1 free kimchi-sale and got myself into a little dispute for fridge-space with 2 kilos of impatient kimchi? Nothing a fritter cant solve is what. Mix 150 grams of fatty ground pork with 2 tsp of grated ginger, 2 cloves of grated garlic, 1 tbsp of soy sauce and 1 tsp of toasted sesame oil. Coat a non-stick skillet with more toasted sesame oil and brown the pork over medium high heat. Transfer the pork into a large bowl, along with 1 cup of finely minced , 1/4 cup of finely diced scallions, 1 large egg, 2 tbsp heavy cream and a few turns of black pepper, and mix evenly. Whisk together 1/2 cup of flour and 1/2 tsp of baking powder, then gently mix the flour into the kimchi-mixture to create a thick batter. Melt butter in a large non-stick skillet over medium heat. Spoon the batter into the skillet (youll have about 5 fritters), cover, and cook until the first side is golden browned. Flip them and cook until the second side is golden browned as well. Torch American singles on top of the fritters (one for each if you care to be right) until melted, and serve with whipped cream cheese season with black pepper
World has depressing news but it also has coffee, lemon poppy seed cakes and Saturdays. Im getting good at this positivity thingy

I believe that, more often than not, it was by pure accidents that most of mankinds greatest culinary discoveries came to light. Things like cheese, yogurts, breads, beer enlightenments via serendipity. I know this to be true because yesterday, it happened to me. I was at my friend Nanas @plantation_hk, a tea shop curated with hand-selected tea leaves from Taiwan, India and China, experimenting on my first tea-blending session with tea leaves and dried flowers. Guided by my utter illiteracy in tea-education, I based my blend purely on esthetics, mixing tieguanyin (a type of Taiwanese oolong tea) with brightly yellow osmanthus flowers. Upon the immediacy of the first sip, I have to say that as far as tea goes, it sucked. But a few seconds went by before I soon realized that the rejection in my brain wasnt prompted by bad taste, instead, it was categorizing what I was tasting in an entirely different food-group. Because the blend didnt taste like tea, but more closely, it intimately resembled seaweed water, or in Japanese, known as dashi. Where is a tea best when it doesnt taste like tea, but dashi instead? Of course, the iconic Japanese rice dish . Tested and approved, blend 3 parts of tieguanyin with 1 part of osmanthus. Brew 1 tbsp of the blend in a tea pot with 3/4 cup of boiling water for 1 minute. Place a scant 1/2 cup of steamed sushi rice in the bowl, then pour the tea over the top. Season it with a heaping 1/4 tsp of fish sauce and the best sea salt you can get, then top with 1 heaping tbsp of rice crispy cereal, a small handful of finely shredded nori (toasted seaweed), finely diced chives, a couple drops of toasted sesame oil and 1/2 turn of black pepper. Weightless, clean, serene and almost meditative, from the making to the lingering aroma dissipating from an empty bowl. By pure chance. Who knew

Sponsored. When extra virgin olive oil from Spain is blended with market lime leaves, green chili, scallion, lime zest, lemongrass, cilantro and ginger, then again strained to become a luxuriously emerald green liquid, it becomes the perfect marinate/poaching liquid for a fatty and silky hunk of halibut, sous vide style. The translucent flesh of the halibut whitens and tightens into the perfectly calculated and controlled state of being opulent and supple, where a small amount of its savory juice seeps into the olive oil, each releasing and absorbing the essence of the other, born anew. Warm out of the water bath, the fish and the extra virgin olive oil is as ready to be served as any. But I couldnt resist to impose an element of crispiness by pan-frying a single side in a hot skillet and emulsifying the olive oil with yolk and garlic into a loose mayonnaise-like sauce. The recipe for halibut sous vide in herby extra virgin olive oil with @oliveoilsspain, is now on the blog. Follow the link in profile

So I have been somewhat absent on IG lately and the truth is, its because Ive been busy at my other, possibly more important job - being a dog mom. On IG, I tend to showcase the sweet, goofy and adorable side of Sesame and SRB, our 1.5 yrs old rottie-mix sisters. Which they are, if I have to point out, when they are with us at home. But in reality, both Sesame and SRB are, since puppyhood, what I would call extremely fearful dogs, of strangers, of other dogs, of strange objects, and of just about anything that are unfamiliar. And because of their fearful but also protective nature, they could behave aggressively in certain situations towards other dogs (although theyve never actually hurt another dog). Recently we are starting to apply more desensitizing training, including exercises that builds up their confidences, plus small play groups that improves their socializing skills, which has been taking up most of my times. But to see Sesame, for the first time, playing with another dog outside of her own pack, makes it all worth it. So sorry guys, mom duty. Ill see you when I see you.

During our recent trip to , we had the pleasure of meeting the young and spirited @chockywoky at a charming cafe in Chinatown. She warmly handed me a small bag of gift and as I opened it, I stared into the content with slight perplexity. What is it? I asked. Granola! She smiled. Ill admit, at the moment, I briefly questioned the accuracy and clarity of my public persona but nonetheless, I took what was probably the second or third bite of granola in my entire life. Now what Im about to say I do not say it lightly. But holy shit, her granola blew my mind. A genuinely clever application of Chinese BBQ pork jerky and miso-rubbed sugar gave the granola an addictive balance of salty and sweet with a bacon-like aroma that kept its subject hooked. She probably saw how sad I was about my finite supply of her granola, yesterday I received two more fixes, this time made equally delicious with pork floss (and theres a vegetarian version with vegetarian pork floss, too!). If youre curious how I could ever, like ever!, be excited about granola, please feel free to harass her for recipes

Wanna know a trick for making super frothy matcha? Answer: A $6 battery-operated milk frother (swipe to see it in action)! Lets all be honest. An fanatic arm-workout and a wabi-sabi-im-super-zen lifestyle is just not simpatico. Which is why I have long switched to this cheap yet reliable tool whenever I want a beautiful foam-cap on my matcha. Well, this and a gradual water-addition technique. Heres what you do: Put about a scant teaspoon of matcha powder in the bowl. Add just a few drops of water in, then whisk it to make a deep green paste. This makes it lump-free, okay? Then, add about 1/3 cup of boiling water. Insert the milk frother, turn it on, and swivel it around until the matcha becomes very frothy. Last, carefully pour in more water on the side so you dont disturb the foam, until the matcha reaches your desired strongness

Homemade instant noodle mix series continues. Japanese curry cubes can be great, convenient, delicious, and a deep-rooted nostalgia for almost every Asian growing up. But it can also be a bit too sweet and lacking of complexity. In the pursuit for an all-purpose instant Japanese curry mix, Ive added to it my own defectors to bring it more intensity and depth from cocoa powder, a touch of bitterness from instant coffee, a slight acidity from Dijon mustard. Then last but not least, the unfailing wonder of American singles melts into the most viscous intention to bring out the childishness in all of us. You can use this mix to make, instantly, mild and drinkable broth or thick and power gravy, bring your late-night slurp to a new height. Get the recipe now. Link in profile

I tried my hands at making savory (sticky rice stuffed in bamboo leaves) for the first time, and Im absolutely , head-over-heel addicted to this process. Nestled in the heart of this geometrically shaped sticky rice dumpling, is a cube of fatty pork belly that was stewed in an extra dark soy sauce-based braising liquid. Being trapped inside the bamboo leaves all together, the sticky rice has no alternative but to fully absorb every lardy, flavorful molecules oozing out of this fatty core, becoming fused as one. Its exciting enough as is, but even more so for all its untapped potentials. My mind is already racing towards parmesan rind, duck fat, truffle I cant wait

Making Singaporean-style soft-boiled eggs for breakfast is easier than you think, and you do not need a sous vide machine! Basically, the eggs need to be cooked in water that is around 160 F/70 C for 23 minutes. But, the temperature can fluctuate between 150 F/65 C to 170 F/75 C, which means its quite forgiving. So bring a pot of water (the water has to be able to fully submerge the eggs) with a thermometer inside over high heat to bring it up to 160 F/70 C. Gently place 4~6 large eggs (whole egg! not cracked!) in the pot, then turn the heat down to THE LOWEST POSSIBLE FLAME. Check every few minutes, and if the temperature goes too close to 170 F/75 C, drop 3~4 ice cubes to bring it down to 150 F/65 C. The water will likely rise again in a few minutes, and you just have to come back to adjust it. But theres certainly no need to babysit the pot every minute of the way.. . After which, soak the eggs in cold water to stop the cooking. You can simply dress the eggs with soy sauce. Or, as I recently discovered, the mushroom sauce from my recipe for Tai Hwa pork noodle is keenly compatible (follow link in profile for the recipe). Do kaya toast, or as I like to serve it with baguette browned in obscene amount of butter. Swipe for the broken yolk shot

Does everyone know about dried lime but me? I mean seriously where has it been all my life?! These tiny babes grind into a powder that adds such a more complex and flavorful acidity than what a squeeze of lime juice ever could! Mildly tart with a lemony whiff of aged lime zest that has become my go-to magic dust on anything that needs a touch of acidity (and guess what, thats EVERYTHING). . . For example, this ambiguous looking thing is a pork wonton rolled in chili oil and whipped avocado dusted with dried lime. A single bite of sensory big bang. Finely mash 1 avocado with 1 grated shallot, 1/4 tsp cream of tartar, and salt to taste. Toss cooked wontons with soy sauce, my xian chili oil, and a bit of grated garlic. Then serve with a dollop of the mashed avocado and a generous dusting dried lime powder. Bet you cant eat just one. You can find dried lime on Amazon

So, I have a cracker problem. I have a sickly obsession with all kinds of crackers and biscuits, especially the plainest water crackers that sucks up all your saliva and even so, I could eat them non-stop. A problem so bad, that it almost got me killed today. . . So when I was walking out of the supermarket today with my bag full of different crackers, as usually, I couldnt even wait until I get home before I opened one and just started munching on it on the street. I crossed the street, and as I was approaching the curbside on the other end, people started yelling at me, Hey Hey Hey!!!. But I was so involved with my own thoughts at the time, Mm, do I love this one? Its a bit oily but the cheddar flavor is on point I didnt even hear them. Until a few seconds layer, the yelling turned to screaming, Wei Wei WEI OY OY OY!!!. I finally turned looking right, and saw a SUV that was trying to back into its parking spot was about to run me over. . . We both came to a halt when there was only two inches of space between me and the SUV, and I was like, WTF? Now Id like you to imagine a woman in a huge beanie and a teddy bear coat, with 1/2 cracker on her hand and a mouth full of cracker, crumb-spitting and everything, who walked slowly over up to the drivers window and mumbled You almost runph phe opher, assphole! The driver looked at me like, whos this crazy cracker bitch. So I repeated I SAID, You almost runph me over! Watch phew road!. Something tells me that the cracker-part delegitimized my seriousness, but whatever, I put the remaining cracker in my mouth, and slowly hovered away

Im not sure who wants this information, but over the years, Ive narrowed down faking-vintage-cutting-board down to a science. And I though that if theres a crazy like me on earth, there must be more out there. So: . . What you need is a SOLID WOOD cutting board that you desperately want to fast-forward 50 years (this is an olive wood board). A cheap, long serrated knife. Rough sand paper. Vegetable oil (I like flaxseed oil because it doesnt get sticky). An oven. A blow-torch. . . If your board has a shiny finish/coating, completely sand it away first. Now, take the serrated knife and start violently, mercilessly, psychotically slashing the board like a motherfucker. I like to start with the edges first, making deep, deep deeply bloody cuts that extends towards the center of the board. Go sideways with the knife as well scraping and sanding the entire edges down to a pulp. Then start making deep cuts on the boards center flat surface, hacking, poking, slashing, focusing on the center but leaving no surface untouched and intact. Take your time, enjoy it, fuck it up. . . Now sand any splinters away with sand paper. Dont wash it yet. Brush the entire board with flaxseed oil, which will darken it considerably. Place the board a few inches under the top-broiler in the oven, and bake it until it has darkened to the shade that you are after. Flip the board and do the same with the other side. This may make a couple cracks on the board, which is why its important to use solid wood board. Afterwards, use a blow-torch to further make darker tones around the edges and corners, mimicking how naturally wood boards age. Hold he torch in slanted angle, make sure the flame is going from the center of the board towards the edge, not the other way around. BE PATIENT, hold the torch far away from the board, applying color slowly as layers, avoiding any concentrated heat spots. . . Now let the board cool down completely before washing it with soap. For even better result, repeat the slashing, oiling and blow-torching for the second time, applying a second layering of effect

Nat Geo Breaking News: The human specie population who have migrated to Hong Kong from much colder environments for more than a year and above, seem to fastly and inevitably shed whatever cold weather-resistance that they had built up in their previous habitats, puzzling scientists in this bizarre evolutionary phenomenon. Here, every time when the temperature drops below the mere 10 Celsius (Im talking 50 F), its inhabitants - regardless whether they were from NY or Norwegian - begin to display frantic behaviors of survival mechanisms, scattering and disappearing into their dwellings wearing comically thick insulations, burning up all available means of energies to save themselves from imaginary hypothermia, huddling in the deep inability to cope. This highly contagious condition is known as, the Colony Frost and Collapse Disorder. And I am one of the many infected. . . Solution: Scientists have yet to understand let alone providing an effective treatment for this life-paralyzing syndrome, therefore, natural remedies are the only available options to date. I suggest, chicken stock oatmeal topped with torched, ground fennel-rubbed chashu pork belly (a leftover blessing from this insufferable book-writing thingy), dribbled with sweet soy sauce, sesame oil, and one-week fermented chili sauce and diced scallions. The ceramic bowl remains toasty from the flames of the blow-torch, acting as a life-saving hand-warmer. Im not saying this isnt ridiculous. But its necessary

Mid-week and already about to jump off of something? Heres a way to make an one mini-skillet, sausage with cream-cuddled egg that might talk you out of it. Heat olive oil in a small skillet over medium heat and brown a couple of your favorite sausages (pork with black truffle being mine). Remove the sausages (leave all the brown drippings inside) and add 1 thinly sliced garlic, 3 sprigs of fresh thyme, and cook until fragrant. Then add 1/4 cup of half-half (or heavy cream if life is too short and agonizing), 1 tsp Dijon mustard, and season it with fish sauce (yes) and black pepper. Drop a large egg in the middle and simmer until the white is cooked and the yolk is not. Return the sausages where they belong, then dig in with a piece of crusty bread. If you still want to end it after this, at least its on a high note

You may notice that my blog has been relatively quiet for quite some time now. And thats because the writing of the book is entering its last two-plus months of panicky crunch-time. This may sound weird, but savory steel-cut oatmeal, Sichuan style. Cook 1/2 cup of steel-cut oatmeal in 1 cup chicken stock and 1/2 cup whole milk for 20-25 min. Season with Kombu soy sauce (store-bought) to taste and let sit and thicken for 3 min. Mix 2 tbsp of my xian chili oil (recipe is in the blogs archive under rice ribbon) with 1 grated garlic, 1 tbsp soy sauce and a hefty pinch of light brown sugar. Douse the oatmeal with the sauce and a soft-boiled egg with fresh herbs. Its a that wakes you for sure

Every morning around 7 AM, these girls who sneaked up onto our bed in the middle of every night, would place their heads on our chests, gently and hopeful, trying to wake us up for... reasons that are beyond me. Are they late for work? Nope. Do they have to pee? Nope. Is the house on fire? Absolutely not. When are they going to become those creatures who sleep 20 hours a day, like all our other dogs, and their mom? One can only hope

Sometimes I substitute instant ramen noodles with dry pasta when Im after a lightening-fast meal, such as this canned sardines pasta with garlics, chili, fresh mints and lime zest. Saut lots of shaved garlics in the olive oil from the sardine cans, add anchovies, chili flakes, ground white peppers (lots) and cooked ramen noodles (al dente of course), then toss everything together with a bit of cooking water, lime zest and fish sauce. Serve after a squirt of lime juice. The ramen noodles provide a completely different but equally addictive texture and flavor, but more importantly, ready in under 3 minutes

I finally got around to make @sarah_kieffers molasses pan-banging cookies, and its everything that I had hoped for and more! Crispy caramelized edges with dense and chewy center, not to mention that beautiful cookie growth rings. The only thing I did differently was that I used light brown sugar instead of granulated, and reduced the amount from 297 grams to 250 grams (and I think it could still be a bit less sweet, just for my taste). I omitted rolling the cookie-dough in sugar, and instead, I scooped them directly onto the pan (it didnt make much difference in the outcome). Perhaps because my oven was hotter, I found that they needed the first banging at 6~7 minutes, then again every 1:30 min, for a total baking time of 12~13 minutes. But overall, for a person with baking birth-defect, it was easy and successful on my first try, which is rare to say the least. If you havent tried this, head over to @sarah_kieffers blog for this awesome recipe

I know this may not gather much endorsement, but lately my favorite thing to cook is actually filleting small, fatty fishes like baby mackerel or saury (or sardines if it was possible to get some), then poach them in garlic and pickled chili-infused extra virgin olive oil. These type of fishes are actually high in nutritional value, superior in taste, and just happens to be more sustainable as well. The process of filleting the fish - understandably hideous to most - is actually, for me, quite meditative in its repetitive, methodical, almost surgical manner. I make them in a large batch (see in my story), and as it gets better by the day, the flavors welds and synchronize, I enjoy them with crackers or a crusty loaf of bread. Because they are not canned or preserved, we finish the batch within days. Which has proven to be, the least effort of all

For reasons both obvious and inexplicable, so far in this life, whether I like it or not, I have found myself to be part of a very loosely knitted family. My father, brother and I barely talk, and every rare attempts to do so felt increasingly muzzled with mutual bickering and subdued resentments. And so we talk even less. My mother, tries as she might, is voiceless in this irreparable dynamic which she could never bring herself to reflect upon as, perhaps, a result of her own compliance. I have five aunties and probably more than a dozen cousins whom I would not even recognize face-to-face on the street let alone having any meaningful relationships with. My in-laws think Im from Mars and I them. Well, where my own fault lays in all of this, judging from how obviously clear I understand the situation and yet have done nothing, is equally undeniable. Why am I bring up all this? Because its holiday season, again, a concept as unfamiliar to me as it is wistfully desired. The anticipation of the warm chaos, the admission to belong, the invitation to bask in, even if its obligatory, the security of a widely casted family net, is something, I guess, I was not assigned to in this life. Maybe, the grass is always greener on the other side. Maybe, it isnt all jolly merry to be a part of a big fat and tight family. What do you think? Am I missing out or better off

Its been way too long since our last vacation and my entire state of sanity is aching for it. Lately I had a conversation with a friend about why those people who already accumulated all the money theyll ever need, still keep on, relentlessly, working to no ends. I mean, why do they, or we, work so hard? Isnt it, after all, to have the means to be happy? But in end, is it really about that, in the end, is it just a prison of insecurities? Sometimes I feel that it only takes a cottage in the sun. Sometimes, an impossible castle. How about you? Why do you do what you do

A big thanks to all the comments that suggested using neem oil for pest-control in my herb garden! For the past few weeks Ive been adding neem oil directly into the soil (instead of a spray, because I didnt want to use soap), once a week, and then watered as usual. And I think it really did reduce the amount of aphids and whatnots on my plants! The oil doesnt not smell pleasant though, which is another reason why I didnt use it in a spray. But now at least my herbs look nice and happy. Thanks guys!

Ive been thinking about premeditation in life. Cooking, in a lot of ways, is premeditating. We imagine, envision, almost methodically, piecing together and rearranging for something, with the least possible amount of margin of error, to exist in the near reality. But life, hardly works that way. And when it does, its almost a pleasant surprise. . Moving back in this apartment we renovated eight years ago, back in a time when the word blog or Instagram were utter alien disinterests, realizing that somehow, even though life has warped, this skeleton we built in the past converges even more fittingly and fully with the changes in the present. Enriched, even. The unexpected, in a sense, completes the premeditated. I guess, life is not a recipe. But we can trust our guts, and let the rest unfold.

This creamy bed of chickpea puree is not made with tahini, but guess what, silken tofu! I ran out of tahini a while ago, and happened to have a box of silken tofu in the fridge, so heres what I did: . Drain and peel 1 can of canned chickpeas and place inside a food-processor, along with a 1/2 clove of garlic, 2 tsp toasted sesame oil, 2 tsp fish sauce, 2 tsp lemon juice, 1/8 tsp ground cumin. Then run until ground to a fine gritty texture. Add 2 tbsp of silken tofu (or medium firmness should work, too) at a time, and run until the mixture is extremely smooth to your preferred thickness, adding more tofu as you need. Re-season with fine sea salt. Serve with an poached egg, with extra virgin olive oil spiced with cumin, chilis and chives. Black pepper, serve

I dont know if its a subtropical climate issue or what, but I am currently in a bloodthirsty war against another earthly specie, a race on who can eat herbs faster than the other. BUGS. Mysterious dickhead bugs who never show themselves but somehow manage to efficiently consume the precious crops of my hard labor, even making sure that they leave a good amount of douchey poops behind just to let me know that they did it. Tiny little black specks of hateful insults on my poor, pillaged baby herbs. At this point Im almost willing to forfeit the right to enjoy these herbs just so I can gleefully slaughter their entire worthless colony with deathly pesticides If anybody has any genocidal tips on wiping out mysterious bugs who leaves black sandy poops behind without mutual annihilation, please give them in the comments.

You know what you should do in the summer? Eat your instant soup noodles, DRY style. Pick your favorite instant noodles, preferably ones that come with at least 2~3 flavoring packets (usually an oil packet, a powder packet, and a dried vegetable packet). After you cook the noodles, drain them well, then mix them with all the flavoring packets except for the powder one (this is where the salt is, and youll need less of it because theres no soup), then mix in just enough powder packet to get to your preferred saltiness. Then I like to douse it with more chili oil, and slurp away with a cold drink on the side

Theres only one thing to do when you get food-homesick, and that is to make matters into your own hands meandering streets are treasure grounds for small vendors that sell rice vermicelli in broth and pigs offals, usually served with garlic sweet soy sauce, thinly sliced ginger and green onions. Its can be eaten as breakfast, lunch or dinner, even late night snack. It takes care of hungry souls from all walks of life without bias. Its probably the that I miss the most. So the other day I made a version of my own, nostalgic, warm and close to heart. The only thing missing were plastic stools

Continuing yesterdays conversation, this is why it was never that hard for me to give up tuna: Smaller yet deeper and more complex flavored fishes like sardines and anchovies, or in this case, a small local fish that are sold at 1.50 usd/lb. Deboned, then poached in hot extra virgin olive oil infused with garlics, pickled red chilis and fish sauce, until they just turn opaque. I let them sit, patiently, for 2 hours, not just to cool down but to let the flavors of the oil seep through their fatty, delicate flesh. Then I devour the whole thing, oily, savory, spicy, pungent, with torn crusty bread. I dont love this as a compromise to bigger, overfished species. I would choose to eat this, anytime any day, over any tuna, chilean sea bass, cods and whatnots. These are the real foodies fish

I want to publishing this entire post on IG but it simply exceeds the word-count limit. So instead, I will say this in short: I havent eaten tuna for 10 years, except one time in Hawaii when/where it was responsible. Maybe youve heard, tuna as a specie isnt doing so hot. If you cannot NOT eat tuna, at least, make sure that its from a sustainable source. And if you cant be sure, then seriously, its just fucking tuna, not a limb or dick. It isnt all that hard to cut loose. I say this not only to those who come here to decide whats for dinner, but also, as a member of the food-blog community which touches this subject all too rarely, its an opportunity to remind us all again that, not just our actions but more so, how our inactions matter. Maybe youre a food-blogger like me whos never posted a tuna-recipe before. Or, maybe youve posted recipes of tuna because its a popular ingredient, maybe you know about the issue of overfishing and maybe you choose not to mention it, either because its off-putting or that youre scared it will give your readers an incentive not to share it, and maybe, that will hurt your traffic and followers, or maybe, you just dont give a shit. Weve all been there. We all still do it. But our maybes are deadlier than a nuclear bomb. Because it will play a part in rendering the ocean fishless. You think North Korea is reckless. We should see whats on our plates. Look, am I a hypocrite? Sure I am, Im no vegan. But not being able to do 100% is no excuse to do zero. Even a hypocrite can do the right thing. Starting with, we should at least give a fuck. This recipe is good. Really good. A velvety sauce that is the sum of all that is awesome about a tuna sandwich minus the gritty texture, served deeply and glisteningly caramelized pork chop in browned butter infused with fresh bay leaves and garlics. And if you have the faintest hope to enjoy it for years to come, make this recipe responsibly. Or not at all. Read the full post. Link in profile

Sometimes happiness feels like the peak of an impossible mountain, beyond the clouds, where Im standing at the bottom looking up. But sometimes, it came simply just a cold plate of summer lychees and peach in an air-conditioned room with dogs at my feet. It is moments like these that I try to take hold to realize, even if I will soon again forget, that it was never meant to be hard. Happiness is a choice. So .

Whats better to eat in a 32C-but-feels-like-42C day, than to sit on the cold concrete floor while soothing in this slightly spicy and aromatic, red coconut curry salmon ? This recipe was published on my blog a couple weeks ago, but instead of cherry tomatoes, I added diced avocados and froze blueberries (and dont leave out the dragonfruit). Each bite is the perfect balance of creamy, savory, tart and sweet. Then instead of being mopped by bread, the leftover sauce went on to delight a couple soft-hearted boiled eggs peeled at table side. The food equivalent of a cold shower. Being grounded by two oversize puppies (who refuse to participate in this particular photo shoot, or any for that matter) means that our next travel is still at least a few months away. But my feet are already itching for the next journey outbound. Theres nothing that excites me more (except for oversize puppies) than traveling to another world that will shift, forever, who I am presently and in the future. It draws my understanding about myself, my life, deeper towards the core, looking outward and inward at the same time. I come home with the same suitcase but anew. So pack your bag and go somewhere, somewhere youve never been before. The only thing you need to leave behind, is the old you.

Ive been saying that Ill post more photos of our apartment that we renovated 8 years ago, actually moved in 1+ year ago, but never really did. The wall is never the accurate shade of white. The furnitures arent the perfect blend of balance. The coffee table is way too clunky, and sofa is a few inches too low. The stove-top in the kitchen must go of course, and a better-looking faucet must come in. I need more linen here, I need less clusters over there. This says I try too hard. That says I have no clue. Its always too much. Its always too little. We talk about creativity a lot on IG, but no one hardly mentions the noxious ego that creeps in. One rarely exists without the other. Are we sharing or flaunting? Id still like to believe that the former fuels better work. I havent yet found my balance in this context. If/when I do, it warrants a celebration.

Though there are many reasons why my very first post on my blog - omg that was 5 years ago - makes me cringe to watch right now, but I only need one good reason to share it again with you, and that is cacio e pepe. To me, you really cannot make a great cacio e pepe without fresh, thick-cut homemade pasta. You can do it with dry spaghetti and it might be good, but definitely not great, not really. You need that chew, that tender resistance that flirts with your jaw-muscles. So no matter how aged and complex your Pecorino Romano may be, or how good you are at forming that emulsification, just remember, without chubby homemade pasta, it just aint there yet. FYI, this type of chubby pasta has a totally different moisture ratio than typical whole egg pasta dough. If you want to see how I make mine, go ahead with the .

What the hell is Chinese almonds? This is confusing, no doubt. And the answer to that, despite my lifelong adoration for this ingredient, actually took me several years to clarify. Turns out, Chinese almonds are not almonds at all, in fact, they are apricot kernel. Apricot kernel in its literal translation in Chinese, is ( is apricot. is kernel), which is a very common ingredient all over Asia. But where it gets confusing is that in Asia, the actual almond - the typical type that we see in North America - is translated into Chinese as American apricot kernel, and in reverse logic, they also label apricot kernels in English as Chinese almond. In fact, to buy apricot kernels online in English, one will have to search by Chinese almond, or else nothing will come up. So growing up, most people only knows these two ingredients - with completely different tastes and aroma - to be the same thing, where in fact, they come from totally different fruits. To make matters even more messy, the essence labeled as almond extract all over the world which is made from (not the snackable sweet almond) bitter almond, you guessed it, tastes exactly like apricot kernel. And amaretti, the liquor that tastes like almond extract, is actually, yes, made from apricot kernels. I remember once reading a New York Times article about chefs from fancy restaurants who, proudly no doubt, crack 45 apricots just to retrieve the kernels that give their ice creams that unmistakably aromatic boost, and thinking to myself, dude, stupid, you can get a whole bag of apricot kernels, peeled dried and ready, from China town or online for just a few bucks. Only that they are not labeled apricot kernels. Theyd be labeled Chinese almonds. So there, now we know.

Six to seven months ago, due to an autoimmune condition called scarring alopecia (under management), I seemed to have caught this current buzz-cut trend by accident. I wasnt exactly in love with this look, but strangely, perhaps just like any other actions in life that make us feel in control, this gesture of buzzing my hair seemed to have grown roots and became somewhat addictive. Every time I feel that Im in fear, not just about hair but any self-image insecurities (like the pain of growing out my hair), I want to buzz my head again (in fact I did it again in January). Im not sure if this is consider healthy in a psychological sense, probably not, but a new bizarre and ironic comfort zone seems to have taken place. Sometime you need to go where it terrifies you in order to be liberated.

This setting reminds me of all those summer days spent at my grandparents courtyard house in Taiwans rural farmland, where I was a wild child, even just for the summer, chicken-chasing, frog-hunting in the mud, making fires and cooking dandelions. It was better than a theme park, where every single grasshoppers and cicadas, every trees and small water canals, every chicken coops and pigs dens were its own little universe, full of groundbreaking discoveries. I didnt even know back then how precious these experiences are in this hyper-modern society that we live in, where most kids are muted from nature and explorations. Wish I could be that kid again for just one day

The conveyor belt method allows you to continuously roll the pasta sheet without re-feeding it back to the machine! I dont know why people dont do this

I prefer a drier dough when it comes to super thin pasta (like my previous post). I mix 2 cups (260 grams) all-purpose flour (or tipi 00), 2 large eggs plus 1 egg yolk, 1/2 tsp salt and maybe just 1 tsp more water. The dough will be very dry and crackly, but just knead it for 5 min then plastic-wrap to rest for 1 hour. After resting, the dough will become significantly more moist and hydrated. Then roll it to the thinnest setting of your pasta machine. Remember to do the "conveyor belt" method! Roll the ends of the sheet together so it becomes a loop, because that way you don't have to keep re-feeding the sheet back to the machine! Continue

Do you know that the sweet potato tapioca gnocchi on my blog is actually a dessert in Asia? Once theyre cooked, cool them down completely under running cold water, drain well, then transfer into a bowl. Mix well with some sugar and let sit for 30 min (so they have time to get sweetened). Serve with shaved ice, sweetened condensed milk, and dark brown sugar syrup. Get the recipe of the gnocchi on the blog!

What youre about to see, can be deeply upsetting to some. Ive never understood Italian gnocchi, airy (mushy), cloud-like (texture-less) and all. It may sound narrow-minded, but where I come from, any flour-involved savory carbohydrates, has to have a chew. Does that give me any right to entirely replace Italian gnocchi with this also soft but pleasantly chewy, mildly sweet and vibrant, and silky smooth dumpling made with sweet potato and tapioca flour? Does it help the verdict to say that its gluten-free? I dont know. Maybe Ill eat a hundred more plates of this and Ill tell you. Recipe now

Found a ratio that I like for sweet potato gnocchi made with tapioca flour and will share with you guys soon. But the tricky thing about this type of recipe is that the result largely depends on the nature of the sweet potatoes being used. Every sweet potato may contain more, or less water, and therefore may take a bit of adjustment every time to get them to the right hand-feel. Ill try my best to detail the instructions. But Im otherwise very excited because these are one of my favorite things to eat!

Asian gnocchi is made of root vegetables and tapioca flour, and is usually eaten as a dessert. This afternoon I gave them a new savory purpose and it worked out beautifully. Will document the process and post the recipe soon.

month item : Mini pork belly buns with smooth peanut butter and capers. Its your ultimate bun-tasy, two-bites-size steamed buns stuffed with braised, melty and tender pork belly, gooey and thick peanut butter and the zing of pan-fried capers, all swirling inside this chewy and but fluffy dough. Get the recipe now!

Another classic other than charsiu bun, is charsiu hand pies. The recipe for the filling is the same as the post "charsiu pull-apart pineapple bun" on the blog. To make these "cat eye" shapes: Roll puff pastry together until you have a log about 1 1/2"(4 cm) in diameter, which you cut into 1/2"(1.5 cm) thick disks. Roll into a circle, place the filling in the middle, then close like a dumplings. Invert the pie so the seam-side now faces down, then press the tips down to refine the shape. Freeze until hard then keep in an air-tight bag until needed. Brush with egg-wash, then bake in a 430 F/220 C oven for 25 min till golden browned.

MONTH item : Turnip cake fritters with prosciutto. Why was the traditional turnip cake steamed, cut, then pan-fried for a crust that barely exist? All along, it shouldve been in fritter form! An improved ratio between the turnips and the batter give these crispy babies an almost juicy interior, bursting in natural sweetness. A simple and elegant ribbon of prosciutto is all they need. Get the recipe now.

If you want to up your canned sardine pasta-game: Use the oil from the sardine cans plus lots of olive oil as your base. Saut lots of garlics, chilis, anchovies, and a few torn MAKRUT LIME LEAVES to flavor the oil. After adding the pasta, use FISH SAUCE to adjust the seasoning instead of just salt. This is an updated version from my old recipe in the archive. Search for sardine pasta on the blog for the complete recipe.

The first recipe to kick off DIM SUM MONTH: Crystal shrimp dumplings with shrimp oil mayonnaise. This recipe will correct many ignored mistakes of this classic item. It will yield a beautifully translucent and slightly bouncy wrapper, stuffed with generous amount of tiger shrimp and fatty pork filling, then highlighted with a dollop of mayonnaise made with shrimp oil. Dim sum literally means to touch heart, and this tiny little bite will certainly do just that. Get the recipe now.

Menchi katsu sando, meaning fried minced pork sandwich, is a paradox. Painfully plain, yet so addictive, a balance of taste that is satisfying yet hard to explain. Most of the recipes online is, in my opinion, lacking if not insulting, because they fail to respect the complexity of this tangy sauce that the Japanese douse upon an extensive number of dishes (okonomiyaki or takoyaki for example). Today, I bring you my version, one that is enhanced with blended potted prunes, for that extra depth of acidity and sweetness beyond just vinegar and sugar. Try it, and you'll understand why we ate this thing 10 times standing outside of convenience stores in Japan. Get the recipe now

If hair is not your thing, then you should at least care about babka. This dough is mixed with 30% sticky rice flour and 70% strong bread flour to achieve that perfect balance of softness and chewiness. Then it's rolled out thinly, rubbed with butter, and pressed with a good layer of brown sugar and Christmas spices. It bakes into a crispy-edged bread with soft but chewy body, beautiful and sweet cross sections, and a sticky gooey bottom. Not even gonna remind you how it makes your house smell like holiday jingles. Get the recipe now

If you are familiar with fermented tofu, and/or not afraid of new ingredients, then I suggest you rubbing that stuff all over lamb chops as a marinate. Then brown them in the skillet and at the last minute, add chopped garlics, tons of ground cumin and coriander, chili flakes and chopped herbs. The fermented tofu just adds a more complex savoriness, very much the way anchovies do. A pantry-must in my opinion

How to perfectly cook that soy sauce chicken you see hung behind the steamy windows of every Cantonese restaurants? Super silky and slick chicken meats with deeply savory and firm skins, simply done inside a low-temperature oven, served with steamed jasmine rice and scallion oil. Don't salivate. Get the recipe now

Strained sauce and chili oil from "Sichuan angry boiling fish" makes a perfect bath for some wontons the next day, and the rest is going to make some noodles real happy. So good. Three meals in one. Get the recipe for boiling fish on the blog

This dish, is probably the Queen B in cuisine. B, as in boiling. In a word-by-word literal translation, the dish is called "water boiled fish", but it can't be further from truth. In fact, it is thinly sliced and marinated fish scolded under a pool of red hot boiling grease, tumbling with dried chilies and Sichuan peppercorns. Pungent, painful, numbing and addictive, it's a one-way highway, and I'm dragging you down with me. Recipe is now

I have found over-proofing to be a real danger in when it comes to baking breads. I don't know if it's the humidity or warm climate (even though I had my AC on), the dough expands almost twice as fast in room-temperature, and even in the fridge! I don't know if there's a correlation between this and the fact that foods also spoil faster even in the fridge in this semi-tropical climate. But this highlights the complex variants and factors when it comes to baking breads, that no recipe is perfect without hands-on experiences. For example. Now when I bake breads in Hong Kong, I use only 1/2 the amount of yeast from recipes that worked well in northern climates. If you're baking breads in semi-tropical climates using recipes developed in norther America or Europe, and wondered why it didn't work well, this might provide some help. By the way, if you like our blog, please give us support by voting on @saveurmag 2016 food blog awards, for best how-to blog. Thanks

Dinner is flattened chicken legs with crispy skin and herb salad (lemongrass, lime leaves, shallots, chili, mint, cilantro, fish sauce, lime juice, olive oil, white pepper). Snapper fins poached in a sauce of lime juice, fish sauce, sake, mirin, minced garlic and cilantro. Jasmine rice. Movie

Know what I miss the most from the Mediterranean? It wasn't a creation from any Michelin chefs, but these fresh anchovies we bought from a local market in . I painstakingly cleaned/deboned the anchovies, marinated them in lemon juice and sea salt, then served them with minced shallots, extra virgin olive oil and a dusting of sumac. Life is no longer enough without it. Here's my howling call to all markets in Hong Kong. Please. Fresh anchovies

My first fruit pie, not of this season, but like ever! I mean I've made creme brle pie and chicken swamp pies (all on the blog) before, but never a fruit pie. Just a few tweaks away from being shared with you. Crochet plate from @dishesonly
My new hobby

After a 16-hours coma, I'm recounting the trophies we laboriously carried back from . Forget Chanel. We are going to start in Paris, then Beaune, Lyon, Lourmarin, Marseille, Cannes, then return our car in Nice. This is the first time we attempt such a long road trip like this. Wish us luck! Carefully scored chicken thighs clothed in a Balinese-style, reduced and intensely aromatic paste, charred over the grill then dipped in a spicy and sweet peanut sauce deepened with pured chicken livers. Last but not least, how I cooked the mushroom water pasta shaped using a tongs: the mushrooms that were soaked are sauted with shallots and garlic. Cook in a bit of flour and milk, then lots of shredded Gouda cheese and a pinch of nutmeg to make a creamy sauce. Finish the pasta in the sauce and serve. Watch how to make these pasta in the videos on the blog

Typhoon night is cleaning-out-the-fridge night. Blanched water spinach mixed with stewed green chili pure. Caramelized cherry tomatoes and basil omelette. Stir-fried bean curd with beef and Sichuan fermented chili paste. Steamed rice. Game set

How I cooked my rice spatula-formed fresh pasta that I call arachidi (peanuts): oil and fish sauce stewed green chili, pured with garlic and a few drops of vinegar (similar recipe as "mean Santa chili sauce" on the blog). Cook the arachidi when they still have a bite, then finish cooking them generously coated in the chili sauce. Shower with parmigiano. To watch the video on how to form these fresh pastas with simple kitchen tools, visit the blog now
Finally, holding in his hand, is the famous Pork chop bun. The chop is not as generous as advertised though, but the flavors are alright

How I cook the fresh paprika pasta: hot skillet. Lots of olive oil. Tons of thinly shaved garlics, like 6 cloves, and a large handful of halved cherry tomatoes. Then 6 to 7 torn kaffir lime leaves! Yes! Sea salt plus a drizzle of fish sauce, peppers, chili flakes, cook until soft, add the pasta, then blanket it with lots of fresh Thai basils. With a cup of iced coffee, is there better summer lunch? For how to hand-shape these fresh pastas, go on the blog for videos and more tricks
Here's another fresh pasta shaped by rice spatula! I call them arachidi (peanuts in Italian lol)! Watch all three videos on the blog for other tricks, plus detailed recipes

Inspired by @miyukiadachi, three videos now on how to make fresh pastas using simple kitchen tools, plus three different pasta dough to be used interchangeably! Seriously, this is so much more fun than Pokemon

Three different types of infused pasta doughs - paprika, basil, and mushroom water - are about to go through texturized boards (homemade or from everyday gadgets like tongs!) to become different pastas! Thank you @miyukiadachi for this revelation. Recipes and results on the blog

Trying to crack that mysterious swirl of @bill.granger's scrambled eggs. So far, still mysterious. If you have any insights into how to achieve that drapery-like, swirly tower of scrambled eggs, please come forward.

@tylerkord, I hate you. Why are you the human who invented the mystical substance called "pho mayo", and not me? But guess what, I stole your pho mayo and blown it up, and made what I call a summer pho bo roll. You invented a mayo that tastes like pho bo, but I have an entire sandwich that IS the reincarnation of pho bo, semi-cooked beef, Thai basil, bean sprouts, srirracha and everything! It's stupid but I won. Recipe now

I never understood General Tsao's chicken until now. Super crispy chicken wings (and stays crispy!) coated in a tangy, sweet, spicy and garlicky sauce with a jewel-like gloss. The base of the sauce is a reduction of pomegranate and cranberry juice which gives it a fruity and complex flavor. Go ahead and wing it! It's more than finger-licking good. Recipe now

Found some really cool kitchenwares from a kitchen supply store in 's Chinatown, especially these aluminum, wide-brim pots with wooden handles! They look like inverted fedora hats! This week, I want to let you in on a secret ingredient of mine, my new MSG - the cured duck yolk. The most underrated Asian ingredient, even in Asia! Once you've crossed the mental barrier of unfamiliarity, you will realize it's nothing but a duck egg cured within its own shell, intense and jewel-like, a compressed soul. For the next couple post, I'm going to share some ideas on how to utilize it, starting with the most extraordinary, flavorful, and creamy carbonara you have ever had. Recipe now
It's that kind of Monday.
Do you know what this is? This is an uncooked yolk from a Chinese salted duck egg, the most underrated ingredient available in most Asian market. Ideas on how to use them to the blog

Chrysanths, or mums, are the most underrated flowers. For some reasons that in Asia, they are always associated with funerals and bad fortunes when in fact, they are one of the most beautiful flowers out there. Perhaps beautiful things come with a bit of sadness
Treating myself dangerously with rampantly runny yolk over creamy risotto. Hello my name is Mandy. I am egg-intolerant and today, I don't fucking care
