Do you love squishy, sweet, borderline childish soft white bread? My friends, the unicorn. Made with 24% sticky rice flour (it won't eat like mochi), this bread has that specific chew, the perfect spot between elasticity and softness. Smeared simply with a thick layer of peanut butter, untoasted please, they are happy pillows for your taste buds. Get the recipe now
I've been trying to nail this recipe for months! Super soft, pillowy and chewy sticky rice bread is to the blog

First it was blue, then it's purple. When it comes to coloring walls, I clearly have CDD - commitment deficit disorder. Not sure if it will be another color next week, but right now it looks pretty nice with jian-shui (sodium carbonate/alkaline salt) zongzi with black sugar syrup, and amazing @annladson's beautiful brass spoon

Love this old-school Hong Kong towel that says "wish you a good morning", and it certainly is with my magic 15-seconds scrambled eggs with shaved Parmesan and chili flakes. Search for "magic scrambled egg" on the blog for the recipe! It will change your mornings
Coffee pearls for breakfast.

We finally start cooking again! Come taste the most iconic Street food of Hong Kong, a glorious bastard child drawing influences from several regions cuisines - the curry fish balls! Eat them in a paper cup with toothpicks, or pour over a bed of instant ramen. Get the recipe now

My first batch of The Monday Blues oatmeal cookies in the new kitchen. Took a bit getting used to the new settings, but these blueberry and burnt butter oatmeal cookies are as good as ever. Search for the recipe on the blog
Took a break from all the cleaning and unpacking, and filled our new home with the aroma of freshly baked bread. Which in itself reinforced the feeling that we're indeed, home

This zig-zag mosaic tile floor in the bedrooms is my favorite new feature of our apartment in Hong Kong. We designed and renovated this apartment ourselves 6 years ago, and 6 years later, we finally put down the final touch. I can't wait to share more photos with you (and start cooking in the new kitchen!), but right now this tiny square is about the only space not covered in stuff! There will be some behind-the-scene messiness on snapchat
Just saw the @nytimes articles on making its way into the NYC food scene! Guess what? You can make your own at home! Search for "Jian Bing" on the blog for one of the best Jian-Bing you'll ever have

The apartment is still under construction and my mind has already wondered off to the balcony garden. I shall name this baby lemon tree... Sourpuss

What's the best thing that could come out of a hotel room? How about a Cantonese-style roast pork sandwich, dripping with scallion and ginger oil, fish sauce and a dash of red wine vinegar, topped with provolone cheese and a crusty roll that catches all the actions? Get the recipe for the sandwich (plus how to make these roast pork at home now

I thought the last, perfect parting-Beijing post wold be to recreate that fried chicken I mentioned from the corner grocery store. But the first trial confirmed that it's special for a reason, and further tweaking and refinement needs to be done. So I guess, I'll keep them to myself for now

Whenever I'm asked to submit a "self-portrait", I cringe. I believe I have a birth defect that disables me from making eye-contacts with cameras. And aside from that, I also don't know the perfect balance between looking like a homeless sloth (reality) to looking like an utter pretense (fantasy). So this is my best effort on the closest representation of myself. If you ever bump into me, chances are I will be in a newsboy hat (I have years-long friends who actually don't even know what my hair looks like), loose sweater and sweat pants, eating some kind of meat buns. Ok, fine, maybe in a much less flattering light, but hey, I will at least cut myself that much slack
A creme brle croissant from 's Urban Bakery on a rainy day

Another look at the spicy tomato, shaved garlics and melted Gouda I made a while back. I find that an inverted, heavy cast iron skillet works better than an actual pizza stone for that crispy crust. Crochet plate from @DishesOnly

I quite like my coffee crema yesterday. Looks like a baby whale swimming in a swirling milky cosmos on a journey of wondrous things. Or, about to be eaten by a huge monster, dead and the end... Depending on your perspective of things

I get asked sometimes about the setting of my "shoot", and I thought I should post a zoomed out photo of what's outside the frame. The typical black background is just a piece of black fabric, most times not even leveled, that I hang by the window. I like how it creates a completely different space within the room. If I'm using artificial lights, the soft light-box would be placed at where the "window" is supposed to be. I use a canon 6D with 35mm 1:1.4, and photoshop for editing. So there

Baked a gorgeous purple yam bread yesterday, using a proofing basket for the first time for that spiral look. Chewy with a hint of sweetness and floral tones, and it keeps moist longer than other country breads. Search for "purple yam bread" on the blog

Grilled cheese's new is spicy coconut soup! Save your shrimp shells and use them along with red curry paste and a bit of tomato paste to make a quick but delicious coconut broth. A grown-up version from tomato soups that is so much better

My latest yummy-but-coincidentally-healthy stuff to eat: spicy salmon bibimbap. You won't believe how delicious something can be when so minimal amount of "cooking" is required. I feel enormously satisfied but strangely guiltless at the same time, and you don't hear these words together a lot. Recipe is now

There's a local supermarket around my block in with a dubious fried chicken booth inside, sometimes with a line in front when a new batch comes out. Over the years for some reasons, common sense mostly, I never tried it. But today, perhaps realizing that I've ingested plenty of more dubious meats in my life to be judgmental, I bought a piece. And holy shit. Yeah . One of the best fried chickens I've ever had in my life. To bring it to your table, an investigation is now ongoing
At the Korean bakery, Tous les Jours in . Wonderful things that happen to make the French's blood boil - hot dog in a croissant. Awesomeness

Ok, two things. First, anything feels tastier if you serve it in a pie pan, even a cleaning-out-the-fridge kinda meal. Second, this Keeping Up With The GOP's reality show is getting old

When I get new wooden spoons, boards, or anything really, I always use a coarse sand-paper to get rid of that brand new sheen. I focus on corners, areas where will most likely wear off, to "fake age". Then I rub them with a little flaxseed oil (best oil to season anything), then wipe the excess off with a towel. I feel more attached to them after I brutalized them. Feels more "mine".
One of our favorite dinner options, torched salmon in green juice sauce. So refreshing and feeling-good-about-my-diet every time! Search "torched salmon in green juice" on the blog.

If in my 20's, you told that in the near future, I'd be eating granola yogurt and listening to zen music from APP store, just to calm the fuck down about my dermatitis flare-ups that's making me shed like a sheep dog... I'd think you had serious issues. Well hello, reality (earphones from @sudiosweden)

Finally, the question haunts me no longer. What is a perfect pastel de nata? I now have my own answer. A hybrid between and , these egg tarts have incredibly and audibly crispy shells made with the zero-folding method using a pasta-machine, and a custard-filling that is super supple, flan-like, and decadently wiggly. The entire recipe, from beginning to end, can be done in 4 hours. Believe me, it's a small commitment to pay for these bad babies. Recipe now
No-folding laminated dough, check. Flan-like custard, check
My favorite pastime activity is to eat a whole, uncut Danish brioche, tearing it string from strings. I allow myself this pleasure once a month. Ok maybe twice

Whenever I accidentally land on a tough cut of meat, I flour and season it, then brown it nicely in a roasting pan. I then add a couple of halved onions, garlics, super large chunks of potato, bay leaves and a splash of sake, cover, then I throw it inside a 120 C/250 F oven overnight (usually 10 to 12 hours). Literally set it then forget it. The next morning, you'll wake up to the most intoxicating aroma of roasting meats. I serve it with salsa verde
The new @bonappetitmag issue is making me crave making-pizzas, and the crave for making pizzas waits for no one. Crushed tomatoes, shaved garlics, grated Gouda and fresh basils. Cheers, weekend
Friday starts with coffee, magazine, and a great revelation that even failed tastes good. @bonappetitmag
Inspired and adapted from 's cookbook! Charred cauliflower with fried garlics, chills, and Tabasco vinegar. It's a robust feast of salty and sweet, spicy and acidic crunches. Recipe now

A little trick I do when it comes to cooking river fishes (like catfish, trout, etc), is to marinate it in a combination of grated ginger and cheap sake (or rice wine). The neutral flavors from the sake and sharpness of the ginger help making river fishes taste cleaner and less "muddy". I do this to sea fishes as well sometimes

This was the soup-version of the sticky rice balls stuffed with jalapeo pork, in super dense chicken broth creamed with a bit of soy milk, then seasoned with fried shallots and herbs. Again, you can find the sticky rice ball recipe on the blog. And search "golden foundation" for dense chicken stock

Over the CNY holidays, I made a bunch of sticky rice balls filled with pickled jalapeo pork and kept them frozen for whenever. You can get creative with them. I eat them with soup, and I also eat them dry (like these ones) while reading the @missionchinesefood cookbook. There's a new update on the recipe by the way. Search for "sticky rice ball" on the blog and check it out

It's called mian-xian (noodle threads) in , or suo-mian (wire noodle) in southern China, or a shorter Japanese version called somen. It's long, soft and elastic, symbolizing longevity in Chinese holidays. But that's not why you should start eating it. You should eat it simply because it's freaking good, especially soaked in dense chicken broth darkened with a gingery and garlicky black sesame paste, with the pungent aroma of crispy fried shallots. It's the ultimate February comfort food. The recipe is now. Happy CNY

There's a "yogurt" function in my rice-cooker (basically keeping the content at 110F/43C) that I never used. Yesterday, I whisked a little bit of plain yogurt (which I wasn't even sure if contains any active yeasts) with whole milk, pushed the button and 6 hours later, HOMEMADE YOGURT!! Guys, listen, if you're reluctant to make yogurt at home because the online instructions tell you to heat milk to 180 F the cool it down to 110F (which is a pain in the ass), guess what, YOU DON'T HAVE TO!! As long as you buy pasteurized milk, which was already heated to kill bacterias (and also breaking down the proteins in order for them to congeal), then this step is completely redundant. Just rinse all your pots with boiling water, then whisk 3 tbsp of plain active yeast-yogurt (or called probiotic) with 750 ml to 1 liter of milk. Then leave it at a very warm place (110F/43C)(I'm thinking maybe the lowest setting inside the oven could work) for 6 hours (the longer you leave it, the thicker and tangier). And boom! Homemade yogurt!! So easy

Super cold days are for staying at home and making duck rillette. There is a recipe on the blog's archive, but over the years, I've adapted by blending it in the foo-processor (instead of mixer) to get a creamier cinsistency, and adding lots of pickled green peppercorns for a nice heads-up in the flavor profile. It tastes better than anything you can buy in the stores.

Behold, fellow sloth-mates, the easiest yet delicious cake I have yet to encounter. The Texas chocolate sheet cake. No creaming, sifting, or any heavy machineries. Have you ever had a "skin egg/, or better known as the thousand years old egg? Most people think it looks horrid, but I think it's one of the most beautiful thing there is. The freckled egg shell has a blue-ish tin, and opens up to a jewel-like, translucent interior with pine leaves patterns. The good ones differ greatly in taste and texture from the mediocre ones, which are probably the majorities out there. It's an acquired taste for sure. One of my favorite thing

My first time spotting and using Asian chive's blossoms. They've got a faint garlicky scent, and are going to decorate an unconventional "cake" for my 's big 15th!

Homemade no-churn soft-serve ice cream infused with roasted barley tea powder! The slight smokiness almost taste coffee- like! If you wanna try it yourself, use the "no-churn mascarpone soft-serve" recipe on the blog. Add 2 tbsp of roasted barley tea powder while heating up the milk and gelatin, then whisk in 1/2 cup of heavy cream and reduce the mascarpone by 1/2. So good. (Fyi, black ice cream cones from McDonald's in Beijing

practice continues. Hong-chen, "red dust" in direct translation. It means the obscure meaninglessness that is living. "Tumbling red dust" can imply the suffering and intangibility of life. "To see through/break the red dust" is to let go of attachments in life and to pursuit enlightenment. In this very particular case, "red dust" is ground cayenne pepper. Yum.

In Beijing, when the weather wakes up from a cold and dry winter, just when you think you can finally enjoy a bit of life... the spring comes full force with flowers-blooming and tree cum-blazing. You heard right. Tree CUM. The cotton-like, mini pom-pom tree-pollens filtrating and pillaging every inch of air in this city. Even if you are free from tree cum-allergy, you cannot escape the fate of feeling like getting tree-fucked in the eyes every time you go outside. I wish I can show you what it's like, but these sneaky little bastards are difficult to capture. Help! I'm going blind! Update: if you wanna know what it's like, Google "Beijing tree fluff" for images

To love a dog is a greater love than loving a child. It is not coded in blood or nature. It is not held by future, hope or prospect. They are not an extension of ourselves. They are not the continuation of our existence. They will not be the comfort we seek by our deathbeds, because it would be the other way around. We love them when they were young. We love them when they are now old, sick, frail and smells. We love them, even knowing it will end, period, and this will be all there is. I don't need to give birth to know what it's like to be mother. I am already.

Operation Wednesday: flop-cake resurrection. Got any bad/dry/days-old/dense flopped cakes that you don't know what to do with? Inspired by Milk Bar's cake truffle, simply mix the crumbled cake with enough milk, amaretto liquor and tiny bit of vanilla extract until you can form a moist ball with it. Let soak for 15 min then make into patties. Brown in skillet over low heat, 3~4 min on each side, then ice cream, maple syru, eat hot. Tah-dah. They will melt in your mouth
